(c)  Whenever in opening, extending, or widening any street, avenue, alley, or public place of the city a small parcel or tract of land is cut off or separated by such work from a larger tract or boundary of land owned by the city, the city council may authorize the mayor to execute and deliver in the name of the city a deed conveying said cut-off or separated parcel or tract of land to an abutting or adjoining property owner or owners in exchange for rights of way of said street, avenue, alley, or public place when such exchange is deemed to be in the best interest of the city. All deeds and conveyances heretofore and hereafter so executed and delivered shall convey all title and interest the city has in such property, notwithstanding the fact that no public sale after advertisement was or is hereafter made. 
(Ord. No. 2018-03, § 5, 6-11-2018) 
ARTICLE VII. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 7.10. - Bonds for officials. 
The officers and employees of this city, both elected and appointed, shall execute such surety or fidelity bonds in such amounts and upon such terms and conditions as the city council shall from time to time require by ordinance or as may be provided by law. 
Sec. 7.11. - Prior ordinances. 
All ordinances, resolutions, rules, and regulations now in force in the city not inconsistent with this Charter are declared valid and of full effect and force until amended or repealed by the city council. 
Sec. 7.12. - First election under this Charter. 
Those persons serving as mayor and councilmembers on the effective date of the adoption of this Charter shall serve out the remainder of their respective terms of office and until respective successors are elected and qualified. The first municipal election shall be on the Tuesday next following the first Monday in November, 1997, at which successors to councilmembers whose terms expire December 31, 1997, shall be elected for an initial term of four years and until respective successors are elected and qualified such that a continuing body is created. Successors to the mayor and councilmembers whose terms expire December 31, 1999, shall be elected in the municipal general election held in 1999 for an initial term of four years and until respective successors are elected and qualified. Each mayor and councilmember elected thereafter shall serve a full term as provided in Section 2.11 of this Charter. 
Sec. 7.13. - Pending matters. 
Except as specifically provided otherwise by this Charter, all rights, claims, actions, orders, contracts, and legal or administrative proceedings shall continue and any such ongoing work or cases shall be completed by such city agencies, personnel, or offices as may be provided by the city council. 
Sec. 7.14. - Definitions and construction. 
(a)  Section captions in this Charter are informative only and shall not be considered as a part thereof. 
(b)  The word "shall" is mandatory and the word "may" is permissive. 
(c)  The singular shall include the plural, the masculine shall include the feminine, and vice versa. 
Sec. 7.15. - Specific repealer. 
An Act incorporating the City of Lake City in the County of Clayton, approved February 12, 1951 (Ga. L. 1951, p. 2351), as amended, is repealed in its entirety. 
Sec. 7.16. - Submission for approval. 
It shall be the duty of the governing authority of the City of Lake City to require the attorney therefor to submit this Act for approval pursuant to Section 5 of the federal Voting Rights Act of 1965, as amended. 
Sec. 7.17. - Effective date. 
This section and Section 7.16 of this Act shall become effective upon its approval by the Governor or upon its becoming law without such approval. The remaining sections of this Act shall become effective July 1, 1996. 
Sec. 7.18. - General repealer. 
All laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are repealed. 
CHARTER COMPARATIVE TABLE 
This table shows the location of the sections of the basic Charter and any amendments thereto. 

 
CHARTER COMPARATIVE TABLE ORDINANCES 
This table gives the location within this Charter of those ordinances which are included herein. 

 
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. 
The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated "The Code of the City of Lake City, Georgia," and may be so cited. The Code may also be cited as the "Lake City Code" or the "city Code." 
(Code 1972, § 1-1; Code 1994, § 1-1) 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances of the city, the rules of construction as contained in O.C.G.A. §§ 1-3-1 and 1-3-3 shall prevail, except that the following shall take precedence if in conflict with O.C.G.A. §§ 1-3-1 and 1-3-3: 
City. The term "the city" or "this city" shall be construed as if the term "of Lake City" followed the term "city" and shall extend to and include its several officers, agents and employees. 
City clerk. The term "city clerk" means the city clerk of the City of Lake City. 
Code. The term "Code" means "The Code of the City of Lake City, Georgia," or the "Lake City Code." 
Computation of time. When a period of time measured in days, weeks, months, years or other measurements of time, except hours, is prescribed for the exercise of any privilege or the discharge of any duty, the first day shall not be counted but the last day shall be counted; if the last day falls on Saturday or Sunday, the person having such privilege or duty shall have through the following Monday to exercise the privilege or to discharge the duty. When the last day prescribed for such action falls on a public and legal holiday provided for in O.C.G.A. § 1-4-1, the person having the privilege or duty shall have through the next business day to exercise the privilege or to discharge the duty. When the period of time prescribed is less than seven days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays shall be excluded in the computation. 
Conjunctions. In a provision involving two or more items, conditions, provisions or events, which items, conditions, provisions or events are connected by the conjunction "and," "or" or "either … or," the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows, except that in appropriate cases the terms "or" and "and" are interchangeable: 
(1)  "And" indicates that all the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events apply. 
(2)  "Or" indicates that the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events apply singly or in any combination. 
(3)  "Either … or" indicates that the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events apply singly but not in combination. 
County. The term "the county" or "this county" means the County of Clayton in the State of Georgia. 
Delegation of authority. Whenever a section appears requiring the head of a department of the city to do some act, it is to be construed to authorize him to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act, unless the terms of the section designate otherwise. 
Employee. The term "employee" means an employee of the city. 
Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
Governing authority, governing body. The term "governing authority" or "governing body" means the mayor and city council of the City of Lake City, Georgia. 
Interpretation. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of this Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provision imposed by this Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. 
Joint authority. All terms giving a joint authority to three or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
Keeper and proprietor. The terms "keeper" and "proprietor" mean and include persons, firms, associations, corporations, clubs and copartnerships, whether acting by themselves or by a servant, agent or employee. 
Mayor. The term "mayor" means the mayor of the City of Lake City. 
Mayor and council. The term "mayor and council" means the mayor and council of the City of Lake City. 
Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. 
Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
Number. Any word importing the singular number shall include the plural and any word importing the plural number shall include the singular. 
Oath. The term "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases, the terms "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the terms "affirm" and "affirmed." 
O.C.G.A. The abbreviation "O.C.G.A." means the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, as amended. 
Officials and officers. Whenever reference is made to officials, boards, commissions, departments, etc., by title only (i.e., "city clerk," "chief of police," etc.), the reference shall be deemed to refer to the officials, boards, commissions and departments of the City of Lake City. 
Owner. The term "owner," applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety of the whole or of a part of such building or land. The term "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any person, agent, operator, firm or corporation having a legal or equitable interest in the property; or recorded in the official records of the state, county or municipality as holding title to the property; or otherwise having control of the property, including the guardian of the estate of any such person, and the executor or administrator of the estate of such person if ordered to take possession of real property by a court. 
Person. The term "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate, as well as to individuals. 
Shall, may. "Shall" is mandatory, and "may" is permissive. 
State. The term "the state" or "this state" means the State of Georgia. 
Street. The term "street" shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public streets and ways in the city and shall embrace all parts thereof constituting the designated right-of-way. 
Tenant, occupant. The term "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, includes any person holding a written or oral lease or who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. 
Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
Week. The term "week" means seven days. 
Year. The term "year" means a calendar year. 
(Code 1972, § 1-2; Code 1994, § 1-2; Ord. No. 05-01, § 1, 6-13-2005) 
State Law reference— Statutory definitions and rules of construction, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1 et seq.; computation of time, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1; construction of definitions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-2; meaning of certain words, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3; time, O.C.G.A. § 9-11-6. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections; history notes and reference notes. 
(a)  The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections or as any part of the section nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(b)  The history notes appearing in parentheses after each section and the references and editor's notes scattered throughout the Code are for the benefit of the user of the Code and shall have no legal effect. 
(Code 1972, § 1-3; Code 1994, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - Repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect or any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal for an offense committed under the ordinance repealed. 
(c)  An ordinance which is in conflict in its entirety with a subsequent ordinance shall be deemed to be repealed in its entirety, even if no specific repealer is stated. If an ordinance is only partially in conflict with a subsequent ordinance, only the portion of the previous ordinance in conflict with the subsequent ordinance shall be deemed to have been repealed, even if a specific repealer is not stated. 
(Code 1972, § 1-4; Code 1994, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-5. - Severability. 
(a)  It is hereby declared to be the intention of the mayor and council that all sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are or were, upon their enactment, believed by the mayor and council to be fully valid, enforceable and constitutional. 
(b)  It is hereby declared to be the intention of the mayor and council that, to the greatest extent allowed by law, each and every section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this Code is severable from every other section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this Code. It is hereby further declared to be the intention of the mayor and council that, to the greatest extent allowed by law, no section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this Code is mutually dependent upon any other section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this Code. 
(c)  In the event that any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall, for any reason whatsoever, be declared invalid, unconstitutional or otherwise unenforceable by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, it is the express intent of the mayor and council that such invalidity, unconstitutionality or unenforceability shall, to the greatest extent allowed by law, not render invalid, unconstitutional or otherwise unenforceable any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs or sections of this Code and that, to the greatest extent allowed by law, all remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code shall remain valid, constitutional, enforceable, and of full force and effect. 
(Code 1972, § 1-5; Code 1994, § 1-5; Ord. No. 00-06, § 1, 9-11-2000) 
Sec. 1-6. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion in this Code. If chapters, sections or subsections or any parts thereof are repealed by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time as this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new code of ordinances by the mayor and council. 
(b)  Amendments to any section of this Code shall be made by amending such section by specific reference to the section number of this Code in substantially the following language: "That section ____________ of The Code of the City of Lake City, Georgia, is hereby amended to read as follows:…." The new section shall then be set out in full. 
(c)  If a new section not existing in the Code is to be added, language substantially similar to the following shall be used: "That The Code of the City of Lake City, Georgia, is hereby amended by adding a section (or article or chapter) to be numbered ____________ , which said section (or article or chapter) reads as follows:…." The new section, article or chapter shall then be set out in full. 
(Code 1972, § 1-6; Code 1994, § 1-6) 
Sec. 1-7. - Altering Code. 
It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever except by ordinance or resolution or other official act of the mayor and council, which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. 
(Code 1972, § 1-7; Code 1994, § 1-7) 
Sec. 1-8. - General penalty. 
(a)  In this section the phrase "violation of this Code" or "violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance" means any of the following: 
(1)  Doing an act that is prohibited or made or declared unlawful, an offense, a violation or a misdemeanor by ordinance, by statute adopted by reference in this Code, by state rule or regulation adopted by reference in this Code, or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(2)  Failure to perform an act that is required to be performed by ordinance, by statute adopted by reference in this Code, by state rule or regulation adopted by reference in this Code or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(3)  Failure to perform an act if the failure is prohibited or is made or declared unlawful, an offense, a violation or a misdemeanor by ordinance, by statute adopted by reference in this Code, by state rule or regulation adopted by reference in this Code or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(b)  In this section the phrase "violation of this Code" or "violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance" does not include the failure of a city officer or city employee to perform an official duty unless it is specifically provided that the failure to perform the duty is to be punished as provided in this section. 
(c)  Unless a higher penalty is otherwise specified, whenever in this Code or in any ordinance of the city any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in this Code or any ordinance the doing of any act is required and the failure to do such act is declared to be unlawful, and no specific penalty is provided, and unless otherwise provided by state law, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 and imprisonment in the city or county jail and work and labor on the streets or public works of the city, whether within or without the corporate limits, not exceeding 180 days, or both a fine and sentence of imprisonment and labor; and all sentences may be in the alternative and fines may be imposed with the alternative of sentence to imprisonment and labor if the fines are not paid. Each day any violation of this Code or of any ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(d)  Violations of this Code may be abated by injunctive or other equitable relief. The imposition of a penalty does not prevent injunctive relief. 
(e)  The infliction of a penalty under the provisions of this section shall not prevent the revocation of any permit or license or the taking of other punitive or remedial action where called for or permitted under the provisions of the city's Charter or this Code. 
(Code 1972, § 1-8; Code 1994, § 1-8; Ord. of 9-28-1972) 
State Law reference— Maximum sentences and fines which may be imposed for violation of municipal ordinance, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2). 
Sec. 1-9. - Right of entry. 
Whenever any officer or employee is required or authorized by any state law, any section of this Code or any ordinance or resolution or rule or order issued thereunder to enter any premises or vehicle for the purpose of making an inspection of the premises or vehicle or of anything contained in the premises or vehicle for the purpose of carrying out his duties, such officer or employee shall have the right to enter any such premises or vehicle at any reasonable time in pursuance of such duties, provided that such entry and inspection shall be made in a lawful manner. 
(Code 1972, § 1-8; Code 1994, § 1-9; Ord. of 9-28-1972) 
Sec. 1-10. - Provisions considered as continuation of existing ordinances. 
The provisions appearing in this and the following chapters and sections, so far as they are the same as those of ordinances or resolutions existing at the time of the adoption of this Code, shall be considered as a continuation thereof and not as new enactments. 
Sec. 1-11. - Prior offenses, penalties and rights not affected by adoption of Code. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty of forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed as abating any action pending under or by virtue of any general ordinance of the city repealed in this chapter, and all general ordinances contained in this Code shall be deemed to be continuing and not a new enactment of the same ordinance. This chapter shall not be deemed as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering any penalty accrued or to accrue or as affecting the liability of any person or as waiving any right of the city under any ordinance or section thereof in force at the time of the adoption of this Code. 
Sec. 1-12. - Rates, charges, and fees established. 
(a)  Unless otherwise provided for, all rates, charges, or fees necessary for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this Code shall be as currently established or as hereafter adopted by motion, resolution or ordinance of the city council, from time to time. Any rates, charges, or fees established by the city pursuant to the regulations or requirements established in this Code may be changed from time to time by the mayor and council, and such changes shall both be considered an amendment to this Code. 
(b)  Whenever any provision of this Code provides that a rate, charge, or fee shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and the amount of such rate, charge, or fee is not expressed in this Code in any dollar amount, then the amount of such rate, charge, or fee shall be the most recent and latest amount established, set or fixed by the mayor and council by ordinance, resolution or motion. 
Sec. 1-13. - Miscellaneous ordinances, resolutions and actions not affected by Code. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect the following: 
(1)  Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract, established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. 
(2)  Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness or any contract or obligation assumed by the city. 
(3)  Any right or franchise granted by any ordinance or resolution of the mayor and council to any person. 
(4)  Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening or vacating any street or public way in the city. 
(5)  Any ordinance levying or imposing taxes not included in this Code. 
(6)  Ordinances prescribing traffic regulations for specific locations, prescribing through streets, bus stops, taxi stands, parking prohibitions, parking limitations, one-way traffic, limitations on load of vehicles or loading zones, consistent with this Code. 
(7)  Any specific rezoning ordinance or any amendment thereto. 
(8)  Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the city. 
(9)  Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor. 
(10)  Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city. 
(11)  Any ordinance extending the boundaries of the city. 
(12)  Any ordinance or resolution fixing the salary of any city officer or employee, unless superseded. 
(13)  Any ordinance or resolution establishing and/or prescribing employment, benefits, and/or personnel policies and procedures. 
(14)  Any right of franchise granted by the city to any person, firm, or corporation. 
(15)  Any appropriation ordinance. 
(16)  Any ordinance or resolution which, by its own terms, is effective for a stated or limited term. 
(17)  Any ordinance or resolution describing or altering the boundaries of the city or annexing property to the city. 
(18)  The administrative ordinances or resolutions of the city not in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of this Code. 
(19)  Any ordinance or resolution of agreement with another political subdivision. 
(20)  Any other ordinance or resolution, or part thereof, which is not of a general and permanent nature; or which is referred to elsewhere in this Code as continuing in effect. 
(b)  Nor shall the repeal of any such ordinance or resolution be construed to revive any ordinance, resolution or part thereof that has been repealed or superseded by a subsequent ordinance or resolution which is repealed or superseded by this chapter. All such ordinances, resolutions and actions are recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
(Code 1994, § 1-10; Ord. of 6-8-1972, § 3) 
Sec. 1-14. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared at least on an annual basis. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive, permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions. 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles. 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers. 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ____________ to ____________ " (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code). 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meanings of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
Sec. 1-15. - Default time limit. 
Whenever this Code provides for the performance of any official act or decision by any person or entity, but fails specifically to provide a time limit for performance of the official act or the rendering of the decision, the act shall be performed or the decision rendered within 30 days of the event rendering the performance of the act necessary or possible. If the final day for performance of the act or rendering of the decision falls on a weekend or a legal holiday on which the government offices of the city are closed, then the final day shall be extended to the next weekday on which the government offices of the city are open. 
(Ord. No. 00-05, § 1, 9-11-2000) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Books and records. 
All books and records of the city of every nature shall be kept at the city hall. The original of any book or record shall not be removed from city hall without the permission of the mayor or upon response to a court directive or subpoena. The city clerk shall be the official custodian of the city records, and every citizen shall have the right to inspect and copy city records. If the city is requested to provide copies, the city clerk shall furnish the copies for a fee of $1.00 per page. 
(Code 1972, § 2-13; Code 1994, § 2-1) 
Sec. 2-2. - Ordinances and resolutions. 
All ordinances and resolutions shall be approved as to form by the city attorney, shall be signed by the mayor or, in the absence of the mayor, by the mayor pro tem and shall be attested by the city clerk. The clerk shall affix the seal of the city. The original of every ordinance and resolution shall be inserted into official books maintained for this purpose by the city clerk. 
(Code 1972, § 2-16; Code 1994, § 2-2) 
Secs. 2-3—2-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FINANCE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-23. - Signatures on city checks. 
All checks written by and for the city shall contain two authorized signatures. 
(Code 1994, § 2-26) 
Sec. 2-24. - Contracts. 
All contracts entered into by the city shall be in writing and reviewed by the city attorney. If within the spending authority of the city manager, they may be signed by the city manager. Anything outside the spending authority of the city manager, or contracts otherwise required to be approved by mayor and city council by the City Charter or applicable state law, shall be signed by the mayor or, in the absence of the mayor, by the mayor pro tem. The city shall have an executed copy of each contract, and the copy shall be inserted into an official book maintained for this purpose by the city clerk. 
(Code 1972, § 2-17; Code 1994, § 2-27; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 1, 4-9-2018) 
Secs. 2-25—2-51. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PURCHASING 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 2-52. - Objectives. 
The objectives of this division are: 
(1)  To conduct city business in such an open manner that potential vendors will recognize the fairness of the system and thus be encouraged to compete which will ensure that the city will secure the best product at the lowest price at all times. 
(2)  To encourage competitive purchasing. 
(3)  To develop and maintain an adequate supply of materials, services and supplies as required. 
(4)  To give due consideration to ethical and quality standards and also to real value rather than price alone. 
(5)  To establish and build good relations with suppliers and departments. 
(6)  To purchase the highest quality in supplies, equipment and contractual services at the least expense. 
(Res. No. 98-01, exh. A, § I, 2-9-1998) 
Sec. 2-53. - Purchasing agent—Selection. 
The purchasing agent shall be selected by the city manager and shall be under the direct supervision of the finance department. 
(Res. No. 98-01, exh. A, § II, 2-9-1998; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 2, 4-9-2018) 
Sec. 2-54. - Same—Powers and duties. 
(a)  The powers and duties of the purchasing agent shall be as follows: 
(1)  Observe and enforce the procedures outlined in this division. 
(2)  Procure for the city the highest quality in supplies and services at the least expense. 
(3)  Supervise and be held responsible for a decentralized purchasing system, where the purchasing agent and department heads have purchasing authority. 
(4)  Encourage competitive bidding at all possible times. 
(5)  Explore the possibilities of buying in bulk to take full advantage of discounts. 
(6)  Adopt as standards the minimum number of qualities, sizes and varieties of supplies consistent with the successful operation of the city. 
(7)  Prepare written specifications for supplies, equipment and services as required. Specifications shall be developed with information available through governmental and private sources and in cooperation with city departments. 
(8)  Prescribe and maintain such forms as necessary for the operation of the office of purchasing agent. 
(9)  Maintain such files as are necessary to the operation of the office of purchasing agent in an organized manner. 
(10)  Obtain all federal and state tax exemptions to which the city is entitled. 
(11)  Investigate and report any possibilities of collusion. 
(12)  Join with other governmental agencies in cooperative purchasing when it is for the best interest of the city. 
(13)  Keep abreast of current developments in the field of purchasing. 
(14)  Advise and assist in formulation of policies concerning purchasing. 
(15)  Be responsible for the disposal of city property declared surplus by the mayor and council. No city employee shall dispose of city property by trade in or otherwise without first consulting with the purchasing agent. Departments having property that is no longer needed should submit a description of such to purchasing. 
(b)  The purchasing agent shall serve at the pleasure of the city manager. 
(Res. No. 98-01, exh. A, § III, 2-9-1998; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 2, 4-9-2018) 
Sec. 2-55. - Functions of the departments. 
(a)  Departments should plan their work so that rush orders and emergencies will be held to a minimum. Requests should be forwarded to the office of purchasing agent far enough in advance to allow sufficient time for delivery. 
(b)  Departments should assist the office of purchasing agent by suggesting the names of vendors that have access to particular items being requested, especially items of a technical nature. However, the office of purchasing agent is in no way confined to the vendors suggested. The office of purchasing agent maintains a list of vendors and any responsible firm may be added to that list upon application by telephone or mail. 
(c)  The city is not obligated to purchase equipment or accessories that are delivered for use on a trial basis. 
(d)  No department has the authority to order directly from a vendor or negotiate purchases in excess of $500.00. 
(e)  No city employee shall purchase supplies, material or equipment of any kind for personal use. 
(f)  Department heads will be called upon to assist in writing specifications for bids. Specifications should not be written which are considered "closed" (written around one specific brand). Brand names, model numbers, etc., may be submitted as a guideline for bid and purchase specifications. Bids for equivalent substitute goods and services will be solicited. 
(Res. No. 98-01, exh. A, § IV, 2-9-1998) 
Sec. 2-56. - Purchasing principles. 
(a)  Generally. The following principles are to apply to the procurement of materials, services and supplies: 
(1)  Materials, services and supplies are to be purchased only when moneys for their cost have been appropriated in the annual budget for the city. 
(2)  Materials, supplies and equipment should be purchased through the state department of administrative services (DOAS) or under state contract when available. 
(3)  Materials, services and supplies not available through DOAS or under state contract are to be purchased according to the procedures in section 2-55. 
(4)  All other considerations being equal, bids shall be awarded on price, service and delivery. Bid items must meet specifications in all cases to qualify. The city has the right to accept or reject all bids. 
(5)  Whenever possible, long-term contracts or blanket purchase agreements should be obtained for supplying commodities such as gasoline or other items for which monthly or periodic requirements can be forecast. The office of purchasing agent shall make monthly checks to ensure that the party under contract is not escalating his delivery price beyond current market. 
(6)  Low bid quotation submitted in compliance with the specifications should be accepted unless rejected by a change in the requirements of the city or for other valid stated reasons and approved by mayor and council. Whenever this occurs the reason should be filed with bids. 
(7)  Request for quotation as well as sealed bids should have a set time, date and location given by the office of purchasing agent when tabulation of bids will be made and this shall be done at the time and date specified. 
(8)  Emergency purchases are the result of breakdown in equipment or other occurrences for which it is impossible to plan in advance. If the occasion arises during the hours of normal operation contact the purchasing agent and he may make the purchase or authorize the department head to do so. If an emergency arises after hours the department head will make the purchase and contact the purchasing agent the next working day and immediately send a memorandum explaining the emergency. 
(9)  Emergency purchases should apply to guidelines of section 2-55. 
(b)  Exceptions. These items are to be handled directly by the finance department: 
(1)  Travel expense reimbursement. 
(2)  Conference or schooling enrollment fees. 
(3)  Dues and memberships. 
(4)  Personal reimbursement of any nature. 
(5)  Petty cash. 
(Res. No. 98-01, exh. A, § V, 2-9-1998) 
Sec. 2-57. - Purchasing procedures. 
(a)  Authorized means of purchase. Purchases may be made either from state contracts administered by the state department of administrative services or through direct negotiation. 
(b)  Purchase methods. The purchasing procedures to be followed by the city are based on the dollar amount of the purchase and are as follows. These procedures apply on a per-item basis and purchases will not be divided or separated to avoid obtaining proper approval for purchasing. 
(1)  For purchases up to $500.00 and budgeted: direct purchase by the department head. 
(2)  For purchases $500.00 up to $5,000.00 and budgeted: quotations taken by the department head and submitted to the purchasing agent. 
(3)  For purchases $5,000.00 up to $10,000.00 and budgeted: written quotations taken by the department head and submitted to the purchasing agent. The purchasing agent and the department head make a recommendation to the city manager, who makes the decision on the vendor. The results of any written quotations and award are to be recorded and filed. 
(4)  For purchases above $10,000.00 and budgeted: requires solicitation of advertised formal sealed bids by the office of the purchasing agent. The purchasing agent and the department head make recommendation to the mayor and council. The mayor and council award the contract for purchase. The results of bids and award are to be recorded and filed. 
(5)  For budgeted vehicles: direct purchase from state contract, by department heads with purchasing agent and city manager approval. 
(6)  For non-budgeted items: 
a.  Five hundred dollars or less. Purchase by purchasing agent or department head (with purchasing agent approval). 
b.  Greater than $500.00. Budget amendment required. 
(c)  Purchase orders. All purchases and requests for purchase shall be memorialized and consummated through the use of purchase orders. 
(1)  Purchase orders shall be sequentially numbered and issued and accounted for by the purchasing agent. 
(2)  The purchase order is the vendor's authorization to invoice and ship the material specified. It is also designed to expedite and control buying for the city. 
(3)  Routing of the purchase order. The purchase order set contains the original and two copies. 
a.  White copy or original copy (marked vendor) is mailed or given directly to the vendor. 
b.  Pink copy (file) is retained in the office of purchasing agent to be encumbered until all items listed are received. The invoice is attached to the purchase order to be entered through accounts payable for payment. In case of back-ordered items a copy of the purchase order shall be made as needed after each invoice has been attached until all items are received. 
c.  Yellow copy (departmental) is for the ordering department for their records. 
It is imperative that the receiving department submits to the purchasing office a signed document that goods or services have been received; otherwise no payment will be made to the vendor. A signed document may be a packing slip or delivery ticket sent by the vendor or, if none is sent, the receiving department may simply list goods or services received or make a copy of the purchase order and note that all goods have been received. In all cases documents must be signed by the person receiving goods or services and the department head. In case of damaged goods, unsatisfactory service or the item was not what was ordered, the receiving department must notify the office of the purchasing agent immediately. 
(d)  Bond and insurance requirements. 
(1)  Public road projects contracts over $5,000.00 require performance bond and payment bond as well as public liability and property damage insurance bonds or policies, and bonds to maintain in good condition; such completed construction for a period of not less than five years, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 32-4-119. 
(2)  Public works contracts in excess of $40,000.00 require a bid bond, performance bond, and payment bond in accordance with O.C.G.A. §§ 13-10-1 and 13-10-2. 
(3)  Any contractor entering into contract for services with the city must carry worker's compensation insurance at the minimum statutory limit, unless exempt under O.C.G.A. § 34-9-1 et seq. 
(4)  Licensed professionals contracting with the city for services in an amount of $40,000.00 or greater must provide professional liability coverage of $1,000,000.00. 
(Res. No. 98-01, exh. A, § VI, 2-9-1998; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 2, 4-9-2018) 
Secs. 2-58—2-87. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Purchases Requiring Bids 

Sec. 2-88. - Competitive bids. 
Subject to the provisions of section 2-57 of this Code, all purchases of supplies, equipment, goods and services shall be by competitive bids wherever possible. However, if there is only one supplier of the product or service needed, the product or service may be obtained by. If professional services are sought, such services shall not be subject to competitive bidding requirements. 
(Code 1994, § 2-42; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 3, 4-9-2018) 
Sec. 2-89. - Purchases by city clerk. 
The city clerk may make purchases of up to $500.00 without approval by the mayor and council if there has been an appropriation for that purpose. 
(Code 1994, § 2-43) 
Sec. 2-90. - Notice inviting bids. 
(a)  A notice containing general specifications should be mailed to all known suppliers inviting bids pursuant to this subdivision. The mailing should take place at least ten days prior to the last day set for the receipt of bids. 
(b)  A similar notice should be published in the official legal organ of the county twice, the last publication being at least four days prior to the last day set for the receipt of bids. 
(c)  All notices required by this section should include a general description of the goods, equipment, supply or service to be purchased; state where bid blanks and specifications may be obtained; and clearly state the date, time and place when bids will be opened. 
(Code 1972, § 12-3; Code 1994, § 2-44) 
Sec. 2-91. - Bid deposits. 
When deemed prudent, the purchasing agent may require bid deposits pursuant to this subdivision. When bid deposits are required, the notice inviting bids shall so state. The city shall return the deposits of the unsuccessful bidders and release the surety, if any. A successful bidder who fails to enter into a contract within ten days of being awarded the bid shall forfeit his deposit and surety, if required to perform. 
(Code 1972, § 12-4; Code 1994, § 2-45; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 3, 4-9-2018) 
Sec. 2-92. - Bid openings. 
Bids for purchases made under this subdivision shall be submitted sealed to the city clerk, and the envelope containing the bid shall clearly identify the contents as a bid. All bids shall be opened at the date, time and place specified in the notice and no other. Openings shall be open to the public. A tabulation of all bids received shall be posted in the city hall for public inspection and a copy furnished to each member of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1972, § 12-5; Code 1994, § 2-46) 
Sec. 2-93. - Awarding of contracts. 
Under this subdivision, only the mayor and council shall have the power to award contracts based on bids. When the public interest is best served, all bids may be rejected. Tie bids shall be decided by the vote of the mayor and council. The mayor and council shall award a contract to the lowest responsible bidder. In determining the lowest responsible bidder, the mayor and council, in addition to price, shall consider the following: 
(1)  The character, reputation, judgment, experience, efficiency, ability, capacity and skill of the bidder; 
(2)  The time involved in performance; 
(3)  Conditions attached to the bid; 
(4)  Prior experience in dealing with the bidder; 
(5)  The financial stability of the bidder; 
(6)  The bidder's ability to provide maintenance when needed; and 
(7)  The location of the bidder's business. 
(Code 1972, § 12-6; Code 1994, § 2-47) 
Sec. 2-94. - Conflict of interest. 
(a)  No purchase shall be made from a member of the mayor and council or from any city employee. No bid by any such member or employee shall be considered. No purchase shall be made from any firm, partnership or corporation in which any member of the mayor and council or any city employee has any financial interest. No bid from such firm, partnership or corporation shall be considered. 
(b)  Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, employees may submit sealed competitive bids to the city for purchases by the city. 
(Code 1994, § 2-48; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 3, 4-9-2018) 
Secs. 2-95—2-116. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DISPOSITION OF CITY PROPERTY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Sale of municipal property, O.C.G.A. § 36-37-6. 

Sec. 2-117. - Sale of city property. 
When the mayor and council shall determine that it is in the best interest of the city to sell or otherwise dispose of any property of the city, the mayor and council shall declare such fact. If the value of the property is less than $500.00, it shall be sold or disposed of as the mayor and council direct. If its estimated value is $500.00 or more, the same procedure shall be followed as is outlined for purchases of similar value in division 2 of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 12-12; Code 1994, § 2-76) 
Sec. 2-118. - Conflict of interest. 
No city property shall be sold, traded or given away to any member of the mayor and council or any city employee; provided that, where sealed bids are solicited for the disposal of surplus city property, city employees may submit sealed bids which will be considered with all other bids and such surplus property may then be sold to the highest bidder, regardless of whether such person is a city employee. 
(Code 1994, § 2-77) 
Secs. 2-119—2-149. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MAYOR AND COUNCIL 

Sec. 2-150. - Official governing body; meetings. 
(a)  The official governing body of the city shall be composed of the mayor and four council members, as set forth in the Charter. 
(b)  The mayor and council shall hold regular meetings in the city hall on the second Monday of each month commencing at 7:00 p.m. 
(c)  Special meetings of the mayor and council may be called by the mayor upon his own motion and shall be called by the mayor upon the request of any two members of the council. At least 12 hours' written notice shall be personally given each member of the mayor and council when a special meeting is contemplated, except that no such notice shall be necessary if all members of the mayor and council are present. Public notice of special meetings shall be given as required by law. 
(Code 1972, § 2-1; Code 1994, § 2-101; Ord. of 9-25-1975, § 2-1; Ord. No. 98-05, § 1, 12-14-1998) 
Sec. 2-151. - Mayor pro tem. 
At the first regular meeting in January of each year, the four members of the city council shall select one of their number to serve as mayor pro tem. Once elected the mayor pro tem shall continue to serve until his successor is elected. The mayor pro tem shall in every instance be clothed with the power and the authority of the mayor in the disability or absence of the mayor. Every duty and obligation imposed by this Code or any ordinance of the city on the mayor shall, in the disability or absence of the mayor, be imposed on the mayor pro tem. 
(Code 1972, § 2-3; Code 1994, § 2-102) 
Sec. 2-152. - Time and date of regular meetings. 
At any regular meeting of the mayor and council, the time or date of the next regular meeting may be changed by action of the mayor and council when it is determined with a reasonable degree of certainty that a quorum will not be present at the next meeting. Any regular meeting that falls on a legal holiday shall be held at 7:00 p.m. on the first workday following the holiday. However, no regular meeting shall be held on any day other than that day set forth in section 2-150(a), unless public notice has been given of the change in such meeting date or time in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
(Code 1972, § 2-1; Code 1994, § 2-103; Ord. No. 98-05, § 2, 12-14-1998) 
Sec. 2-153. - Officer presiding at meetings; rules of order. 
(a)  The mayor or, in his absence, the mayor pro tem or, in the absence of both the mayor and mayor pro tem, any member of the council who may be designated by the members present, a quorum being present, shall preside at all meetings of the mayor and council. 
(b)  The presiding officer shall enforce Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, relating to parliamentary procedure during all meetings of the mayor and council. However, if Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, conflict with this Code, this Code shall prevail. 
(Code 1972, § 2-2; Code 1994, § 2-104) 
Sec. 2-154. - Agenda. 
The mayor, after receiving input from the city manager and the council, and with the assistance of the city clerk, shall be responsible for preparing an agenda for all regular meetings of the mayor and council. A copy of the agenda shall be furnished to each member of the mayor and council at least 24 hours prior to the meeting. Matters may be added to the agenda at any council meeting upon the affirmative vote of three council members, subject to the requirements of the Georgia Open Meetings Act. 
(Code 1972, § 2-4; Code 1994, § 2-105; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 4, 4-9-2018) 
Sec. 2-155. - Minutes of meetings. 
The city clerk shall be responsible for taking minutes of all meetings of the mayor and council. The city clerk shall note the names of those present and shall enter on the minutes at the request of any member the reasons for his vote or action in any matter. Minutes shall be taken in accordance with section 2-210(1) setting forth the duties of the city clerk. 
(Code 1972, § 2-5; Code 1994, § 2-106) 
Sec. 2-156. - Conflict of interest. 
It shall be unlawful for any member of the mayor and council to vote upon any question in which he is personally interested. 
(Code 1994, § 2-107) 
Sec. 2-157. - Salaries. 
The compensation paid to the mayor shall be $14,000.00 per year and to each councilmember shall be $8,400.00 per year. 
(Ord. No. 97-02, § 1, 8-11-1997; Ord. No. 07-06, § 1, 6-28-2007; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 4, 4-9-2018) 
Secs. 2-158—2-182. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-183. - Performance bonds. 
The mayor and council shall have the authority to set the amount of surety and performance bonds for officers and employees from time to time as is in the best interests of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 2-19; Code 1994, § 2-127) 
Sec. 2-184. - Official holidays. 
(a)  The city shall observe the following holidays: 
(1)  New Year's Day. 
(2)  Memorial Day. 
(3)  Independence Day. 
(4)  Labor Day. 
(5)  Thanksgiving Day and the day after. 
(6)  Christmas Day. 
(7)  Employee's birthday. 
(b)  Any employee may be required to work on a holiday when the best interests of the city will be served. Any employee required to work on an official holiday shall be, as soon as practicable thereafter, given a like amount of time off from work. 
(Code 1972, § 2-18; Code 1994, § 2-128) 
Sec. 2-185. - Social security. 
(a)  It is declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend, under the agreement entered into by the state and the federal Social Security Administration, to the employees and officials of the city and its instrumentalities not excluded by law or by this section, the benefits of the system of old-age and survivor's insurance as authorized by the federal Social Security Act, the state enabling act and amendments thereto. In pursuance of this policy and for that purpose, the city shall take such action as may be required by the applicable state or federal laws. 
(b)  The mayor or other chief executive is authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments with the employees' retirement system of the state for coverage of city employees and officials as provided in subsection (a) of this section, not including any employees that are in positions covered by a public retirement system, in the manner provided by such law. 
(c)  Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees and officials for the purpose provided in subsection (a) of this section are authorized in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws and shall be paid over to the state agency. 
(d)  There shall be appropriated from general funds such amounts at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws for employers' contributions, administrative expenses and a guaranty fund to ensure that the state will not incur any debt or loss as a result of the agreement referred to in subsection (b) of this section. Such funds shall be paid over to the employees' retirement system of the state in accordance with the requirements established by such system. 
(e)  The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws. 
(f)  There is excluded from this section any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position or any employee or official not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws. 
(Code 1972, § 2-21; Code 1994, § 2-129) 
State Law reference— Social security coverage for employees of political subdivisions of the state, O.C.G.A. § 47-18-1 et seq. 
Secs. 2-186—2-208. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY CLERK 

Sec. 2-209. - Appointment; compensation; hours. 
The mayor and council shall appoint a city clerk who shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor and council and whose compensation and hours are fixed by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1972, § 2-6; Code 1994, § 2-141) 
Sec. 2-210. - Duties. 
The city clerk shall have the following duties: 
(1)  Keep a minutes book in which shall be recorded accurately, legibly and in detail the proceedings of all meetings of the mayor and council, taking care to set forth therein all motions, resolutions and ordinances voted on; every report of every committee; every contract made; all funds expended; each act of the mayor and council; and such other information as may be pertinent and proper in keeping a permanent record of the city. 
(2)  Be the custodian of all city records and make such records available for inspection and examination by any citizen during working hours. 
(3)  Receive, protect and deposit all funds paid to or received by the city from any source, keeping an accurate record of such. 
(4)  See that all debts of the city are timely paid, taking care to see that the city receives the benefit of any discounts offered. 
(5)  Receive correspondence, petitions, claims and requests directed to the city and direct the attention of the mayor and council to such as soon as possible. 
(6)  Issue, in the name of the city, permits, certificates, warrants, summons, receipts, executions and processes when directed to do so by this Code or by the mayor and council. 
(7)  Do those acts required by chapter 36, article II, pertaining to ad valorem taxation. 
(8)  Attest to all ordinances, resolutions and documents of the city. 
(9)  Keep, file and preserve all papers in connection with all purchases by the city of goods, supplies and services. 
(10)  Do such other acts and perform such other services as may be directed by the mayor and council or required elsewhere in this Code. 
(Code 1972, § 2-6(A)—(J); Code 1994, § 2-142) 
Secs. 2-211—2-228. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER 

Sec. 2-229. - Appointment. 
The city manager shall appoint or contract for a code enforcement officer who shall serve under the direct supervision of the city manager or designee. 
(Code 1972, § 2-7; Code 1994, § 2-156; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 5, 4-9-2018) 
Sec. 2-230. - Duties. 
Duties of the code enforcement officer shall be as follows: 
(1)  Enforce the technical codes adopted by the city; 
(2)  Enforce chapter 42, pertaining to zoning; 
(3)  See to the lawful issuance of building, construction and occupancy permits; and 
(4)  Perform such other services and do such other acts as may be directed by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1972, § 2-7; Code 1994, § 2-157) 
Secs. 2-231—2-253. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CITY ATTORNEY 

Sec. 2-254. - Appointment; qualifications; retainer. 
(a)  The city attorney shall be appointed by the mayor and council and shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor and council. 
(b)  He shall be at least 25 years of age and shall have had at least three years of legal practice in the state. 
(c)  His retainer fee shall be fixed by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1972, § 2-10; Code 1994, § 2-171) 
Sec. 2-255. - Duties. 
Duties of the city attorney shall be to: 
(1)  Prepare all ordinances and resolutions requested by the mayor and council; 
(2)  Review all contracts prior to their execution by the city; 
(3)  Represent the city in all threatened or pending litigation; and 
(4)  Perform such other duties and acts as directed by the mayor and council or as prescribed by this Code. 
(Code 1972, § 2-10; Code 1994, § 2-172) 
Secs. 2-256—2-273. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS, COMMITTEES, AND AUTHORITIES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-274—2-295. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DOWNTOWN DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY 

Sec. 2-296. - Statement of findings. 
It has been determined by the mayor and council that: 
(1)  There exists an urgent need to provide incentives for the investment of funds for the creation of a central business district of the city. 
(2)  Adequate financing for the creation of a central business district cannot be provided through the ordinary operation of private enterprise and a public agency as herein contemplated in such an undertaking would not be competitive with private enterprise. 
(3)  The Downtown Development Authorities Law (Georgia Laws 1981, p. 1744 et seq., codified as chapter 42 of title 36 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, hereinafter referred to as the "Act") which was enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, creates for every municipal body in the state a public corporate and politic to be known as the downtown develop authority of such municipal corporation, which shall consist of a board of seven directors to be appointed by the governing body of such municipal corporation. 
(4)  The mayor and council have determined that there is a need for a downtown development authority to function in the city to aid in the financing of projects for the development of a central business district of the city which will promote for the public good and general welfare trade, commerce, industry and employment opportunities within the city and the state. 
(5)  The mayor and council, after a thorough study and investigation, have determined that it is desirable and necessary that a downtown development authority be activated immediately to function in the city with all the powers granted to such authorities under said Act to issue revenue bonds, notes and other obligations for the purpose of providing funds to finance the cost of vitalization and development of a central business district of the city, all as more fully set forth in said Act. 
(Ord. No. 2013-02, § 2, 4-8-2013) 
Sec. 2-297. - Declaration of need. 
There is a determined and declared to be a pressing and existing need for a downtown development authority to function in the city in accordance with the terms and provisions of the Downtown Development Authorities Law for the purpose of providing a means of financing of projects for the vitalization and development of a central business district of the city, thereby promoting the public good and general welfare of the residents of the city and the state. 
(Ord. No. 2013-02, § 3, 4-8-2013) 
Sec. 2-298. - Activation of authority. 
There is activated the public body corporate and politic to be known as the Downtown Development Authority of Lake City (hereinafter referred to as the "authority"), which authority was created pursuant to the Downtown Development Authorities Law, Georgia Laws 1981, p. 1744 et seq. A true and correct copy of the Act shall be attached to the ordinance from which this division is derived and by this reference thereto same is incorporated herein and made a part of this division. 
(Ord. No. 2013-02, § 4, 4-8-2013) 
Sec. 2-299. - District designated. 
The central business district of the city is designated as the area which is geographically constituted as shown on Exhibit A, which is attached to the ordinance from which this division is derived, and available for public inspection in the office of the city clerk, and expressly incorporated herein and made a part of this division. 
(Ord. No. 2013-02, § 5, 4-8-2013) 
Sec. 2-300. - Appointment of members. 
The members of the board of directors of the downtown development authority shall be appointed as provided by state law, and shall serve a four-year term; provided that if one director is a member of the city council, he shall only serve as a director while a member of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2013-02, § 6, 4-8-2013) 
Sec. 2-301. - Term of members. 
The persons named as directors of the downtown development authority in section 2-300 shall serve in such capacity for the number of years set forth opposite their respective names, and if, at the end of any term of office of any director, a successor thereto shall not have been elected as hereinafter provided, then the director whose term of office shall have expired shall continue to hold office until his successor is elected, except as otherwise provided for in this section. No person shall receive any compensation for serving as director, but a director may be reimbursed for his actual expenses incurred in the performance of his duties. 
(Ord. No. 2013-02, § 7, 4-8-2013) 
Sec. 2-302. - Residency requirement of directors. 
In the event a director of the downtown development authority at any time ceases to be a taxpayer residing in the city, his eligibility to serve as a director shall cease and his appointment as a director shall end. 
(Ord. No. 2013-02, § 8, 4-8-2013) 
Sec. 2-303. - Organization; powers; duties. 
The board of directors of the downtown development authority hereinbefore elected shall organize itself, carry out its duties and responsibilities, and exercise its powers and prerogatives in accordance with the terms and provisions of the Act as it now exists and as same may hereafter be amended or modified. 
(Ord. No. 2013-02, § 9, 4-8-2013) 
Secs. 2-304—2-324. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ELECTIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Georgia Election Code, O.C.G.A. § 21-2-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-325. - Law governing elections. 
All elections in the city shall be conducted in every respect as set forth in the Charter, the Georgia Election Code (O.C.G.A. § 21-2-1 et seq.), and this article. 
(Code 1972, § 6-1; Code 1994, § 30-1) 
Sec. 2-326. - Election officials. 
The following offices are created in connection with the conduct of elections for the city: 
(1)  Superintendent. The mayor and council shall appoint a municipal election superintendent who shall receive such compensation as provided by the mayor and council. The superintendent shall exercise those powers and duties as set forth under state law. 
(2)  Poll officers. 
a.  Chief manager. A chief manager shall be appointed by the mayor and council for each election. The chief manager shall receive such compensation as provided by the mayor and council and shall exercise those powers and duties as set forth under state law. 
b.  Assistant managers. Two assistant managers shall be appointed by the mayor and council for each election. The assistant managers shall receive such compensation as provided by the mayor and council and shall exercise those powers and duties as set forth under state law. 
c.  Clerks. Prior to the opening of the polls of each election, the mayor and council shall appoint a sufficient number of clerks to serve at such election. The clerks shall receive such compensation as provided by the mayor and council and shall exercise those powers and duties as set forth under state law. 
(Code 1972, § 6-3; Code 1994, § 30-2) 
Sec. 2-327. - Registrar. 
The election registrar shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor and council and until his successor is appointed and qualified, except for resignation or removal as provided in this section. The mayor and council shall have the right to remove one or more of such registrars at any time for cause after notice and hearing. Any registrar shall have the right to resign at any time by submitting a resignation to the mayor and council. If any such removal or resignation of a registrar occurs, his duties and authority as such shall terminate instanter. For the removal, death or resignation of a registrar, the mayor and council shall appoint a successor who shall serve the unexpired term if such term is specified. Each such appointment or change in designation shall be entered on the minutes of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1972, § 6-7; Code 1994, § 30-3) 
Sec. 2-328. - Expenses. 
The election superintendent is authorized to incur expenses in the preparation and conduct of an election, including the cost of purchasing identification badges for poll officers, the printing of ballots and voters certificates and the purchasing of all other supplies necessary for the conduct of an election. The superintendent is further authorized to incur all necessary expenses to provide voting booths for the proper conduct of all elections. 
(Code 1972, § 6-4; Code 1994, § 30-4) 
Sec. 2-329. - Election district and polling place. 
The entire area within the corporate limits shall constitute an election district. Those persons qualified to vote and living within the city shall vote at the city hall. The election superintendent shall cause the polling place to be provided with sufficient light and heat. 
(Code 1972, § 6-5; Code 1994, § 30-5) 
Sec. 2-330. - Qualifying period and fees. 
(a)  The qualifying period for a candidate seeking election in a special or general election shall be three days. The qualifying period shall otherwise be set as provided in O.C.G.A. § 21-2-132. 
(b)  The mayor and council shall publish a qualifying fee which shall be three percent of the annual salary of the office and which shall be paid by candidates seeking election in a special or general election. The fee will be paid to the municipal elections superintendent at the time the candidate files his notice of candidacy. 
(Code 1972, § 6-9; Code 1994, § 30-7; Ord. No. 2015-7, § 1, 12-14-2015) 
Sec. 2-331. - Nonpartisan elections. 
All elections held for the purpose of filling municipal offices in the city shall be nonpartisan, and no political party shall conduct primaries for the purpose of nominating candidates for such municipal elections. 
(Code 1972, § 6-10; Code 1994, § 30-8) 
Sec. 2-332. - Vote required for election. 
A candidate for municipal office may be elected in a general or special election by receiving a plurality of the votes cast to fill such office. The candidate for mayor who receives the most votes shall be declared elected, and the candidates for council who receive the most votes shall be declared elected. If a tie vote occurs, a runoff shall be held between the candidates receiving such tie vote. 
(Code 1972, § 6-12; Code 1994, § 30-9) 
Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.; authority to adopt rules and regulations relating to manufacture, sale and distribution of distilled spirits, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-49. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
(a)  The definitions set forth in O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2 ("Alcoholic Beverages—General Provisions—Definitions"), shall be effective as definitions of the words, terms and phrases used in this chapter. All words, terms and phrases used in this chapter, other than those specifically defined elsewhere in this chapter, shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2, and shall have the same scope and effect that the same words, terms and phrases have where used in O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2. 
(b)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Applicant means an individual applying for any license authorized by this chapter. 
Application means a form supplied by the city for the purpose of applying for any license authorized by this chapter. 
Church means a permanent building where persons regularly assemble for religious worship. 
Family includes any person related to the holder of a license within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity as computed according to the civil law. 
Hotel means every building or other structure kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public to be a place where food is actually served and consumed and sleeping accommodations are offered for adequate pay to travelers and guests, whether transient, permanent or residential. To meet the definition of "hotel" under this chapter, the facility must have 50 or more rooms used for sleeping accommodations of such guests and one or more public dining rooms, with an adequate and sanitary kitchen and a seating capacity of at least 60 persons, where meals are regularly served to such guests. All sleeping accommodations and dining rooms must be conducted in the same building or in separate buildings or structures used in connection therewith that are on the same premises and are a part of the hotel operation. Motels meeting the qualifications set out in this definition for hotels shall be classified in the same category as hotels. Hotels shall have the privilege of granting franchises for the operation of a lounge or restaurant in their premises, and the holder of such franchise shall be eligible for a license under the "hotel" classification. 
Interest in license exists if the person involved is the outright holder of the license, a co-holder of the license, a partner in a partnership which holds all or any part of a license, a stockholder in any corporation organized for pecuniary gain which holds all or any part of a license, an owner, lessee, sublessee or stockholder in any corporation organized for pecuniary gain owning or leasing any real estate which is occupied by an alcoholic beverage establishment or shares in any of the income or corpus of any trust fund or estate having any interest in an alcoholic beverage establishment. Provided, however, a stockholder shall not be deemed to have an interest in an alcoholic beverage establishment where such stockholder owns stock in a motel or hotel having 200 or more rooms with an alcoholic beverage establishment located on the premises of such motel or hotel and owned by such motel or hotel. Provided, further, that a stockholder holding no more than five percent stock in a publicly held corporation shall not be considered to hold an interest in an alcoholic beverage license. 
License means authorization granted by the city to operate as a malt and vinous package beverage dealer or retail alcohol consumption dealer, retail dealer or wholesale dealer. 
Licensee means a person holding a license. 
Lounge means a separate room connected with, a part of, and adjacent to, a restaurant or a room located in hotels as defined herein, with all booths, stools and tables being open and unobstructed to the view of any other customers in such lounge, or the manager thereof. All lounges shall be air conditioned and have a seating capacity of at least 60 persons. A lounge located in other than a hotel, which is operated on a different floor than a restaurant in the premises, or in a separate building, or is not connected to or adjacent to a restaurant shall be considered a separate establishment and shall pay an additional license fee therefor. 
Metropolitan Atlanta area includes only the counties of Fulton, Clayton, Henry, Fayette, Walton, Douglas, Cobb, Paulding, Newton, Cherokee, Gwinnett, Forsyth, DeKalb, Rockdale, Bartow, Carroll and Pickens. 
Motel. See Hotel. 
Private club means a corporation or association organized and existing under the laws of the state, actively in operation within the city at least eight years prior to the application for a license hereunder, having at least 200 members regularly paying dues, for at least five years prior to application for license, organized and operated exclusively for pleasure, recreation and other nonprofitable purposes, no part of the net earnings of which inures to the benefit of any shareholder or member, and owning, hiring or leasing a building or space therein for the reasonable use of its members with suitable kitchen and dining room space and equipment and maintaining and using a sufficient number of servants and employees for cooking, preparing and serving meals for its members and guests; provided that no member or officer, agent or employee of the club is paid, or directly or indirectly receives, in the form of salary or other compensation, any profits from the sale of distilled spirits, wines, champagnes or malt beverages beyond the amount of such salary as may be fixed by its members at an annual meeting, or by its governing body, out of the general revenue of the club. For the purpose of this definition, tips which are added to the bills under club regulations shall not be considered as profits hereunder. A private club organized or operated primarily for the selling or serving of alcoholic beverages by the drink shall not be licensed under this chapter, nor permitted to sell or serve such beverages at all. The restrictions contained in section 4-43 shall not apply to private clubs. All distance requirements as set forth in section 4-43 shall apply. 
Private residence means a house, dwelling or structure wherein not less than one, nor more than two, families reside and shall not include a mobile home court, an apartment house having facilities for housing more than two families, nor a boardinghouse or roominghouse where there are five or more boarders or roomers. Any building occupied as a residence located within an area zoned for business shall not be construed as a private residence. 
Restaurant means any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place where meals are actually and regularly served, without sleeping accommodations, such place being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and a dining room seating capacity of at least 60 persons, having employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employees to prepare, cook and serve suitable food for its guests. At least two meals per day, each with a minimum serving time open to the public of two hours, shall be served at least six days a week, with the exception of weeks including holidays, vacations and periods of redecorating, and the serving of such meals shall be the principal business conducted, with the serving of distilled spirits to be consumed on the premises as only incidental thereto. As used in this definition, the term "seating capacity" shall mean that no more than 25 percent of such seating shall be at a common table or counter area or shall be other than individual tables or booths designed for seating of at least two individuals. As used in this definition, the term "principal business" shall mean that at least 51 percent of the receipts of such business shall come from the sale of food. To be included in the tabulation of receipts for the purpose of this calculation, are all receipts of all persons laboring on the premises, including the services of all independent contractors, performers, servers, entertainers, or other non-employee personnel not to include, however, persons who are called to the premises from other licensed businesses to perform services, repairs or construction on equipment or building premises. For purposes of this definition, the calculations of receipts for alcoholic beverages shall be made pursuant to the scheduling of pricing and the regulations contained therein as required by section 4-121. 
Retailer or retail dealer means any person who sells malt beverages or wine in unbroken packages at retail only to consumers for consumption at some location other than the licensed premises; retail sales are not for resale. 
Sales by the drink means any person who sells alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises at retail only to consumers and not for resale. 
Seating capacity means the amount of individual seating which is located at tables for the purpose of serving the dining public, but not including any seating located in a lounge, bar or other area designed primarily for the serving of alcoholic beverages. 
(Code 1994, § 6-1; Ord. No. 96-3, § 1, 8-12-1996; Ord. No. 96-04, § 1(6-1), 8-12-1996) 
Sec. 4-2. - Purpose of chapter. 
The ordinance from which this chapter is derived is enacted in accordance with a plan designed for the purposes, among others, of: 
(1)  Promoting the health and general welfare of the community; 
(2)  Establishing reasonable standards for the control of the licensing and sale of off-premises consumption package malt beverages and wine and on-premises consumption of alcoholic beverages; 
(3)  Protecting and preserving schools and churches; 
(4)  Giving affect to land use. 
(Code 1994, § 6-2; Ord. No. 96-3, § 1, 8-12-1996; Ord. No. 96-04, § 1(6-2), 8-12-1996) 
Sec. 4-3. - Drinking in public or public facilities.
