No alcoholic beverages shall be sold in a billiard room except in an establishment which also possesses a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises. Only alcoholic beverages sold under the license may be consumed or be kept on the premises and must remain within the building at all times. 
(Code 1994, § 10-33; Ord. No. 90-2, § 3(f), 10-8-1990) 
Sec. 6-27. - Presence of minors. 
It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years to play billiards in or for any other purpose to enter or remain on the premises of any billiard room in which alcoholic beverages are offered for sale. This section shall not apply to a person under 18 years of age who is accompanied by a parent or guardian or who possesses a written permit from a parent or guardian, which permit is witnessed by a notary public with seal. If the proprietor of a billiard room is of the opinion that any person desiring admission is under the age of 18 years, he shall require such person to produce photo identification establishing his age. 
(Code 1994, § 10-34; Ord. No. 90-2, § 3(g), 10-8-1990) 
Secs. 6-28—6-57. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES 

Sec. 6-58. - Required; application; issuance. 
(a)  Any person desiring to operate a billiard room shall obtain a license which, unless billiards is to be the sole business enterprise, shall be acquired in addition to all other licenses required by this Code, including but not limited to licenses to serve alcoholic beverages and other business licenses. Such person shall make application to the city clerk or designated representative and shall show the following: 
(1)  The applicant has never been convicted of a crime of moral turpitude; 
(2)  The applicant will certify that he is actively involved in the management of the business and that he will be responsible for violations that occur; and 
(3)  The applicant agrees to comply with all state laws and applicable sections of this Code and other local ordinances pertaining to the business. 
(b)  The application shall include a scale drawing of the premises, including interior walls and also any parking areas reserved for the licensed establishment. 
(c)  Upon the applicant meeting the requirements set forth in this section, a license shall be issued by the city for such fee as set forth in the city business license schedule. 
(Code 1994, § 10-46; Ord. No. 90-2, § 2, 10-8-1990) 
Sec. 6-59. - Alcoholic beverage sales. 
No license to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the billiard room premises shall be issued or remain in effect for any business holding a billiard room license, unless the establishment is licensed as a restaurant and derives at least 50 percent of its revenue from the sale of products or services other than alcoholic beverages. No package sales of alcoholic beverages shall be allowed for any business holding a billiard room license. 
(Code 1994, § 10-47) 
Sec. 6-60. - Suspension; revocation. 
(a)  In addition to the penalties prescribed by section 6-20, the city manager or designee, upon becoming aware of an alleged violation of this article or of any state law pertaining to alcoholic beverages or controlled substances on the licensed billiard room premises, may notify the license holder to appear for a hearing at such time and place as established by the city manager to answer to charges of the alleged violation and to show cause why his license should not be suspended or revoked. At least ten days' written notice shall be provided to a license holder of any hearing under this subsection. Such notice shall state the date and time for the hearing which shall be conducted by the city manager or designee. The decision of the city manager or designee may be appealed to the mayor and city council within ten days of the date of the decision issued in writing by the city manager or designee by delivering an appeal in writing to the city manager. The mayor and city council, upon receiving the appeal, shall hold a hearing within 30 days after the receipt of the appeal. The decision of the mayor and city council shall be final. An aggrieved party may appeal said decision to the Superior Court of Clayton County by petition for writ of certiorari in accordance with state law. 
(b)  Any violation of this article, chapter 4, pertaining to alcoholic beverages, other sections of this Code or city ordinances or state laws relating to billiard rooms, alcoholic beverages or controlled substances shall be considered as grounds for license suspension or revocation under this article. 
(Code 1994, § 10-48; Ord. No. 90-2, § 6, 10-8-1990; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 6, 4-9-2018) 
Secs. 6-61—6-78. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-79. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Arcade room means any establishment where more than three coin-operated amusement devices are maintained. 
Arcade room proprietor means any proprietor of an arcade room. The terms "proprietor" and "arcade room proprietor" shall be synonymous, unless specifically provided otherwise. 
Bona fide coin-operated amusement machine. 
(1)  The term "bona fide coin-operated amusement machine" means every machine of any kind or character used by the public to provide amusement or entertainment whose operation requires the payment of or the insertion of a coin, bill, other money, token, ticket, card, or similar object and the result of whose operation depends in whole or in part upon the skill of the player, whether or not it affords an award to a successful player pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(b) through (g), and which can be legally shipped interstate according to federal law. 
(2)  Examples of bona fide coin-operated amusement machines include, but are expressly not limited to, the following: 
a.  Pinball machines; 
b.  Console machines; 
c.  Video games; 
d.  Crane machines; 
e.  Claw machines; 
f.  Pusher machines; 
g.  Bowling machines; 
h.  Novelty arcade games; 
i.  Foosball or table soccer machines; 
j.  Miniature racetrack, football, or golf machines; 
k.  Target or shooting gallery machines; 
l.  Basketball machines; 
m.  Shuffleboard games; 
n.  Kiddie ride games; 
o.  Skeeball machines; 
p.  Air hockey machines; 
q.  Roll down machines; 
r.  Trivia machines; 
s.  Laser games; 
t.  Simulator games; 
u.  Virtual reality machines; 
v.  Maze games; 
w.  Racing games; 
x.  Coin-operated pool tables or coin-operated billiard tables as defined in of O.C.G.A. § 43-8-1(3); and 
y.  Any other similar amusement machine which can be legally operated in the state. 
(3)  The term "bona fide coin-operated amusement machine" also means machine of any kind or character used by the public to provide music whose operation requires the payment of or the insertion of a coin, bill, other money, token, ticket, card, or similar object such as jukeboxes or other similar types of music machines. 
(4)  The term "bona fide coin-operated amusement machine" does not include the following: 
a.  Coin-operated washing machines or dryers; 
b.  Vending machines which for payment of money dispense products or services; 
c.  Gas and electric meters; 
d.  Pay telephones; 
e.  Pay toilets; 
f.  Cigarette vending machines; 
g.  Coin-operated scales; 
h.  Coin-operated gumball machines; 
i.  Coin-operated parking meters; 
j.  Coin-operated television sets which provide cable or network programming; 
k.  Coin-operated massage beds; and 
l.  Machines which are not legally permitted to be operated in the state. 
Class A machine means a bona fide coin-operated amusement machine that is not a Class B machine, does not allow a successful player to carry over points won on one play to a subsequent play or plays, and: 
(1)  Provides no reward to a successful player; 
(2)  Rewards a successful player only with free replays or additional time to play; 
(3)  Rewards a successful player with noncash merchandise, prizes, toys, gift certificates, or novelties in compliance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(c) or (d)(1), and does not reward a successful player with any item prohibited as a reward in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(i) or any reward redeemable as an item prohibited as a reward in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(i); 
(4)  Rewards a successful player with points, tokens, tickets, or other evidence of winnings that may be exchanged only for items listed in subsection (3) of this definition; or 
(5)  Rewards a successful player with any combination of items listed in subsections (2), (3), and (4) of this definition. 
Class B machine means a bona fide coin-operated amusement machine that allows a successful player to accrue points on the machine and carry over points won on one play to a subsequent play or plays in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(d)(2) and: 
(1)  Rewards a successful player in compliance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(d)(1) and (2); and 
(2)  Does not reward a successful player with any item prohibited as a reward in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(i) or any reward redeemable as an item prohibited as a reward in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(i). 
Distributor means any person who sets up for operation by another and leases or rents for the purpose of operation by another any device to which this article applies, whether such leasing or renting is for a fixed charge or rental or on the basis of a division of the income derived from such device or otherwise. 
Proprietor means any person who, as the owner or lessee, has under his control any establishment, place or premises in or at which a coin-operated amusement device is placed or kept for use or play or is on exhibition for the purpose of use or play by the general public. 
(Code 1994, § 10-71) 
Sec. 6-80. - Inspections. 
The chief of police shall inspect or cause the inspection of any place or building in which any coin-operated amusement device is operated or set up for operation and shall inspect, investigate and test such devices as needed. 
(Code 1994, § 10-72) 
Sec. 6-81. - Attendant required. 
Under this article, it shall be unlawful for any proprietor to open his business to the public unless an attendant is present. The attendant shall be of sufficient mental and physical capacity as to be able to provide aid to patrons if needed or desired. The attendant shall not be less than 18 years of age. 
(Code 1994, § 10-73) 
Sec. 6-82. - Placement of devices. 
All coin-operated amusement devices shall at all times be kept and placed in plain view of and open and accessible to any person who may frequent or be in any place of business where such devices are kept or used. However, no machine shall be placed within five feet of any public entrance or exit, and no proprietor, except game room proprietors, may keep or maintain a machine between any public entrance or exit and any cash register. 
(Code 1994, § 10-74) 
Sec. 6-83. - Gambling devices. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed to authorize, permit or license any gambling device of any nature whatsoever. 
(Code 1994, § 10-75) 
Sec. 6-84. - Refunds and adjustments. 
Refunds and adjustments to all customers shall be the responsibility of the proprietor of the coin-operated amusement device in question. 
(Code 1994, § 10-76) 
Sec. 6-85. - Loitering. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Loitering means remaining idle in essentially one location and includes the concepts of spending time idly, loafing or walking about aimlessly and also includes the colloquial expression "hanging around." 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter within the immediate vicinity of any coin-operated amusement device or business premises to which this article pertains or for any person licensed to operate a game room to permit loitering on or in the immediate vicinity of any coin-operated amusement device or business premises to which this article pertains in such a manner as to: 
(1)  Create or cause to be created a danger of a breach of the peace. 
(2)  Create or cause to be created any disturbance or annoyance to the comfort and repose of any person. 
(3)  Obstruct the free passage of pedestrians or vehicles. 
(4)  Obstruct, molest or interfere with any person lawfully in any public place. 
(Code 1994, § 10-77) 
Sec. 6-86. - Minors. 
Under this article, proprietors shall not allow anyone under the age of 18 years to frequent or remain on their premises except during the following hours: 
(1)  During normal school terms: 
a.  Sunday through Thursday, 3:00 p.m. to 10:00 p.m. 
b.  Friday, 3:00 p.m. to 11:00 p.m. 
c.  Saturday, 9:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. 
(2)  During times when public schools are not in session: 
a.  Sunday through Thursday, 9:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. 
b.  Friday through Saturday, 9:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. 
(Code 1994, § 10-78) 
Sec. 6-87. - Attire of patrons. 
Under this article, all proprietors shall require shirts and shoes to be worn at all times by persons frequenting their premises. 
(Code 1994, § 10-79) 
Sec. 6-88. - Pool tables. 
Under this article, no proprietor shall maintain pool tables or bumper pool tables on the premises. 
(Code 1994, § 10-80) 
Sec. 6-89. - Alcoholic beverages. 
Under this article, no proprietor shall allow alcoholic beverages to be brought onto his premises by any person. 
(Code 1994, § 10-81) 
Secs. 6-90—6-106. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES 

Sec. 6-107. - Required. 
No person shall engage in the business of a distributor or proprietor of coin-operated amusement devices without first having obtained the proper license. 
(Code 1994, § 10-91) 
Sec. 6-108. - Application. 
(a)  Application for a license required by this division shall be filed in writing with the business license department, on a form to be provided by the city, and shall specify the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant and, if a firm, corporation, partnership or association, the principal officers thereof and their addresses. 
(2)  For a proprietor, the address of the premises where the licensed devices are to be operated, together with the character of the business carried on at such place. 
(3)  For a proprietor, the number of devices to be maintained on the premises. 
(4)  The name and address of the owner of the devices, if other than the proprietor. This information shall not be released to the general public without the consent of the licensee. 
(5)  Whether or not the person having the management of or supervision over the applicant's business has been convicted of a crime, misdemeanor or the violation of any city ordinance or section of this Code, and the nature of such offense and the punishment assessed therefor. 
(b)  The proper license fee shall accompany the application. 
(Code 1994, § 10-92) 
Sec. 6-109. - Distributor's fee. 
The fee for each distributor applying for a license required under this division shall be as provided in the city business license tax schedule. All distributors' license fees shall be payable annually in advance. No portion of the license fee shall be refunded to the licensee. 
(Code 1994, § 10-93) 
Sec. 6-110. - Proprietor's fee. 
The fee for each proprietor applying for a license required under this division shall be as provided in the city business license tax schedule. All proprietors' license fees shall be payable annually in advance. No portion of the license fee shall be refunded to the licensee. 
(Code 1994, § 10-94) 
Sec. 6-111. - Arcade room proprietor's fee. 
The fee for each arcade room proprietor applying for a license required under this division shall be as provided in the city business license tax schedule. All arcade room proprietors' license fees shall be payable annually in advance. No portion of the license fee shall be refunded to the licensee. 
(Code 1994, § 10-95) 
Sec. 6-112. - Qualifications of applicant. 
No license required under this division shall be issued to or renewed for any person who has or employs a person who has, within five years of issuance or renewal of the license, been convicted of or pled guilty or nolo contendere to any felony involving any federal or state offense or any federal or state misdemeanor involving a drug-related offense or an offense involving moral turpitude. The licensee will submit the identity of all owners and employees to the business license department on a continuing basis as changes occur. This information is to be forwarded to the police department for the purpose of allowing a complete check in order that these character qualifications be fulfilled prior to the issuance or renewal of any license issued under this division. 
(Code 1994, § 10-96) 
Sec. 6-113. - Posting; transferability; placing stickers on devices. 
(a)  The license issued under this division shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the establishment of the licensee. 
(b)  Such license shall be nonassignable and nontransferable and for a proprietor shall apply only to the premises for which such license is issued. 
(c)  In addition, each coin-operated amusement device shall have placed upon it by the licensee a sticker showing the license number of its distributor or proprietor. 
(Code 1994, § 10-97) 
Sec. 6-114. - Increasing number of devices. 
If a proprietor licensed under this division desires, after the expiration of any portion of any license year, to increase the number of coin-operated amusement devices to be used or played or exhibited for use or play in his establishment so that he then has four or more machines, he shall surrender his license to the business license department who shall issue a new arcade room proprietor license upon payment of the proper license fee with any applicable credit for the previously paid license fee. 
(Code 1994, § 10-98) 
Sec. 6-115. - Revocation. 
(a)  Any license issued under this division shall be subject to suspension or revocation. 
(b)  Violation of any provision of this article shall be sufficient grounds for revocation of a license issued pursuant to this division. 
(Code 1994, § 10-99) 
Secs. 6-116—6-143. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Giving massages in places used for lewdness, prostitution, assignation or masturbation for hire, O.C.G.A. § 16-6-17; governing authority has power to enact legislation to restrict operation of adult bookstores, explicit media outlets, and adult movie houses to areas zoned for commercial or industrial purposes, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-3; establishment, maintenance or use of building, structure or place for unlawful sexual purposes, O.C.G.A. § 41-3-1. 

Sec. 6-144. - Purpose. 
(a)  Based on city officials' review of information regarding establishments that exploit live human nudity and human sexuality for commercial profit, euphemistically referred to as "adult entertainment," and the experiences of other urban cities and counties, including, but not limited to, Austin, Texas; Manatee County, Florida; the State of Minnesota; Indianapolis, Indiana; Oklahoma City, Oklahoma; and Phoenix, Arizona, and as further described in City of Erie v. Pap's A.M., 529 U.S. 277, 120 S. Ct 1382 (2000), which experiences are relevant to the problems faced by the city, and based on the evidence and testimony of persons who have appeared before the mayor and council, the mayor and council take note of the well-known and self-evident conditions attendant to the commercial exploitation of live human nudity and human sexuality, which do not vary greatly among generally comparable communities within the country. 
(b)  The mayor and council expressly find that the negative effects of adult entertainment are not limited to adult entertainment that offers live or recorded performances with human nudity or the depiction of sexual acts. Other forms of adult entertainment also have a deleterious effect upon the quality of life in nearby neighborhoods and commercial districts and on urban life in general Such other forms of adult entertainment include, but are not limited to, adult bookstores, peep shows, adult theaters, adult gift or novelty shops, and lingerie modeling studios. 
(c)  Further, based on the investigation conducted by the city regarding lingerie modeling studios, it is the finding of the mayor and council that lingerie modeling studios are establishments that offer adult entertainment in the form of live human nudity in a private setting. Based on the evidence presented to the mayor and council, it is apparent that lingerie modeling studios, by providing adult entertainment in a private setting, lead to criminal behavior, including, but not limited to, masturbation for hire, prostitution, and sodomy. 
(d)  Furthermore, based on the investigation conducted by the city, it is apparent that lingerie modeling studios pose a more difficult challenge to the enforcement of regulations pertaining to adult entertainment business, in that the activity occurs within a private setting, as opposed to in an open area which is visible to all patrons of the establishment. The mayor and council have determined that lighting, visibility and access are measures that can reduce the risk of crime to patrons and others. 
(e)  Accordingly, the mayor and council find that it is in the best interest of the health, welfare, safety and morals of the community to limit and regulate adult entertainment within the corporate boundaries of the city, so as to limit the adverse impact on property values, other business uses, residential uses and public and semi-public uses; to ensure that adult entertainment uses and adult entertainment facilities do not impede development, redevelopment and neighborhood revitalization efforts; to restrict adult entertainment and adult uses in heavily-used public pedestrian areas; and to protect patrons of adult entertainment business from unreasonable risk of crime. 
(f)  After giving due consideration to the considerations stated in these findings and the current state of growth and development of the city, the mayor and council find that the area zoned M Manufacturing is so situated as to provide sufficient vehicular access to patrons and suppliers, while providing the desired containment from residential uses and pedestrian traffic, regarding adult entertainment facilities and adult entertainment businesses. 
(g)  This article is not intended as a de facto prohibition of legally protected forms of expression. This article is intended to represent a balancing of competing interests: reduced criminal activity and protection of neighborhoods and development through the regulation of adult entertainment establishments versus any legally protected rights of providers and patrons of adult entertainment. 
(h)  It is a matter of governmental interest and concern and in the interest of the public welfare to minimize the proliferation of criminal behavior and undesirable community conditions normally associated with establishments that commercially exploit human sexuality through adult entertainment to limit adult entertainment uses of property to certain prescribed areas of the city. To that end, the ordinance from which this article is derived is hereby adopted. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-100), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 6-145. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Adult entertainment means, by way of description and not by limitation, the commercial, for-profit offering or provision of any of the following or any combination thereof: 
(1)  When offered for sale, rental, viewing or use and the proceeds from such offering constitute more than ten percent of the gross income of the establishment, any motion picture not rated G, PG, PG-13 or R by the Motion Picture Association of America, or any good, material, device, instrument, writing, document, audio recording, photograph, or tangible thing of whatever kind or description, including data compilations from which information can be obtained or viewed through any machine, instrument, computer or other detection or interpretation device, the principal intended effect of which is to excite the sexual arousal, desire or gratification of the user or another person and, further, that is characterized or distinguished by an emphasis on specified sexual acts, activities, conduct, contact, relations or situations, or the exhibition, display or exposure of any specified human anatomical parts or areas; 
(2)  When offered as part of a commercial transaction, any service, whether or not it involves physical contact, performed by an employee or agent for a patron during which any specified human anatomical part or area of the employee or agent, is exposed, displayed or exhibited, or touched by either a patron or any employee; 
(3)  When offered as part of a commercial transaction, any activity, performance, exhibition, entertainment, show, demonstration, simulation or amusement the principal intended effect of which is to excite the sexual arousal, desire or gratification of any participant or any person viewing or intended to view such performance, exhibition, entertainment show, demonstration or amusement and, further, that is characterized or distinguished by an emphasis on specified sexual acts, activities, conduct, contact, relations or situations, or the exhibition, display or exposure of any specified human anatomical parts or areas; 
(4)  Random acts of patrons or employees done without the consent, authority, foreknowledge, encouragement, acquiescence or tolerance of the management of a commercial establishment that do not yield a direct financial benefit to the establishment shall not be construed as adult entertainment for the purposes of this article; 
(5)  Sale or rental of any device or paraphernalia that is designed principally for sexual activities, but not including contraceptive devices, so long as such sales or rentals account for more than ten percent of gross income for the establishment; or 
(6)  Sale or rental of any drug related object, as that term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-13-32, so long as such sales or rentals account for more than ten percent of gross income for the establishment. 
Adult entertainment business or business shall include, by way of description and not by way of limitation, any establishment, business, commercial enterprise or service that offers any form of adult entertainment, as defined herein, to the public on the premises of the business or elsewhere, in exchange for a fee, payment, tip, charge, compensation, or other value or consideration as part of a commercial transaction. 
Adult entertainment facility or facility means any building, structure or location within the corporate limits of the city where adult entertainment, as defined herein, is sponsored, allowed, encouraged, condoned, presented, sold or offered to the public or to patrons or members, and any establishment with a segment, room or section devoted to such activity. A facility meets this definition even if such activity occurs on only one occasion. Examples of adult entertainment facilities include, but are not limited to, adult bookstores, adult video stores, adult theaters, peep shows, adult gift or novelty shops and establishments where live nude entertainment is offered. 
Dressing room means an employee restroom or a room or area within an adult entertainment facility used by employees for the purpose of changing clothes. 
Employee or agent means, without regard to whether such person would be considered an employee, agent or independent contractor for other purposes, any person who derives income or compensation from, or offers or provides with the expectation of receiving income or compensation, any of the following: 
(1)  The conduct or operation of any adult entertainment business; 
(2)  The provision or offering of adult entertainment; 
(3)  Any commercial transaction involving adult entertainment, whether or not such transaction is completed; or 
(4)  Any commercial transaction incidental to an adult entertainment business and involving any intended interaction with any patron, whether or not such transaction is completed. 
Fixed stage means a raised-floor area or stage at least four feet high and designed exclusively for, and used only by performers. A table used for seating of and service to customers does not constitute a fixed stage and shall not be used for performance purposes. 
License means a current license to operate an adult entertainment business within the corporate limits of the city issued by the city clerk upon true, correct and complete information provided by the license applicant. 
Lingerie modeling studio means any commercial establishment which offers for sale lingerie, bathing suits, or other garments and offers modeling of such garments. 
Patron includes any person other than an employee, contractor, agent or supplier of an adult entertainment business who frequents, visits, attends, or is present at an adult entertainment facility, including any customer, client, invitee or licensee of any adult entertainment business, whether or not a commercial transaction is completed with such person. 
Place of assembly means a structure, portion of a structure, or area (either indoor or outdoor), including but not limited to movie theaters, concert halls, stadiums, amusement parks carnivals, churches, elementary, middle, high, secondary and post graduate schools, day care centers, private commercial schools, such as martial arts or dance studios, clubs, lodges and arenas, designed primarily for people to gather to observe or participate in a single event or series of single events, including but not limited to the presentation of a motion picture, a concert, an educational presentation, a sermon, an inspirational presentation, a rally, a lecture, dramatic, dance, musical, or other live performance, or a sporting event. 
Principal intended effect means the consequence reasonably to be anticipated, and may be inferred from the totality of the circumstances. 
Private performance means adult entertainment at an adult entertainment facility that takes place in or is viewed in a private room. 
Private room means any area within an adult entertainment facility access to which is restricted to less than all patrons, customers or clients at some or all times during business hours, or an area within an adult entertainment facility which is intentionally totally or partially screened or partitioned so as to restrict visibility of or access to the screened area to less than all patrons. 
Specified human anatomical parts or areas refers to the body of any employee or agent of an adult entertainment business, any person depicted in any recorded medium and to any patron, customer, invitee or licensee of any such business, and the following when uncovered or covered by less than fully opaque material: the areola of the female breast; the female genitalia, including the mons veneris, vulva, vagina, labia and clitoris; the male genitalia and pubic region, including the pubis, penis, scrotum and testicles; the anus, perineum and more than two inches of the cleft of the buttocks. 
Specified sexual acts, activities, conduct, contact, relations or situations shall include, by way of description and not by limitation, any of the following, performed, portrayed, exhibited, simulated, or depicted in the presence of a patron, within view of a patron, or with the anticipation of a patron or recorded for the purpose of thereafter being viewed, used, or observed by a patron: actual sexual intercourse; masturbation; manual, mechanical, digital, oral or penile stimulation of any specific human anatomical part or area; stimulation or penetration of any specific human anatomical part or area by any foreign object; exposure, exhibition or display of any specified human anatomical part or area; disrobing or stripping to expose any specified human anatomical part or area; and any other act the principal intended effect of which is to excite the sexual arousal, desire or gratification of any patron. 
Stimulation includes fondling, caressing, stroking, touching and any other form of physical contact the principal intended effect of which is to excite the prurient interest or sexual arousal, desire or gratification of any patron of an adult entertainment business. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-101), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 6-146. - Regulation of conduct on premises. 
Any person, firm, business, partnership, corporation or other entity licensed hereunder or patronizing an adult entertainment business or an adult entertainment facility shall comply with the following rules and regulations: 
(1)  No person shall offer adult entertainment and no patron shall remain on the premises of any adult entertainment facility except between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. Monday through Friday, and Saturday from 8:00 a.m. through 12:00 midnight on Sunday. 
(2)  No person under the age of 18 years shall be permitted on the premises of an adult entertainment facility. 
(3)  No patron shall touch, fondle or caress any employee, nor shall any employee touch, fondle or caress any patron. 
(4)  No patron shall place any tip or gratuity upon the person of any employee or in the clothing of any employee and no employee shall permit any tip or gratuity to be placed on their person or in their clothing by a patron. 
(5)  No part of any live performance of adult entertainment shall take place other than in an area generally accessible to all patrons and on a fixed stage. No person who is performing live adult entertainment shall leave a fixed stage during any performance, dance or demonstration. 
(6)  No patron shall be permitted on a fixed stage for any purpose. 
(7)  No patron shall be allowed within three feet of any fixed stage. 
(8)  No person shall serve, offer, consume or be in possession of any alcoholic beverage on the premises of an adult entertainment facility or in any parking area dedicated to use of an adult entertainment facility. 
(9)  In all rooms where adult entertainment occurs, lighting equivalent to five footcandles, as that term is used in Kaufman and Christensen, Eds., IES Lighting Handbook (Illuminating Engineering Society of North America, 1987), shall be maintained at all times that the facility is accessible to patrons. 
(10)  No private performances shall be allowed within an adult entertainment facility. 
(11)  No adult entertainment shall occur in a private room within an adult entertainment facility. 
(12)  No patron shall be permitted to enter any dressing room or private room nor shall any employee and patron jointly occupy any private room or dressing area. 
(13)  The license shall be displayed in a prominent place on the premises at all times. 
(14)  It shall be unlawful for any employee to be in a state of nudity except in a dressing room. It shall be unlawful for any patron to be in a state of nudity. For the purposes of this section, the term "nudity" shall mean showing of the human male or female genitals, pubic area or buttocks with less than a fully opaque covering; the showing of the female breast with less than a fully opaque covering of any part of the nipple. It is the belief of the mayor and council that this subsection is legal under state law and the laws of the United States of America. However, if any court of competent jurisdiction declares to the contrary, it is the intention of the mayor and council that this subsection shall cease to be applicable or enforceable and shall instead be void. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-102), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 6-147. - Prohibitions; permitted locations. 
(a)  It is the belief of the mayor and council that the activities described in subsection (1) of the definition of "adult entertainment" in section 6-145 are illegal under state law and therefore not licensable under city ordinance. However, if any court of competent jurisdiction declares to the contrary, adult entertainment shall be a permitted use within the corporate limits of the city only pursuant to this article and in locations zoned M Manufacturing. 
(b)  It is the belief of the mayor and council that the activities described in subsection (2) of the definition of "adult entertainment" in section 6-145 are illegal under state law and therefore not licensable under city ordinance. However, if any court of competent jurisdiction declares to the contrary, adult entertainment shall be a permitted use within the corporate limits of the city only pursuant to this article and in locations zoned M Manufacturing. 
(c)  It is the belief of the mayor and council that the activities described in subsection (3) of the definition of "adult entertainment" in section 6-145 are illegal under state law and therefore not licensable under city ordinance. However, if any court of competent jurisdiction declares to the contrary, adult entertainment shall be a permitted use within the corporate limits of the city only pursuant to this article and in locations zoned M Manufacturing. 
(d)  It is the belief of the mayor and council that the activities described in subsection (5) of the definition of "adult entertainment" in section 6-145 are illegal under state law and therefore not licensable under city ordinance. However, if any court of competent jurisdiction declares to the contrary, adult entertainment shall be a permitted use within the corporate limits of the city only pursuant to this article and in locations zoned M Manufacturing. 
(e)  It is the belief of the mayor and council that the activities described in subsection (6) of the definition of "adult entertainment" in section 6-145 are illegal under state law and therefore not licensable under city ordinance. However, if any court of competent jurisdiction declares to the contrary, adult entertainment shall be a permitted use within the corporate limits of the city only pursuant to this article and in locations zoned M Manufacturing. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any lingerie modeling studio to allow modeling of lingerie in any room that is closed to the public. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-103), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 6-148. - Other location requirements. 
(a)  No adult entertainment business or adult entertainment facility shall be located: 
(1)  Within 200 feet of any parcel of land which is either zoned or used for residential uses or purposes; 
(2)  Within 1,000 feet of any parcel of land upon which a place of assembly, governmental building, library, public park or playground, hospital, child care business, community club, jail, prison or building owned or operated by any governmental or quasi-governmental entity is located; 
(3)  Within 100 feet of any parcel of land upon which another establishment regulated or defined under this article is located; 
(4)  Within 200 feet of any parcel of land upon which any other establishment selling alcoholic beverages is located; 
(5)  Within 500 feet of the property boundary of any hotel or motel; or 
(6)  On a parcel which fails to provide one parking space for every three patrons that such an establishment has the capacity to hold. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, distance shall be by straight-line measurement from property line, using the closest property lines of the parcels of land involved. The term "parcel of land" means any quantity of land capable of being described by location and boundary, designated and used or to be used as a unit. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-104), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 6-149. - Structural requirements. 
Adult entertainment businesses and adult entertainment facilities shall be subject to the provisions of the zoning regulations in chapter 42, as may from time to time be amended, this article, and the following standards of use: 
(1)  In addition to the development standards of the zoning regulations in chapter 42, each adult entertainment business shall have an adult entertainment facility dedicated solely to the operation of the business named in its license. Said adult entertainment facility shall be located on a lot used for no purpose other than the conduct of the business named in the license. No adult entertainment facility shall be located in any strip shopping center, mall or other group structure. No adult entertainment facility shall share any common wall, parking area, entrance, waiting area, restrooms or lobby with any other business or use. 
(2)  The minimum lot area for an adult entertainment facility shall be one acre. 
(3)  In addition to zoning development standards governing commercial zoning districts, buildings and structures established in connection with an adult entertainment business or as an adult entertainment facility shall be separated by at least 40 feet from the buildings and structures of any other business establishment. The minimum rear yard shall be 75 feet. 
(4)  The parking standards established by the zoning regulations in chapter 42 shall apply to adult entertainment businesses and adult entertainment facilities. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-105), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 6-150. - Licenses subject to suspension or revocation. 
All licenses are subject to be suspended or revoked under the provisions of the ordinances of the city now in effect or which hereafter may be enacted. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-106), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 6-151. - License required. 
(a)  No person, group, unincorporated association, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity may operate or conduct an adult entertainment business or an adult entertainment facility or offer any form of adult entertainment without a valid and current license for an adult entertainment business having first been issued by the city clerk. A license shall be valid only if the information contained in the application therefor is true, correct and complete. 
(b)  A license to operate an adult entertainment business must be applied for and held in the name of the person, group, unincorporated association, firm, partnership, limited liability company or corporation that actually operates the business. 
(c)  No person, group, unincorporated association, firm, partnership, limited liability company or corporation shall maintain an adult entertainment facility without a valid license to operate an adult entertainment business. 
(d)  The license shall be displayed in a prominent place on the premises at all times. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-107), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 6-152. - License application information. 
To obtain an adult entertainment business license, an applicant must submit to the city clerk a completed, sworn license application containing the following information: 
(1)  If the applicant is: 
a.  An individual, the individual's legal name, aliases, date of birth, and mailing address; 
b.  A partnership, full and complete name of the partnership, whether the partnership is general or limited, a copy of the partnership agreement (if any), and the legal names, dates of birth, aliases and mailing addresses of each partner; 
c.  A corporation, the corporation's exact and complete corporate name, the date of its incorporation, evidence that the corporation is registered to do business in and in good standing with the state, the legal name, date of birth, aliases, mailing address and corporate title of each officer and director and of each stockholder, the name and address of the registered agent for service of process, and the address of the principal business office of the corporation; or 
d.  Another entity, full and complete name of the entity, whether the entity is for profit or not for profit, a copy of the document that creates the entity or establishes the rights and duties of the owners of the entity, or if no such document exists, a document that recites the rights and duties of the owners and the legal names, dates of birth, aliases and mailing addresses of each and every person who has any ownership interest in the entity or who will benefit or profit in any way from the conduct of the business; 
e.  Regardless of the form of ownership of the applicant, the legal names, dates of birth, aliases and mailing addresses of each and every person who is a beneficial or equitable owner of the adult entertainment business, being defined as any person who enjoys the rights and benefits incident to ownership, whether or not legal title evidences such ownership; 
(2)  Whether within the 15 years immediately preceding the date of the application, the applicant or any individual identified in response to subsection (1) of this section was convicted of or entered a plea of guilty or nolo contendere to any criminal offense in violation of chapter 6 of title 16 of the Official Code of Georgia, other than O.C.G.A. § 16-6-23 or 16-6-24; 
(3)  Whether the applicant or any individual identified in response to subsection (1) of this section has been issued or has applied for a license to operate an adult entertainment business under this Code or in any other jurisdiction; and, if so, the name in which the license was issued or applied for; the date any such license was granted or, if not granted, applied for; the business location for which license was issued or applied for; the current status of the application or license; and the date and circumstances of any application denial, license suspension or license revocation or other adverse action regarding any license, permit or application for license or permit; 
(4)  Whether the applicant or any individual identified in response to subsection (1) of this section holds any other business or occupation license under this Code or similar codes from other jurisdictions, and, if so, the name, location, license number, and licensing jurisdiction or agency of each such other licensed establishment; 
(5)  The location of the proposed adult entertainment facility for the conduct of the adult entertainment business for which application is made, including a legal description of the property and the legal street address; 
(6)  The names, addresses, dates of birth, aliases and dates of employment of all employees known as of the date of the application; 
(7)  A site plan and a certified survey drawn to appropriate scale of the proposed adult entertainment facility indicating at least all property lines, rights-of-way, location of buildings, parking areas and spaces, curb cuts, driveways and distances to the following: 
a.  The nearest parcel of land used or zoned for residential use; 
b.  The nearest parcel of land upon which any hotel, motel, place of assembly, library, public park, hospital, child care business, community club, jail, prison or building owned or operated by any governmental or quasi-governmental entity is located; 
c.  The nearest parcel of land upon which another establishment regulated or defined under this article is located; and 
d.  The nearest parcel of land upon which an establishment selling alcoholic beverages is located. 
(8)  A floor plan drawn to appropriate scale of the proposed establishment indicating, but not limited to: 
a.  All windows, all doors, all entrances and exits; and 
b.  All fixed structural and interior features, including but not limited to doors, walls, stages, partitions, dressing rooms, and private areas. 
(9)  Designation of two individuals who are to be actively involved in the on-site management of the proposed adult entertainment business, who reside in the Greater Atlanta area, as listed in the Bellsouth Real White Pages, or within 30 miles of the city limits, together with such representatives residence addresses, day and evening telephone numbers and means of being contacted 24 hours per day, in case of emergency. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-108), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 6-153. - Investigation fee. 
Payment of an investigation fee must accompany an application to operate an adult entertainment business. The investigative fee shall be in an amount as established by the mayor and council from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-109), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 6-154. - Disqualification for criminal conviction of specified offenses. 
(a)  No person, partnership, business, firm or corporation shall be granted a license if any person, partner, officer or owner of 15 percent or more of the shares of or interest in any such business, firm, partnership or corporation has been convicted of or has plead guilty or entered a plea of nolo contendere to any criminal offense in violation of chapter 6 of title 16 of the Official Code of Georgia, other than O.C.G.A. § 16-6-23 or 16-6-24, within a period of 15 years immediately prior to the filing of the application. 
(b)  Should any such person, partner, or officer or shareholder of a corporation, after a license has been granted, be convicted of or plead guilty or nolo contendere to any such crime, said license shall be subject to suspension or revocation under section 6-165. 
(c)  Withdrawal of an owner, officer or partner or enumerated shareholder, after being convicted or entering a plea of guilty or nolo contendere to the crimes specified in subsection (a) of this section shall not necessarily mitigate against denial o fan application or suspension or revocation of a license. 
(d)  Transfer of ownership while an owner, partner, officer or enumerated shareholder is under investigation by any law enforcement agency for any of the crimes specified in subsection (a) of this section or after such person has been convicted of or entered a plea of guilty or nolo contendere shall not necessarily mitigate against denial of an application or suspension or revocation of a license. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-110), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 6-155. - Limitation on number of licenses. 
(a)  The following shall be the maximum number of licenses for adult entertainment businesses per 1,500 persons living in the city according to the most recent decennial census of the United States as published by the United States Bureau of the Census (in making this calculation, fractions of the required population minimum shall not be counted toward the establishment of an available license): 
(1)  One license for an adult entertainment business offering adult entertainment as described in subsection (1) of the definition of "adult entertainment" in section 6-145; 
(2)  One license for an adult entertainment business offering adult entertainment as described in subsection (2) of the definition of "adult entertainment" in section 6-145; 
(3)  One license for an adult entertainment business offering adult entertainment as described in subsection (3) of the definition of "adult entertainment" in section 6-145; 
(4)  One license for an adult entertainment business offering adult entertainment as described in subsection (5) of the definition of "adult entertainment" in section 6-145; and 
(5)  One license for an adult entertainment business offering adult entertainment as described in subsection (6) of the definition of "adult entertainment" in section 6-145. 
(b)  Should an adult entertainment business meet the definition of more than one of the above, then its dominant use shall determine the category for purposes of this section. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-111), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 6-156. - Illegal activity not permitted. 
This article does not license, permit or render legal any act or conduct that is illegal under the laws of the state or the United States of America. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-112), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 6-157. - License renewal. 
A license to operate an adult entertainment business shall be valid from the date of issuance until January 1 of the following year and must be renewed annually. A change of ownership at any time shall require a new license and a new license fee. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-113), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 6-158. - License fee. 
The fee for an adult entertainment business license shall be in an amount as established by the mayor and council from time to time, and shall be payable upon approval of license application, and thereafter annually and upon any change in ownership of the business, as a prerequisite to issuance of a license. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-114), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 6-159. - Effect of change in ownership. 
(a)  Any change in more than 20 percent of the ownership, including but not limited to sale of stock or substitution of partners or members, of an adult entertainment business shall require a separate application and investigation fee. 
(b)  Any change in 20 percent or less of the ownership, including but not limited to sale of stock or substitution of partners or members, of an adult entertainment business shall not require a separate application and investigation fee. However, the adult entertainment business shall provide to the city, within 30 days of such in ownership, notice of the change as well as the names, addresses and phone number of all new stockholders, partners, members or other owners. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-115), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 6-160. - Compliance with law. 
Any person, firm, partnership or corporation which holds an adult entertainment business license must also comply with all applicable local, state and federal laws or regulations. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-116), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 6-161. - Time for action by city clerk. 
Applications for new licenses shall be passed upon by the city clerk within 60 days of the date of filing of the completed application. Date of filing shall be the time that a properly completed and executed application, along with the investigation fee, is received by the city clerk. Upon the expiration of the 60-day period without a decision being made on the application by the city clerk, the applicant shall be permitted to begin and conduct business as an adult entertainment business under this statutory provision unless and until such time as the city clerk denies the application for a new license. No person or entity conducting business as an adult entertainment business under this provision shall acquire any vested rights to continued conduct of such business, and if the city clerk later denies the application, the business must be brought into compliance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-117), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 6-162. - Denial of application. 
(a)  In the event that the city clerk denies an application for a license, the denial shall be transmitted in writing, with the reasons for that action specified to the mailing address specified on the application and pursuant to section 6-161 and the other requirements of this article. 
(b)  Effective date of denial; review hearing. 
(1)  Should the city clerk deny an application, the denial shall be effective beginning three business days from the date of the notice. Any applicant may request a hearing within ten days of the date of such notice before the city manager for the purpose of presenting evidence and asking for reconsideration of such action. Failure to request such reconsideration within ten days of the date of the notice shall result in a waiver of any appeal rights hereunder. 
(2)  If a hearing for reconsideration before the city manager is requested, a hearing shall be held not more than 30 days from the date the written notice requesting such hearing is received by the city manager. Upon the expiration of the 30-day period without a hearing, the applicant shall be permitted to begin business as an adult entertainment business under this statutory provision unless and until such time as the city manager sustains or modifies the original determination. No person or entity conducting business as an adult entertainment business under this provision shall acquire any vested rights to continued conduct of such business, and if the city manager later sustains or modifies the original determination, the business must be brought into compliance with this article. 
(3)  The city manager may sustain, overrule, or modify the original determination. The decision of the city manager following the hearing on the matter shall be issued within 20 days of the date of the hearing and shall be final. Upon the expiration of the 20-day period without a decision of the city manager being issued on the matter, the applicant shall be permitted to begin or resume business as an adult entertainment business under this statutory provision unless and until such time as the city manager sustains the original determination. No person or entity conducting business as an adult entertainment business under this provision shall acquire any vested rights to continued conduct of such business, and if the city manager later sustains or modifies the original determination, the business must be brought into compliance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-118), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 6-163. - Employee investigation; fees. 
(a)  No person may be employed, whether as an employee or as an independent contractor whose work involves any intended interaction with any patron, by an adult entertainment business holding a license issued pursuant hereto without first obtaining a work permit from the police department indicating the person has not, within the preceding ten years, been convicted of or entered a plea of guilty or nolo contendere to any criminal offense in violation of chapter 6 of title 16 of the Official Code of Georgia, other than O.C.G.A. § 16-6-23 or 16-6-24. A current and valid work permit must be kept on file at the adult entertainment facility where such person performs or is otherwise employed. This subsection shall apply to performers, entertainers and musicians engaged in temporary work as well as regular full-time and part-time employees, regardless of the nature of work performed. 
(b)  Eligibility for employment. 
(1)  The police department shall fingerprint all persons applying for a work permit to work for an adult entertainment business or at an adult entertainment facility and shall determine whether the work permit applicant has a record of conviction, whether by trial verdict, guilty plea or plea of nolo contendere, of any criminal offense in violation of chapter 6 of title 16 of the Official Code of Georgia, other than O.C.G.A. § 16-6-23 or 16-6-24. Within 20 days from the date a complete application is received by the police department, the police department shall mail (by certified mail, return receipt requested) to the work permit applicant a letter stating whether the applicant is eligible or ineligible for employment at an adult entertainment facility or by an adult entertainment business according to the criterion set forth herein. If a determination of ineligibility is made, the reason therefor shall be set forth in the letter. Upon the expiration of the 20-day period without a letter regarding eligibility being mailed to the applicant, the applicant shall be permitted to begin employment at an adult entertainment facility or by an adult entertainment business under this statutory provision unless and until such time as the police department mails to the applicant a letter stating that the applicant is ineligible. No applicant employed at an adult entertainment facility or by an adult entertainment business under this provision shall acquire any vested rights to such continued employment, and if the police department later mails to the applicant a letter stating that the applicant is ineligible, the applicant must comply with this article. For the purposes of this section, date of mailing shall be the date on which the letter is posted with the United States Postal Service. 
(2)  A determination of ineligibility may be appealed to the city clerk. A notice of appeal shall be filed in writing no later than six business days from the date of the letter from the police department. Failure to appeal the police department's determination within six business days of the letter from the police department shall constitute a waiver of any appeal rights hereunder. If an appeal is filed, a hearing shall be held not more than 30 days from the date of the written notice of appeal. Upon the expiration of the 30-day period without a hearing, the applicant shall be permitted to begin employment at an adult entertainment facility or by an adult entertainment business under this statutory provision unless and until such time as the city clerk sustains or modifies the determination of the police department. No applicant employed at an adult entertainment facility or by an adult entertainment business under this provision shall acquire any vested rights to such continued employment, and if the city clerk later sustains or modifies the determination of the police department, the applicant must comply with this article. 
(3)  The city clerk may sustain, overrule, or modify the determination of the police department. The decision of the city clerk following the hearing on the matter shall be issued within 30 days of the date of the hearing and shall be final. Upon the expiration of the 30-day period without a decision of the city clerk being issued on the matter, the applicant shall be permitted to begin employment at an adult entertainment facility or by an adult entertainment business under this statutory provision unless and until such time as the city clerk sustains or modifies the decision of the police department. No applicant employed at an adult entertainment facility or by an adult entertainment business under this provision shall acquire any vested rights to continued employment at such business, and if the city clerk later sustains or modifies the determination of the police department, the applicant must comply with this article. There shall be no right of appeal of the decision of the city clerk. 
(c)  Work permits shall expire 12 months from the date of issuance and it shall be the responsibility of the employee or independent contractor to see that the permit is thereafter renewed. It shall be unlawful for an adult entertainment business or facility to allow any person required by this article to obtain a work permit to work or perform on its premises without a valid work permit. The adult entertainment business must keep a copy of the work permit of each person required by this article to obtain a work permit on file at the adult entertainment facility available at the facility for inspection by city officials at all times. 
(d)  The mayor and council may prescribe reasonable fees for work permits and investigations incident thereto. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-119), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 6-164. - Exemptions. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed as applying to the practice of any profession or occupation licensed by the state or a licensing agency recognized by the state. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-120), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 6-165. - Suspension or revocation of license; appeal. 
(a)  The following shall constitute grounds for the suspension or revocation of adult entertainment business licenses: 
(1)  Any violation of this article regulating adult entertainment facilities or businesses or other ordinances of the city relating to conduct of the business. 
(2)  Violation of any federal or state law by any owner or employee arising out of conduct on the licensed premises or otherwise affecting the suitability of such person to engage in adult entertainment. 
(b)  Notice; review hearing. 
(1)  Should the city clerk determine that grounds exist for the suspension or revocation of a license under subsection (a) of this section, the city clerk shall send by first class mail to the license holder written notice of the license suspension or revocation with a statement of the grounds supporting such action. Such suspension or revocation shall be effective beginning three business days from the date of the notice. Any license holder may request a hearing within ten days of the date of such notice before the city manager for the purpose of presenting evidence and asking for reconsideration of such action. Failure to request such reconsideration within ten days of the date of the notice shall result in a waiver of any appeal rights hereunder. 
(2)  If a hearing for reconsideration before the city manager is requested, a hearing shall be held not more than 30 days from the date the written notice requesting such hearing is received by the city manager. Upon the expiration of the 30-day period without a hearing, the license holder shall be permitted to resume business as an adult entertainment business under this statutory provision unless and until such time as the city manager sustains or modifies the original determination. No person or entity conducting business as an adult entertainment business under this provision shall acquire any vested rights to continued conduct of such business, and if the city manager later sustains or modifies the original determination, the business must be brought into compliance with this article. 
(3)  The city manager may sustain, overrule, or modify the original determination. The decision of the city manager following the hearing on the matter shall be issued within 20 days of the date of the hearing and shall be final. Upon the expiration of the 20-day period without a decision of the city manager being issued on the matter, the license holder shall be permitted to resume business as an adult entertainment business under this statutory provision unless and until such time as the city manager sustains the original determination. No person or entity conducting business as an adult entertainment business under this provision shall acquire any vested rights to continued conduct of such business, and if the city manager later sustains or modifies the original determination, the business must be brought into compliance with this article. 
(c)  Any violation by an agent or employee of a license holder which would subject the licensee to suspension or revocation under subsection (a) of this section shall be considered a violation by the licensee for the purpose of the suspension and revocation provisions of this section. 
(d)  In addition to the procedure for license suspension and/or revocation as outlined in this section, any violation of this article shall subject the offender, upon conviction, to punishment as provided by section 1-8. 
(Ord. No. 03-04, § 1(art. IV, § 10-121), 4-14-2003) 
Chapter 8 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to exercise animal control, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(3); dogs generally, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-1 et seq.; Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; rabies control and licensing of animals by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Agreement with county. 
The mayor and council are authorized to enter into an agreement with the county or any agency or department thereof for the enforcement of this chapter. When such is the case, the rules of the party with whom the contract is made as to impoundment, storage, costs, fees, redemption and disposal shall prevail. 
(Code 1972, § 3-6; Code 1994, § 14-1) 
Sec. 8-2. - Manner of keeping animals and fowl. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, maintain or permit any animal or fowl in the city in such manner as to create an unsatisfactory condition or to cause offensive odors. Upon receipt of a complaint from a citizen of the city that such a condition exists, it shall be the duty of the code enforcement officer or the chief of police to inform the owner or the person in charge of the animal or fowl of the complaint made. Such owner or keeper shall be notified that he has a period of 72 hours within which the unsanitary condition or offensive odor must be abated. Failure to abate the condition or the odor within the time specified shall constitute an offense against this chapter. 
(Code 1972, § 3-9; Code 1994, § 14-2) 
Sec. 8-3. - Poison. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to leave or deposit any poison or substance containing poison on any property not owned by such person. 
(Code 1972, § 3-8; Code 1994, § 14-3) 
Sec. 8-4. - Disposal of dead animals. 
Dead animals on public or private property shall be removed by the owner, and it shall be unlawful to fail to do so. Should the owner fail to do so, the city shall remove and dispose of the carcass and charge the costs of removal and disposition to the owner. 
(Code 1972, § 3-7; Code 1994, § 14-4) 
Secs. 8-5—8-26. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOGS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-27. - Confinement; leash required. 
A dog owner residing in the city is required to confine his dog to the premises of the owner, and it shall be unlawful for any owner to fail to do so. However, the owner or some competent person who has the permission of the owner may have a dog off the owner's premises, provided that the dog is on a leash not more than six feet in length. 
(Code 1972, § 3-4; Code 1994, § 14-26) 
Sec. 8-28. - Impoundment of dogs running at large. 
A dog at large is defined as any dog off the owner's premises and not on a leash as described in section 8-27. All dogs at large in the city shall be impounded by the proper authorities of the county. 
(Code 1972, § 3-5; Code 1994, § 14-27) 
Secs. 8-29—8-59. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DANGEROUS DOGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Responsible Dog Ownership Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq. 

Sec. 8-60. - Authority; definitions. 
(a)  The ordinance from which this division is derived is enacted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq. 
(b)  The definitions set forth in O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq. ("Dangerous Dog Control—Definitions"), shall be effective as definitions of the words, terms and phrases used in this division. All words, terms and phrases used herein, other than those specifically defined elsewhere in this chapter, shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq., and shall have the same scope and effect that the same words, terms and phrases have where used in O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq. 
(Code 1994, § 14-41; Ord. No. 89-1, § 3(3-16), 1-10-1989) 
Sec. 8-61. - Appointment of dog control officer and animal control board. 
(a)  The county, pursuant to contract with the city, shall designate a dog control officer who shall perform the duties and exercise the powers assigned to that position by the Dangerous Dog Control Law (O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.). 
(b)  The county animal control boards are designated to serve as animal control boards for the city, pursuant to intergovernmental contract. 
(Code 1994, § 14-42; Ord. No. 89-1, § 3(3-17), 1-10-1989) 
Sec. 8-62. - Registration. 
(a)  The owner of a classified dog must secure a certificate of registration in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 4-8-27 (Dangerous Dog Control—Issuance of Certificate of Registration). 
(b)  The annual fee for the certificate of registration shall be as established from time to time by the county. 
(c)  Nonpayment of the registration fee shall be an offense and shall be punishable under section 1-8. 
(d)  The dog control officer shall maintain a copy of all state laws and sections of this Code applicable to dangerous dogs and potentially dangerous dogs which shall be available for inspection by the public during regular business hours. The dog control officer shall not be authorized to interpret these laws or give advice to owners. 
(Code 1994, § 14-43; Ord. No. 89-1, § 3(3-20), 1-10-1989) 
Sec. 8-63. - Investigation. 
The dog control officer may make such investigations and inquiries as may be necessary to identify dangerous dogs and potentially dangerous dogs and their respective owners within the city. The dog control officer shall have the authority to investigate complaints as part of the process of identifying dangerous dogs and potentially dangerous dogs. The dog control officer's authority to investigate shall include the power to enter onto public and private property for the purpose of periodic inspection. 
(Code 1994, § 14-44; Ord. No. 89-1, § 3(3-18), 1-10-1989) 
Sec. 8-64. - Classification; notice and hearing. 
(a)  When a dog control officer determines that a dog is subject to classification as a dangerous dog or vicious dog, the dog control officer shall mail a dated notice to the dog's owner within 72 hours. Such notice shall include a summary of the dog control officer's determination and shall state that the owner has a right to request a hearing from the city manager or his designee on the dog control officer's determination within 15 days after the date shown on the notice. The notice shall also provide a form for requesting the hearing and shall state that if a hearing is not requested within the allotted time, the dog control officer's determination shall become effective for all purposes under this division. 
(b)  When a hearing is requested by a dog owner in accordance with subsection (a) of this section, such hearing shall be scheduled within 30 days after the request is received; provided, however, that such hearing may be continued by the city manager or designee for good cause shown. At least ten days prior to the hearing, the city manager or designee conducting the hearing shall mail to the dog owner written notice of the date, time, and place of the hearing. At the hearing, the dog owner shall be given the opportunity to testify and present evidence and the city manager or designee conducting the hearing shall receive other evidence and testimony as may be reasonably necessary to sustain, modify, or overrule the dog control officer's determination. 
(c)  Within ten days after the hearing, the city manager or designee which conducted the hearing shall mail written notice to the dog owner of its determination on the matter. If such determination is that the dog is a dangerous dog or a vicious dog, the notice of classification shall specify the date upon which that determination shall be effective. If the determination is that the dog is to be euthanized pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 4-8-26, the notice shall specify the date by which the euthanasia shall occur. 
(d)  Judicial review of the authority's final decision may be had in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 50-13-19. 
(Code 1994, § 14-45; Ord. No. 89-1, § 3(3-19), 1-10-1989) 
Sec. 8-65. - Confiscation. 
(a)  Dangerous dogs and potentially dangerous dogs are subject to immediate confiscation pursuant to the grounds for confiscation in O.C.G.A. § 4-8-27. 
(b)  Dangerous dogs and potentially dangerous dogs that have been confiscated shall be taken to such impound facility as is designated from time to time by the mayor and council. 
(c)  Dog owners shall pay a confiscation fee and the daily boarding fee as established by the county for each day the dog remains at the impound facility. Nonpayment of either or both of these fees shall be an offense and shall be punishable under section 1-8. 
(d)  Dangerous dogs and potentially dangerous dogs shall be returned to their owners pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 4-8-27 and after all fees have been paid. 
(Code 1994, § 14-46; Ord. No. 89-1, § 3(3-21), 1-10-1989) 
Secs. 8-66—8-88. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LIVESTOCK 

Sec. 8-89. - Running at large. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner or the person having custody to allow any livestock or fowl to run at large in the city. 
(Code 1972, § 3-1; Code 1994, § 14-66) 
Sec. 8-90. - Impoundment; fees. 
It shall be the duty of the proper authorities of the county to impound any livestock or fowl found running or roaming at large in the city. For each day of impoundment of any livestock or fowl, the county shall receive a fee from the owner or custodian in accordance with county policies prior to release. 
(Code 1972, § 3-2; Code 1994, § 14-67) 
Sec. 8-91. - Notice of impounding; disposition. 
Upon the impoundment of any livestock or fowl, the officer impounding shall make a reasonable and continuing effort to notify the true owner or custodian. The animal may be redeemed by the owner or custodian by the payment of the impounding fees referred to in section 8-90. If an impounded animal is not redeemed in accordance with county policies, the county will dispose of the animal. 
(Code 1972, § 3-3; Code 1994, § 14-68) 
Chapter 10 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to adopt technical codes, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(12); construction standards generally, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-1 et seq.; minimum state construction codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25; enforcement of minimum state construction codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Building official or building inspector means the qualified building official or qualified building inspector as designated by the city. 
Code enforcement officer means the qualified code enforcement official as designated by the city. 
Sec. 10-2. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The building official and the code enforcement official are hereby authorized to enforce within the city the provisions of this chapter, the zoning regulations in chapter 42, and the state minimum codes adopted herein. 
(b)  The building official and the code enforcement official are further authorized to render interpretations of this chapter and the adopted state codes and to adopt policies and procedures in order to clarify the application of their provisions. Such interpretations, policies and procedures shall be in compliance with the intent and purpose of this chapter. Such policies and procedures shall not have the force and effect of law and shall not have the effect of waiving requirements specifically provided for in this Code or in the adopted state codes. 
Sec. 10-3. - Final decision. 
The city manager or his designee shall constitute the building and construction board of appeals of the city (hereinafter referred to as the "appeals board"). The duties of the appeals board will be to act as a reviewing body in matters pertaining to building and construction standards, devices, appliances and equipment. The building and construction board of appeals shall review and render a decision, when requested to do so by any person, firm or corporation, on any interpretation or ruling made by the building official or the code enforcement official relative to this chapter. Any decision or ruling rendered by the appeals board shall be final, subject to appeal to and decision of the mayor and council. 
Sec. 10-4. - Duties of code enforcement officer. 
It shall be the duty of the code enforcement officer to see to the proper construction, alteration, repair, redesigning, remodeling, demolition, moving, removal, equipment, use and occupancy, location and maintenance of all buildings of every nature in the city. 
(Code 1972, § 4-1; Code 1994, § 18-1) 
Sec. 10-5. - Codes adopted; amendments. 
(a)  The codes listed in this section are adopted for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the construction, alteration, repair, redesigning, remodeling, demolition, moving, removal, equipment, use and occupancy, location and maintenance of buildings and structures.
