(b)  In addition to the criminal penalties prescribed by subsection (a) of this section, upon a third conviction or plea of guilty or nolo contendere within a 12-month period, the business license of the license holder shall be suspended for a period of six months. A fourth conviction or a plea to a similar offense within 12 months shall result in forfeiture of the business license. No new business license shall issue to a person whose license has been forfeited for the same category of business within the city for a period of 12 months. Suspension or forfeiture of licenses shall be accomplished by action of the mayor and council following notice and opportunity to be heard. 
(Code 1994, § 22-114; Ord. No. 93-3, § 11, 6-21-1993) 
Sec. 12-132. - Business licenses. 
All used motor vehicle dealers, motor vehicle dismantlers and motor vehicle salvage dealers operating within the city shall obtain a city business license and pay the appropriate license fees and taxes therefor as a condition of carrying on such business. No business license shall be issued to a used motor vehicle dealer unless the applicant presents proof of a current state license to operate as a used car dealer under O.C.G.A. § 43-47-1 et seq. No business license shall be issued to a motor vehicle dismantler unless the applicant presents proof of a current state license to operate as a dismantler under O.C.G.A. § 43-48-1 et seq. 
(Code 1994, § 22-115; Ord. No. 93-3, § 3, 6-21-1993) 
Sec. 12-133. - Open storage of used vehicles. 
The open storage or display of used motor vehicles, other than junk vehicles, is permitted by used motor vehicle dealers, provided the location of such storage or display areas is limited to the BG General Business District or M Manufacturing District and otherwise complies with the zoning standards in chapter 42. 
(Code 1994, § 22-116; Ord. No. 93-3, § 4, 6-21-1993) 
Sec. 12-134. - Display of junk vehicles. 
Junk vehicles may not be maintained on open lots or be located upon premises of a used motor vehicle dealer so as to be visible from any public right-of-way or from any adjacent private property. All junk vehicles shall be completely enclosed within a building or stored behind a solid opaque fence at least eight feet in height. Such fence shall meet the setback requirements of chapter 42, pertaining to zoning. The use of webbing in chainlink fences to meet the requirements of this section is specifically prohibited. 
(Code 1994, § 22-117; Ord. No. 93-3, § 5, 6-21-1993) 
Sec. 12-135. - Locations for motor vehicle salvage dealers and dismantlers. 
Motor vehicle salvage dealers and motor vehicle dismantlers may be located only within the M Manufacturing District. All storage of vehicles and parts shall be either completely enclosed within a building or behind a solid opaque fence at least eight feet in height so as to screen the operations from any public right-of-way or adjacent private property. Usable parts removed by motor vehicle dismantlers shall be likewise stored within enclosed buildings or behind a solid opaque fence at least eight feet in height so that such parts are not readily visible from any public right-of-way or any adjacent private property. 
(Code 1994, § 22-118; Ord. No. 93-3, § 6, 6-21-1993) 
Sec. 12-136. - Restrictions on dismantlers. 
A motor vehicle dismantler shall conduct his operations in strict compliance with the following standards: 
(1)  All fluids shall be drained from every vehicle at the time the vehicle first appears on the dismantler's property. Drainage and storage of fluids shall be performed in compliance with all EPA and EPD rules. 
(2)  Dismantling of parts from abandoned, wrecked or reparable motor vehicles shall be accomplished within ten days of the date such vehicles are first moved to the dismantler's facility. 
(3)  When usable parts are removed from a vehicle, the hulk of the vehicle shall be removed from the dismantler's premises within 20 days. 
(4)  A dismantler shall keep records showing the date each vehicle from which parts are taken was brought onto the dealer's premises, the date parts and fluids removal was completed and the date when the hulk of the vehicle was removed from those premises. Such records shall be open to inspection during reasonable business hours by officials of the city for the purpose of ensuring compliance with this article. 
(Code 1994, § 22-119; Ord. No. 93-3, § 7, 6-21-1993) 
Sec. 12-137. - Notice to remove. 
(a)  Whenever the chief of police or his authorized agent determines that vehicles or dismantled parts are being maintained in violation of this article, he shall provide notice to the owner or operator of the business to correct such violation and to bring the premises into compliance with this article. Such notice shall be in writing, shall describe the offense and shall provide five days within which to comply with this article. 
(b)  The notice of violation shall be served by one of the following methods: 
(1)  Personal service; 
(2)  Certified mail, return receipt requested; and 
(3)  Where service has been attempted and cannot be accomplished either by personal service or by certified mail, the notice may be served by mailing a copy of the notice by first class mail, with adequate postage, to the last known address of the owner and by posting a copy of the notice on the business premises. 
(Code 1994, § 22-120; Ord. No. 93-3, § 8, 6-21-1993) 
Sec. 12-138. - Failure to comply with notice. 
Upon receipt of a notice of violation pursuant to section 12-137 and upon failure of the owner or operator of those premises to bring the premises into compliance with this article within the period of time stated in the notice, the chief of police or his agent may proceed to cite the owner or operator of the business for violation of this article. Such notice of violation shall include a summons to appear in the municipal court on a date certain to answer the charge of violation of this article. Each and every vehicle maintained in violation of this article shall be considered as a separate offense, and each day beyond the five-day notice period during which such vehicle remains on the property shall also be considered a separate offense. 
(Code 1994, § 22-121; Ord. No. 93-3, § 9, 6-21-1993) 
Secs. 12-139—12-159. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MASSAGE THERAPY AND MASSAGE PARLORS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Georgia Massage Therapy Practice Act, O.C.G.A. § 43-24A-1 et seq.; municipal ordinances in effect before July 1, 2005, relating to the practice of massage therapy or requiring licensure of a massage therapist are preempted from enforcement against persons issued a license under Georgia Massage Therapy Practice Act, O.C.G.A. § 43-24A-22. 

Sec. 12-160. - Massage therapy definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Board means the state board of massage therapy established under O.C.G.A. § 43-24A-1 et seq. 
License means a valid and current certificate of registration issued by the state board of massage therapy as provided by O.C.G.A. § 43-24A-1 et seq. 
Massage and/or massage therapy means the application of a system of structured touch, pressure, movement, and holding to the soft tissue of the body in which the primary intent is to enhance or restore health and well-being. The term "massage" or "massage therapy" includes complementary methods, including without limitation the external application of water, superficial heat, superficial cold, lubricants, salt scrubs, or other topical preparations and the use of commercially available electromechanical devices which do not require the use of transcutaneous electrodes and which mimic or enhance the actions possible by the hands; the term "massage" or "massage therapy" also includes determining whether massage therapy is appropriate or contraindicated, or whether referral to another health care provider is appropriate. The term "massage therapy" shall not include the use of ultrasound, fluidotherapy, laser, and other methods of deep thermal modalities. 
Massage therapist means a person who administers massage or massage therapy for compensation. 
Massage therapy assistant means any person who does not qualify as a massage therapist as that term is defined in this section, but who assists a massage therapist and who works under the direct supervision of a licensed massage therapist. 
(Ord. No. 06-02, § (a)(22-122), 6-12-2006) 
Sec. 12-161. - Practice by person not licensed; public nuisance. 
The practice of massage therapy is declared to be an activity affecting the public interest and involving the health, safety, and welfare of the public. Such practice by a person who is not licensed to practice in the state is declared to be a public nuisance, harmful to the public health, safety, and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 06-02, § (a)(22-123), 6-12-2006) 
Sec. 12-162. - State license. 
The city recognizes that the state has not formed a state board at this time for massage therapists to apply for a license in the state. Consequently, all massage therapy shall be prohibited within the city limits until such state board is formed as provided by O.C.G.A. § 43-24A-1 et seq. Any and all massage and/or massage therapy clinics and/or parlors existing within the city limits at this time shall apply for a state license as provided by O.C.G.A. § 43-24A-1 et seq., as soon as the state board is formed. 
(Ord. No. 06-02, § (a)(22-124), 6-12-2006) 
Sec. 12-163. - Fines and punishment. 
Any person who practices massage therapy without a valid license in violation of O.C.G.A. § 43-24A-1 et seq., upon being convicted, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00 for each offense or with imprisonment for not more than 180 days, or both. Upon being convicted a second or subsequent time under this section, such person shall be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 for each offense, imprisonment for not more than six months, or both. 
(Ord. No. 06-02, § (a)(22-124), 6-12-2006) 
Secs. 12-164—12-194. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - NON-CONSENSUAL TOWING PERMITS 

Sec. 12-195. - Definitions. 
The following terms when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
License means a private trespass towing license issued by the city pursuant to this article and to O.C.G.A. § 44-1-13(d). 
Towing and storage firm means a business entity that removes vehicles from private real property at the request of a person in possession of such private real property pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 44-1-13(a). 
(Ord. No. 03-10, § 1(art. VI, § 22-131), 12-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-196. - License required. 
It shall be unlawful for any towing and storage firm to operate within the city without a valid non-consensual towing permit. The city shall charge an annual fee for the permit. The annual permit fee shall be in an amount as established by the mayor and council from time to time. Permits shall be valid for 12 months after the date of issuance. 
(Ord. No. 03-10, § 1(art. VI, § 22-132), 12-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-197. - Qualifications. 
(a)  In order to qualify for and keep a permit, a towing and storage firm must adhere to the following conditions: 
(1)  Maximum reasonable costs for removal, relocation, and storage of vehicles shall not exceed the maximum rate tariff as set by the state department of motor vehicle safety from time to time. 
(2)  No storage fees shall be charged for the first 24 hours after a vehicle is removed from a property. 
(3)  No fees for removal or storage shall be charged for any removal or storage that occurs in violation of O.C.G.A. § 44-1-13. 
(4)  For each vehicle removed, the towing and storage firm must notify the local law enforcement agency having jurisdiction over the property from which the vehicle is removed as soon as reasonably possible after such removal that the vehicle has been towed and of the license tag identification information for the vehicle. 
(5)  A secure impoundment facility must be maintained. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a towing and storage firm to fail to adhere to these conditions. 
(Ord. No. 03-10, § 1(art. VI, § 22-133), 12-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-198. - Adoption of other regulations. 
All other applicable regulations contained in O.C.G.A. § 44-1-13 and adopted by the state department of motor vehicle safety are hereby adopted by reference. 
(Ord. No. 03-10, § 1(art. VI, § 22-134), 12-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-199. - Penalties. 
(a)  For each failure to provide the notice required by section 12-197(a)(4), violators shall be subject to a fine of $200.00. The city's receipt from another jurisdiction of a report that the vehicle has been stolen shall raise a rebuttable presumption of a failure to provide the notice required by section 12-197(a)(4). 
(b)  Failure to obtain a permit required by this article may result in a civil penalty of $2,500.00. 
(c)  In addition to, or in lieu of, the penalty provided by subsection (a) of this section, the city may terminate the permit of a towing and storage firm for any failure to comply with the terms and conditions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 03-10, § 1(art. VI, § 22-135), 12-8-2013) 
Secs. 12-200—12-221. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - CABLE AND VIDEO FRANCHISES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Consumer Choice for Television Act, O.C.G.A. § 36-76-1 et seq. 

Sec. 12-222. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Cable service means the one-way transmission to subscribers of video programming or other programming service and subscriber interaction, if any, which is required for the selection or use of such video programming or other programming service. The term "cable service" shall not include any video programming provided by a provider of commercial mobile service as defined in 47 USC 332(d) or video programming provided as part of and via a service that enables users to access content, information, e-mail, or other services offered over the public Internet. 
Cable service provider means any person or group of persons: 
(1)  Who provides cable service over a cable system and directly or through one or more affiliates owns a significant interest in such cable system; or 
(2)  Who otherwise controls or is responsible for, through any arrangement, the management and operation of such a cable system. 
Cable system means a facility consisting of a set of closed transmission paths and associated signal generation, reception, and control equipment that is designed to provide cable service which includes video programming and which is provided to multiple subscribers within a community, but the term "cable system" shall not include: 
(1)  A facility that serves only to retransmit the television signals of one or more television broadcast stations; 
(2)  A facility that serves subscribers without using any public right-of-way as defined in this section; 
(3)  A facility of a common carrier which is subject, in whole or in part, to the provisions of 47 USC 201 through 276, except that such facility shall be considered a cable system, other than for purposes of 47 USC 541(c), to the extent such facility is used in the transmission of video programming directly to subscribers, unless the extent of such use is solely to provide interactive on-demand services as that term is defined in 47 USC 522(12); 
(4)  An open video system that complies with 47 USC 573; or 
(5)  Any facility of any electric utility used solely for operating such electric utility system. 
Franchise means an initial authorization or renewal of an authorization issued by a franchise authority, regardless of whether the authorization is designated as a franchise, permit, license, resolution, contract, ordinance, certificate, agreement, or otherwise, that authorizes the construction or operation of a cable service provider or video service provider's network in the public rights-of-way. 
Franchise authority means any governmental entity empowered by federal, state, or local law to grant a franchise. With regard to the holder of a state franchise within the service areas covered by such state franchise, the secretary of state shall be the sole franchising authority. With respect to a franchise agreement with a municipal or county governing authority, that municipality or county shall be the sole franchising authority within the service areas covered by that local franchise. 
Gross revenues means all revenues received from subscribers for the provision of cable service or video service, including franchise fees for cable service providers and video service providers, and advertising and home shopping services revenues and shall be determined in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. The term "gross revenues" shall not include: 
(1)  Amounts billed and collected as a line item on the subscriber's bill to recover any taxes, surcharges, or governmental fees that are imposed on or with respect to the services provided or measured by the charges, receipts, or payments therefor; provided, however, that for purposes of this section, such tax, surcharge, or governmental fee shall not include any ad valorem taxes, net income taxes, or generally applicable business or occupation taxes not measured exclusively as a percentage of the charges, receipts, or payments for services; 
(2)  Any revenue, such as bad debt, not actually received, even if billed; 
(3)  Any revenue received by any affiliate or any other person in exchange for supplying goods or services used by the provider to provide cable service or video programming; 
(4)  Any amounts attributable to refunds, rebates, or discounts; 
(5)  Any revenue from services provided over the network that are associated with or classified as noncable or nonvideo services under federal law, including, without limitation, revenues received from telecommunications services, information services other than cable service or video service, Internet access services, or directory or Internet advertising revenue, including, without limitation, yellow pages, white pages, banner advertisements, and electronic publishing advertising. Where the sale of any such noncable or nonvideo service is bundled with the sale of one or more cable services or video services and sold for a single nonitemized price, the term "gross revenues" shall include only those revenues that are attributable to cable service or video service based on the provider's books and records; such revenues shall be allocated in a manner consistent with generally accepted accounting principles; 
(6)  Any revenue from late fees not initially booked as revenues, returned check fees, or interest; 
(7)  Any revenue from sales or rental of property, except such property as the subscriber shall be required to buy or rent exclusively from the cable service provider or video service provider to receive cable service or video service; 
(8)  Any revenue received from providing or maintaining inside wiring; 
(9)  Any revenue from sales for resale with respect to which the purchaser shall be required to pay a franchise fee, provided the purchaser certifies in writing that it shall resell the service and pay a franchise fee with respect thereto; or 
(10)  Any amounts attributable to a reimbursement of costs, including, but not limited to, the reimbursements by programmers of marketing costs incurred for the promotion or introduction of video programming. 
Public right-of-way means the area in, on, along, over, or under the public roads that are part of the municipal or county road system or the state highway system. 
Service area means the geographic territory within the city where a cable service provider or video service provider provides or has proposed to offer cable service or video service pursuant to a franchise. 
Subscriber means any person or entity lawfully receiving video service from a video service provider or cable service from a cable service provider. 
Video programming means programming provided by, or generally considered comparable to programming provided by, a television broadcast station, as set forth in 47 USC 522(20). 
Video service means the provision of video programming through wireline facilities located at least in part in the public rights-of-way without regard to delivery technology, including Internet protocol technology. The term "video service" shall not include any video programming provided by a provider of commercial mobile service as defined in 47 USC 332(d) or video programming provided as part of and via a service that enables users to access content, information, e-mail, or other services offered over the public Internet. 
Video service provider means an entity providing video service as defined in this section. The term "video service provider" shall not include a cable service provider. 
(Ord. No. 08-01, § 1(22-130), 3-10-2008) 
Sec. 12-223. - Franchise fee. 
(a)  For all cable and/or video service provided in the service area by cable and/or video service providers, a franchise fee shall be imposed in the amount equal to five percent of the gross revenues the cable and/or video service provider receives from providing cable and/or video service to subscribers in the service area. 
(b)  The franchise fee shall be payable to the city within 30 days after the last day of each calendar quarter. Such payment will be considered complete if accompanied by a statement showing, for the quarter covered by the payment: 
(1)  The aggregate amount of the state franchise holder's gross revenues, specifically identifying subscriber and advertising and home shopping services revenues under this article insofar as the franchise holder's existing billing systems include such capability, attributable to such municipality or unincorporated areas of the county; and 
(2)  The amount of the franchise fee payment due to such municipality or county. 
(c)  In the event that franchise fees are not paid on or before the dates specified in subsection (b) of this section, then the city shall provide written notice to the franchise holder giving the cable service provider or video service provider 15 days from the date of the franchise holder's receipt of such notice to cure any such nonpayment. In the event franchise fees are not remitted to the city postmarked on or before the expiration of the 15 day cure period, then the holder of the state franchise shall pay interest thereon at a rate of one percent per month to the city. If the 15 day cure period expires on Saturday, Sunday, or a legal holiday, the due date shall be the next business day. Moreover, the franchise holder shall not be assessed interest on late payments if franchise payments were submitted in error to a neighboring local governing authority. 
(Ord. No. 08-01, § 1(22-131), 3-10-2008) 
Secs. 12-224—12-254. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PAWNBROKERS AND PRECIOUS METALS DEALERS[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference— Pawnbrokers generally, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-130 et seq.; municipal authority to license and regulate pawnbrokers, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-136; duties of purchasers of gold bullion, gold dust, etc., O.C.G.A. § 12-4-120 et seq.; dealers in precious metals and gems, O.C.G.A. § 43-37-1 et seq.; dealers in used watches, O.C.G.A. § 43-49-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-255. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Dealer in precious metals and gems means a person, whether known as a redemption center, gold and silver dealer, pawnshop or any other name, either owner or manager, whose business involves receiving by buying or trading of, for or in precious metals such as gold or silver or platinum, including coins, and the receiving by buying or trading jewelry, gems or precious or semiprecious stones; however, the term shall not include purchases from licensed wholesalers in the normal course of business nor shall it include pawnbrokers who only take precious metals or gems on pawn or pledge. 
Employee means any person employed or allowed to perform duties, whether or not such person receives a salary, wages or other compensation or consideration, but not including the person covered on the license or renewal application. 
Goods means the same as its normal meaning and the term should further be construed in the broadest sense allowable and should include all forms of personal property. 
Owner means any person or partner or stockholder owning 25 percent or more of a business. 
Pawnbroker means any person who shall in any manner lend or advance money or other things for profit on the pledge or possession of personal property or other valuable things other than securities or written evidences of indebtedness or who deals in the purchasing of personal property or other valuable things on condition of selling such back to the seller at a stipulated price. 
Person means individual, firm, corporation, partnership or any other entity. 
(Code 1994, § 74-1) 
Sec. 12-256. - State law. 
This article is to be construed as consistent with state law. However, this article is to be applied in lieu of state law and state fee and registration requirements whenever possible. It is the intent of the mayor and council that all duties delegated to the chief law enforcement officer of the city shall be exercised as provided in this article. 
(Code 1994, § 74-3) 
Sec. 12-257. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Any person licensed under this article shall be guilty of an offense if such person shall: 
(1)  Fail to make any entry of any required item in the permanent record book. 
(2)  Make any false entry therein. 
(3)  Falsify, obliterate, record so that information is illegible, or destroy or remove from his place of business such permanent record book. 
(4)  Refuse to allow any duly authorized law enforcement officer to inspect such permanent record book or any goods in his possession, during the ordinary hours of business or any reasonable time, or refuse to allow any member of the general public to inspect goods in his possession being held under pawn or purchase, within the 15-day purchase and 30-day pawn dates, pursuant to section 12-268, during ordinary hours of business. 
(5)  Be convicted or plead nolo contendere to any crime prohibited by this section. 
(6)  Fail to maintain a record of each pawn or purchase transaction for at least four years. 
(7)  Violate any other section of this article. 
(b)  Operation of any business under this article in violation of this article shall constitute a separate offense for each day of operation. 
(Code 1994, § 74-4) 
Sec. 12-258. - Exclusions, exceptions. 
Businesses which limit the purchase of used valuables to the acceptance of trade-ins for credit for new goods or the dispensing of refunds in regard to valuables previously purchased from the business shall not be required to comply with this article. 
(Code 1994, § 74-5) 
Sec. 12-259. - Location of business. 
All businesses licensed under this article shall be located in strict compliance with chapter 42, pertaining to zoning, and at a location with an identifiable street address, which shall be stated on the license or renewal application, along with other required information. No business licensed under this article shall change its address without giving advance notice to the city clerk, the code enforcement officer and the police department and receiving approval of the change, such approval being granted if the new location complies with this article and chapter 42, pertaining to zoning. No such business shall be operated in or from a motel or hotel. 
(Code 1994, § 74-6) 
Sec. 12-260. - Records. 
All pawnbrokers and dealers of precious metals and gems, in addition to other records, shall keep books wherein shall be entered an accurate description of all property received by or pledged or sold to them. Such description shall include the brand name of the article; any identifying mark, number, initial, social security number or name of any person or company; and a statement of the kind of material of which it is made. In such books there shall be entered also the name, age, address, signature and identification number from a driver's license or similar identification of the person by whom the property was delivered, deposited or sold; the name of the broker, agent or employee receiving the item; the time when such transaction occurred; the price paid for the goods purchased; and the check number issued, if applicable. These entries shall be made no later than one hour after the transaction. A permanent bound set of the pawn tickets shall constitute the book required by this section. All books and records required by this article and items pledged or sold shall at all times be subject to inspection and examination by any law enforcement officer of the city or the state. Any person engaged in any business licensed under this article who shall fail or refuse to keep the records as provided in this article or who shall make false entries concerning the transaction or who shall fail or refuse to permit an inspection by any law enforcement officer of the city or the state of such records and of the property with or sold to them shall be guilty of a violation of this article. 
(Code 1994, § 74-7) 
Sec. 12-261. - Standard forms required. 
All businesses licensed under this article shall use a standard form for pawn and a standard form for purchase, and no ticket may be used for a dual purpose. Standard forms may differ only by the name of the business and business' address. The design of this form shall be provided by the city and the forms shall be numbered and chronologically used and sent to the police department. Each number missing from the chronological sequence shall be considered a separate violation of this article. 
(Code 1994, § 74-8) 
Sec. 12-262. - Accepting articles without making required records. 
No business licensed under this article shall take any item in pawn or purchase, taking full or possession title thereto, without entering each transaction of such goods on the books and on the standard forms as provided in sections 12-260 and 12-261. 
(Code 1994, § 74-9) 
Sec. 12-263. - Daily report to police. 
Every business licensed under this article shall make a daily report in writing to the police department of all property pledged or purchased during the 24-hour period ending at 10:00 p.m. on the date of the report. Such reports shall be legibly written or typed in English and shall show the following: 
(1)  Name and address of the business; 
(2)  Time of transaction; 
(3)  Sequel number of the pawn or purchase tickets; 
(4)  Amount paid or advanced; 
(5)  Full description of articles, including kind, style, material, color, design and number of stones in jewelry and all identifying names, marks, numbers, initials or social security numbers; and 
(6)  A description of the person selling or pawning the item, including name, address, race, weight and height, and a description of the identifications presented by the person selling or pawning the item. 
(Code 1994, § 74-10) 
Sec. 12-264. - Identification required. 
All businesses licensed under this article shall, when receiving in pawn or in purchasing goods, require a proper identification, driver's license or military ID card or state-approved ID card containing a picture and showing positive identification of the person who is pawning, selling or bartering and shall verify the identification. A photograph or videotape of such person shall also be made. 
(Code 1994, § 74-11) 
Sec. 12-265. - Fingerprint required. 
Every business licensed under this article shall require every person from whom it accepts goods on pawn or purchase to place the fingerprint of his right index finger (if right index finger is missing, the next finger in line will be used) in ink on the front of the copy of the pawn or purchase ticket which is to be sent to the police department. 
(Code 1994, § 74-12) 
Sec. 12-266. - Retention period for purchased articles. 
Every business licensed under this article shall, unless sooner released to the owner, hold, on the premises designated in the license for doing business, every item required to be listed under section 12-260 for at least 15 days before disposing of the item by sale, transfer or shipment. This section shall not apply to purchases from licensed wholesalers in the normal course of business. 
(Code 1994, § 74-13) 
Sec. 12-267. - Retention period for pawned articles. 
Every business licensed under this article which takes goods on pawn shall hold such goods for at least 30 days, unless redeemed by the owner or on authority of the owner, before disposing of the goods by sale, transfer, shipment or otherwise. 
(Code 1994, § 74-14) 
Sec. 12-268. - Display of goods pledged or purchased. 
For a period of 15 days from the date of purchase and 30 days from the date of pledge, unless redeemed by or on authority of the person who pledged the goods, all goods purchased or pawned pursuant to this article and required to be listed under section 12-260 shall be kept on the premises designated in the license for doing business. Every item required to be kept on the premises under this section shall have attached to it either a copy of the form required in section 12-261 or the number of such form. Any person desiring to examine any merchandise shall first obtain a copy of a police department incident or stolen property report. Upon presentation of a copy of such report to any licensed dealer or employee and upon giving in writing to such dealer a full description of the stolen items sought, including all identifying characteristics, his name, address, signature, identification and incident or stolen property report number and issuing department, such individual shall be allowed to examine any merchandise of the type described on the premises. Such written information shall be kept in sequential, dated order in a permanent file or book. This record shall be kept in addition to all other records required in this article. 
(Code 1994, § 74-15) 
Sec. 12-269. - Alteration of articles. 
Any item required to be kept or displayed under sections 12-266 through 12-268 shall be kept in its original form as it existed when first purchased, and its physical characteristics shall not be altered in any material or immaterial manner. 
(Code 1994, § 74-16) 
Sec. 12-270. - Erasures, obliterations or changes in records. 
No person licensed under this article shall erase, obliterate, type over, write over or in any way cause the original entry on the records required under this article to become illegible. All pawn or purchase tickets filled out in error shall be sent to the police department in their numbered order along with daily reports and shall have the term "void" typed or written across the front. Such entry shall not be used to cause the original entry to be illegible. If an error is made and the ticket is still to be used, a single line shall be drawn through the incorrect entry. This line shall not cause the original entry to be illegible, and the correct information entry shall be made on the next available area. 
(Code 1994, § 74-17) 
Sec. 12-271. - Records maintained for four years. 
The record of each pawn or purchase transaction regulated by this article shall be maintained for a period of not less than four years from the date of the transaction. 
(Code 1994, § 74-18) 
Sec. 12-272. - Hours of operation. 
Every business licensed under this article shall close its establishment and cease transacting any business no later than 10:00 p.m. each day and shall not begin its operation and commence transacting business before 7:00 a.m. each day. 
(Code 1994, § 74-19) 
Sec. 12-273. - Dealing with minors. 
It shall be unlawful for any person licensed under this article to receive in pawn or in purchase any goods of any character or of any description from any person who has not attained the age of 17 years. 
(Code 1994, § 74-20) 
Sec. 12-274. - Transactions conducted outside building. 
No business transaction by any business licensed under this article shall be conducted outside the building designated as the normal place to conduct transactions. The term "business transaction" means any part of business including inspection or appraisal of any goods when it is possible for such goods to be taken inside the building where transactions normally are made (the term "possible" being used in the broadest sense), and no person other than a person possessing a license or employee permit shall be allowed to conduct any form of business transaction either inside the establishment or on any part of outside land area covered under address of the license. 
(Code 1994, § 74-21) 
Sec. 12-275. - Accepting articles with serial numbers removed, altered or obliterated. 
No business licensed under this article shall accept any article that has had the serial number altered, obliterated or removed from such article or which the person who is making the business transaction knows should have a serial number on it. Licensees shall immediately report any attempted business transactions of this nature to the police department. 
(Code 1994, § 74-22) 
Sec. 12-276. - Nonformed precious metals. 
It shall be unlawful for any person licensed under this article to purchase precious metals in a melted, smelted or nonformed state unless the purchase is from a registered dealer in precious metals. 
(Code 1994, § 74-23) 
Sec. 12-277. - Stolen items. 
Every person licensed under this article shall, immediately upon request, turn over to the police department every item believed by the police department to be a stolen item. The police department shall furnish a property receipt including a case number of recovery to the dealer surrendering such item. The item shall be returned to the licensee only after it has been determined that such item is not stolen. If it is determined that such item is stolen, it shall be returned to its lawful owner. 
(Code 1994, § 74-24) 
Sec. 12-278. - Access from separate business establishment. 
No business licensed under this article shall be designed or operated so as to allow immediate access to the business from any other business without first exiting the other business into a common or open area to which the public at large has access. 
(Code 1994, § 74-25) 
Secs. 12-279—12-304. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUSINESS LICENSE AND EMPLOYEE PERMIT 

Sec. 12-305. - License required. 
(a)  Every person doing business in the city as a pawnbroker or dealer in precious metals or gems, prior to commencing business, shall make proper application for and receive the appropriate business license as set forth in this division. 
(b)  No application for a license to do business as a pawnbroker or dealer in precious metals and gems shall be considered, approved or issued where the number of such licenses issued and in effect at the time of such application number one for each 5,000 residents according to the latest decennial census figures available. Licenses to pawnbrokers dealing exclusively with pawns of car titles shall not exceed one license for every 1,000 residents according to the latest decennial census figures available. In making this computation, fractions of population shall not be considered. 
(Code 1994, § 74-46) 
Sec. 12-306. - Employee permit. 
Each person authorized or allowed to work, whether or not for compensation, in any place of business covered under this division shall be considered an employee and must have an approved employee permit. This permit must be displayed along with the business license. 
(Code 1994, § 74-47) 
Sec. 12-307. - Application for license and permit. 
(a)  An applicant for a license or permit under this division shall file with the city clerk a written, sworn application on a form provided by the city clerk. The application shall be signed by the applicant if an individual, by the partner making application if a partnership and by the president if a corporation. The application shall show the following: 
(1)  The names of the principals, agents and employees of the applicant's business during the time that it is proposed that it will be carried on in the city; the local addresses of such persons while engaged in such business; the permanent addresses of such persons; the capacity in which such persons will act (as proprietor, agent, employee or otherwise); the name and the address of the person for whose account the business will be carried on, if any; and if a corporation under the laws of what state it is incorporated; 
(2)  The fingerprints of the principals, agents or employees of the applicant's business and other evidence which establishes to the satisfaction of the city clerk, subject to the approval of the mayor and council, the good character of such persons to carry on the business; 
(3)  The place in the city where it is proposed to carry on the applicant's business, the zoning district at such place and the length of time during which it is proposed that the business shall be conducted; 
(4)  The place, other than the permanent place of business of the applicant, where the applicant within the six months next preceding the date of the application conducted an itinerant business, stating the nature thereof and giving the post office and street address or any building or office in which such business was conducted; 
(5)  Whether or not the person having the management or supervision of the applicant's business has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or the violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of such offense and the punishment assessed therefor; 
(6)  Credentials from the person for which the applicant proposes to do business, authorizing the applicant to act as such representative; 
(7)  If the applicant is a corporation, whether or not: 
a.  Any shares in the corporation have been sold and if so to whom the shares were sold; and 
b.  Majority control of the corporation has been transferred in the preceding year; and 
(8)  Such other information as to the identity or character of the person having the management or supervision of the applicant's business or the method or plan of doing such business as the city clerk may deem proper to fulfill the purpose of this article in the protection of the public good. 
(b)  Every applicant for a license shall post with the city clerk a surety bond in favor of the city in the amount of $8,000.00, which bond shall not be accepted unless it is with a corporate surety licensed to do business in the state and unless it is conditioned that the applicant shall comply fully with all applicable provisions of federal, state and local laws, rules and regulations concerning the activity for which the applicant is to be licensed and that the property purchased is guaranteed to be in accordance with the specifications, standards and conditions represented to the purchaser by the applicant. A blanket bond otherwise meeting the requirements of this subsection shall be accepted. In lieu of posting the bond, the licensee may post cash. 
(c)  If any person shall be aggrieved by the conduct of any licensee and shall receive judgment against him therefor, such person may, after the return unsatisfied, either in whole or in part, of any execution issued upon the judgment, maintain an action in his own name upon the bond or letter of credit of the licensee in any court having jurisdiction of the amount of the judgment remaining unsatisfied. 
(d)  The application shall state the following: "It is unlawful for any person to make a false statement on this application." Any false statement made on the application form will be cause to revoke the license issued thereunder and also shall constitute a violation of city ordinances. 
(Code 1994, § 74-48) 
Sec. 12-308. - Fees. 
(a)  All businesses licensed under this division shall pay a designated license and permit fee: 
(1)  Pawn shops/dealers in precious metals or gems shall pay a license fee each calendar year. This fee shall include the initial registration of the named applicant. The annual license shall be in an amount as established by the mayor and council from time to time. 
(2)  Employee permit, per calendar year per application. The employee permit shall be in an amount as established by the mayor and council from time to time. 
(b)  Any co-owner, agent, employee or any other person authorized to transact business other than the licensee shall be required to have the employee permit for each license he operates or transacts business under. There shall be no proration or refund of any license fee. 
(Code 1994, § 74-49) 
Sec. 12-309. - Character qualifications. 
No license or employee permit required under this division shall be issued to continue, or be renewed for any person who conducts or is employed in a business in which such owner or employee has currently, or within five years of issuance or renewal, been convicted of or pled guilty or nolo contendere to any felony involving any federal or state offense or any federal or state misdemeanor involving theft-related offenses, alcohol, drugs or any crime of moral turpitude, and the licensee will submit the identity of all owners and employees to the city clerk on a continuing basis as changes occur. This information is to be forwarded to the police department, for the purpose of allowing a complete check in order that these character qualifications be fulfilled, prior to the issuance of or renewal of any license or permit issued. 
(Code 1994, § 74-50) 
Sec. 12-310. - Transferability. 
(a)  Transfer of license or permit. The license and permit issued under this division, regardless of whether issued to a person, firm or corporation, shall be transferrable as to location if the new location otherwise meets all of the qualifications required by this division. A fee as established from time to time by the mayor and council shall be required for all license transfers. 
(b)  Transfer of ownership interest. Any transfer of 25 percent or more of the ownership interest in a corporation which holds a license under this division shall be considered a new license application, and the transferee shall comply with this division as to application and issuance. Transfers of less than 25 percent ownership interest may be approved by the city clerk upon payment of the required transfer fee and proof that the transferee meets all standards of this article. 
(c)  Suspension or revocation of proceedings. In the event proceedings have been instituted against a license holder for possible suspension or revocation of the license, no transfer of such license shall be permitted to any other person, firm or corporation. 
(Code 1994, § 74-51) 
Sec. 12-311. - Inspection. 
As a condition of the granting of the license under this division, every licensee agrees to allow any duly authorized law enforcement officer, pursuant to his official duties, to be and remain on or about his premises without the formality of a warrant, provided the officer does not unduly interfere in the licensee's operation. 
(Code 1994, § 74-52) 
Secs. 12-312—12-340. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS, AND TRANSIENT MERCHANTS[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference— Peddlers and itinerant traders, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 12-341—12-368. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS 

Sec. 12-369. - Registration; permit. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, attempt to sell, take order for future delivery or promote any product, picture, map, book, magazine, household device, equipment or goods at any residence in the city without first registering with the chief of police. The person shall provide the chief with a recognizable photograph of himself and shall pay a regulatory fee for a 30-day permit. The regulatory fee will be in an amount as established by the mayor and council from time to time. 
(Code 1972, § 14-1; Code 1994, § 78-1; Ord. No. 99-01, § 1(78-1), 6-14-1999) 
Sec. 12-370. - Notification of division provisions. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police to provide a copy of the ordinance from which this division is derived to any person to whom he issues a permit under section 12-369. 
(Code 1972, § 14-5; Code 1994, § 78-2) 
Sec. 12-371. - Hours of operation. 
It shall be unlawful for any person holding a valid permit under section 12-369 to make any calls except between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. No calls shall be made on Sunday. 
(Code 1972, § 14-2; Code 1994, § 78-3) 
Sec. 12-372. - Calls prohibited on certain property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person holding a valid permit under section 12-369 to make a call at any residence where the owner or any person residing therein has posted a sign reading as follows: "No Solicitors." 
(Code 1972, § 14-3; Code 1994, § 78-4) 
Sec. 12-373. - Failure to leave premises upon request. 
It shall be unlawful for any person holding a valid permit under section 12-369 to fail to immediately leave the premises of any person when requested to do so. 
(Code 1972, § 14-4; Code 1994, § 78-5) 
Secs. 12-374—12-404. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference— Transient Merchant Act of Georgia, O.C.G.A. § 43-46-1 et seq. 

Sec. 12-405. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this division, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Merchandise means any samples, model goods, wares, or merchandise sold or offered for sale by a transient merchant. 
Transient merchant. 
(1)  The term "transient merchant" means any person, firm, or corporation, as principal or agent, or both, which is not a regular retail or wholesale merchant with a permanent place of business in the city, but rather one who displays samples, model goods, wares, or merchandise in any lot, building, room, vehicle, trailer or structure of any kind, whether fixed or mobile, for the purpose of retail sales and the securing of orders for the retail sale of such items or items of like kind or quality for the immediate or future delivery. 
(2)  The term "transient merchant" shall not include any person, firm, or corporation which: 
a.  Sells agriculture or forestry products; 
b.  Makes house-to-house or personal calls for the purpose of displaying samples or taking orders for shipment directly from a manufacturer; 
c.  Conducts business at any industry or association trade show; or 
d.  Sells items at a rummage, garage, antique, or similar sale when such person, firm, or corporation is a resident of the city or has a permanent place of business within the city and such sale has been authorized by city permit. 
(Code 1994, § 100-1; Ord. No. 95-3, § 1, 9-11-1995) 
Sec. 12-406. - Registration; permit. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to act as a transient merchant within the city without first registering with the city manager. Any person desiring to operate as a transient merchant within the city shall make application for a permit in writing and file the application with the city manager. The application shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name and permanent address of the transient merchant; 
(2)  The name and permanent address of the transient merchant's registered agent or office; 
(3)  The type of business to be conducted, including a description of the merchandise to be sold by the transient merchant; 
(4)  The form of the transient merchant's business (i.e., corporation, partnership, sole proprietorship), including the date and state of incorporation, when said transient merchant is a corporation; 
(5)  A recognizable photograph of the transient merchant and any person who will be working with the transient merchant within the city; 
(6)  Documentation in writing from the owner of the property where the transient merchant intends to be located, by lease or otherwise, stating that the transient merchant has permission from the owner to transact business on the property; 
(7)  A map or diagram indicating the parking to be used by customers of the transient merchant. Any such parking must not diminish the available parking for the underlying use of the property below that required by city ordinances; 
(8)  A copy of a liability insurance policy acceptable to the mayor and council and providing liability insurance in an amount as established by the mayor and council from time to time; 
(9)  A bond in an amount payable to the city so as to provide recourse to the city in the event that a complaint is made by a citizen of defective merchandise sold by the transient merchant and the citizen has no recourse against the transient merchant. The bond will be good for a period through six months for an amount as established by the mayor and council from time to time; 
(10)  A description of the lot, building, room, vehicle, trailer or structure of any kind, whether fixed or mobile, in which the transient merchant intends to conduct business within the city; and 
(11)  A set of fingerprints prepared by the chief of police for the transient merchant and all agents or employees who will sell merchandise on behalf of the transient merchant within the city. 
(b)  The application shall be made under oath and the giving of false information shall result in the revocation of any permit issued in reliance thereon. 
(c)  A permit fee must be filed contemporaneously with the application for a 30-day permit. The permit fee will be in an amount as established by the mayor and council from time to time. 
(d)  No more than two permits shall be issued to any transient merchant in any calendar year. 
(Code 1994, § 100-2; Ord. No. 95-3, § 1, 9-11-1995) 
Sec. 12-407. - Hours of operation. 
It shall be unlawful for any person holding a valid permit under section 12-406 to conduct any business or sell any merchandise except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. 
(Code 1994, § 100-3; Ord. No. 95-3, § 1, 9-11-1995) 
Sec. 12-408. - Location of business; signs. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any transient merchant to conduct business or to be located on any city-owned rights-of-way or to be situated so as to block or impede traffic or interfere with traffic by blocking vision at intersections. 
(b)  The location of the business of a transient merchant must comply with all commercial setback requirements as provided in chapter 42, pertaining to zoning. Establishment of sales and/or display areas within required front yards is specifically prohibited. The parking required for all businesses shall also be provided by transient merchants and such parking shall not diminish the required parking of any business also located on the lot or parcel utilized by the transient merchant. 
(c)  No signs or other visual displays shall be posted by a transient merchant without first obtaining a sign permit as provided in this Code. 
(Code 1994, § 100-4; Ord. No. 95-3, § 1, 9-11-1995) 
Sec. 12-409. - Business operations. 
(a)  All merchandise must be displayed by the transient merchant in a neat and orderly fashion. 
(b)  All merchandise displayed by the transient merchant must be secure from wind, rain, or other inclement weather. In the event that merchandise is not under a cover or in an enclosed structure, all merchandise must be removed and safely secured from the rain, wind or other inclement weather. 
(c)  All merchandise must be in a secured location during non-business hours. In the event that a transient merchant does not have a building, structure, or vehicle in which the merchandise can be locked, all merchandise must be removed from the property during non-business hours. 
(Code 1994, § 100-5; Ord. No. 95-3, § 1, 9-11-1995) 
Sec. 12-410. - Inspection authority. 
The chief of police or his agent shall have the right to enter onto the property where the transient merchant is conducting business, at reasonable times, to inspect the property and business operation of the transient merchant for compliance with this division. 
(Code 1994, § 100-6; Ord. No. 95-3, § 1, 9-11-1995) 
Sec. 12-411. - Penalties. 
(a)  Upon conviction or the entering of a plea of nolo contendere to any citation under this division, the person cited shall be subject to penalties set out in section 1-8. 
(b)  In addition to the criminal penalties prescribed by subsection (a) of this section, upon conviction or plea of guilty or nolo contendere, the permit of the transient merchant shall be revoked. No new permit shall issue to a transient merchant whose permit has been forfeited within the city for a period of 12 months. Revocation of permits shall be accomplished by action of the mayor and council following notice and opportunity to be heard. 
(Code 1994, § 100-7; Ord. No. 95-3, § 1, 9-11-1995) 
Chapter 14 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Charge imposed on each wireless enhanced 911 telecommunications connection. 
A wireless enhanced 911 charge is hereby imposed upon each wireless telecommunications connection subscribed to by subscribers whose billing address is within the jurisdiction of the city at a rate per month per wireless connection provided to each telephone subscriber. The amount of the rate charged shall be the maximum allowed under state law. 
(Res. No. 99-02, 6-14-1999) 
Secs. 14-2—14-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CIVIL EMERGENCIES 

Sec. 14-21. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Emergency management means the preparation for and the carrying out of all emergency and disaster functions, other than those functions for which military forces or state and federal agencies are primarily responsible, to prevent, minimize and repair injury and damage resulting from emergencies or disasters or the imminent threat thereof of man-made or natural origin caused by enemy attack, sabotage, acts of domestic or international terrorism, civil disturbance, fire, flood, earthquake, wind, storm, wave action, oil spill or other water contamination requiring emergency action to avert danger or damage, epidemic, air contamination, blight, drought, infestation, explosion, riot or other hostile action, radiological action, or other causes. These functions include, without limitation, firefighting services; police services; emergency medical services; medical and health services; rescue; engineering; warning services; communications; protection against the effects of radiological, chemical, biological, and other special weapons to include weapons of mass destruction; evacuation of persons from stricken areas; consequence management functions to include victim services; emergency welfare services; emergency transportation; plant protection; shelter; temporary restoration of public utility services; and other functions related to civilian population, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to total emergency and disaster preparedness for carrying out such functions. 
(b)  The definitions set forth in O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3 ("Emergency Management—Definitions"), shall be effective as definitions of the words, terms and phrases used in this article. All words, terms and phrases used herein, other than those specifically defined elsewhere in this article, shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3, and shall have the same scope and effect that the same words, terms and phrases have where used in O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3. 
(Code 1994, § 26-26; Res. No. 91-4, § I, 10-14-1991) 
Sec. 14-22. - Construction of article. 
This article shall be construed liberally in order to effectuate its purpose. 
(Code 1994, § 26-27; Res. No. 91-4, § VII, 10-14-1991) 
Sec. 14-23. - Penalties. 
Any person violating this article or any rule, order or regulation made pursuant to this article shall, upon conviction, be punished for committing a misdemeanor as provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1994, § 26-28; Res. No. 91-4, § VI, 10-14-1991) 
Sec. 14-24. - Agency established; office of emergency management director. 
(a)  In agreement with the governing officials of the cities within the county, the establishment of the county emergency management agency is acknowledged and approved. 
(b)  The chairperson of the board of county commissioners, with concurrence of the mayors of cities within the county, shall nominate for appointment by the governor a director of emergency management for the entire county and participating cities located therein. When appointed, the emergency management director is charged with the following duties: 
(1)  Represent the governing officials of the county and cities therein on matters pertaining to emergency management. 
(2)  Assist county and city officials in organizing county and city departments for emergency operations. 
(3)  Develop, in conjunction with county and city departments, the county plan for emergency functions set forth in section 14-21. Such plan will be in consonance with the state natural disaster operations plan and nuclear emergency operations plan and shall be submitted to the governing officials of the county and the cities therein for approval and thence to the state emergency management agency for approval. 
(4)  Maintain the emergency management agency and carry out the day-to-day administration of the county and city emergency program, including the submission of required reports to the state emergency management agency. 
(5)  Submit reports as required by governing officials in keeping with good management practices (e.g., financial, daily activity, etc.). 
(6)  Obtain, with the authority of governing officials, a facility to be used as the county emergency operating center. 
(7)  Coordinate the activities of the county emergency operating center staff during periods of an undeclared emergency and under the supervision of county governing officials. 
(Code 1994, § 26-29; Res. No. 91-4, § II, 10-14-1991) 
Sec. 14-25. - County emergency management agency. 
(a)  The county emergency management department shall be established around existing county and city departments and agencies. The emergency functions listed in section 14-21 are assigned as set forth in the functional responsibility assignment, attachment C, of the county emergency operations plan and as attached to the resolution from which this article is derived. 
(b)  Heads of departments listed are responsible for developing appropriate annexes to the local emergency operations plan (EOP) for their assigned function, as listed in attachment C of the emergency operating plan reference in subsection (a) of this section. Such plans will be submitted through the emergency management director/coordinator to the county board of commissioners and city mayors for inclusion in the local emergency operations plan. 
(Code 1994, § 26-30; Res. No. 91-4, § III, 10-14-1991) 
Sec. 14-26. - Powers during emergency or disaster. 
If a manmade or natural disaster, actual enemy attack upon the United States or any other emergency occurs which may affect the lives and property of the citizens of the county and participating cities, the chairperson of the county board of commissioners, jointly with the mayors of the affected cities or, in their absences, their legally appointed designees, may determine that an emergency or disaster exists and thereafter shall have and may exercise for such period as such emergency or disaster exists or continues the power to: 
(1)  Enforce all rules, laws and regulations relating to emergency management and to assume direct operational control over all emergency management resources; 
(2)  Seize or take for temporary use any private property for the protection of the public; 
(3)  Sell, lend, give or distribute all or any such property or supplies among the inhabitants of the county and maintain a strict accounting of property or supplies distributed and for funds received for such property or supplies; and 
(4)  Perform and exercise such other functions and duties and take such emergency actions as may be necessary to promote and secure the safety, protection and well-being of the inhabitants of the county. 
(Code 1994, § 26-31; Res. No. 91-4, § IV, 10-14-1991) 
Sec. 14-27. - Volunteers. 
All persons, other than officers and employees of the county and cities therein, performing emergency functions pursuant to this article shall serve with or without compensation. While engaged in such emergency functions, duly assigned volunteers shall have the same immunities as county and city officers and employees. 
(Code 1994, § 26-32; Res. No. 91-4, § V, 10-14-1991) 
Chapter 16 - ENVIRONMENT 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 16-1—16-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DRAINING OF MOTOR VEHICLE FLUIDS 

Sec. 16-19. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Fluid includes but is not limited to oil, lubricants, transmission fluid, antifreeze, gasoline, brake fluid, windshield washer antifreeze and detergent, Freon, power steering fluid, battery acid and like substances. 
(Code 1994, § 38-26; Ord. No. 91-7, § 2, 9-9-1991) 
Sec. 16-20. - Applicability of article. 
This article applies to all businesses licensed in the city that buy, sell or service motor vehicles, whether such businesses are identified as service stations, automobile dealers, salvage dealers, auto auctions or by some other classification. This article further applies to all individuals within the city who drain fluids from motor vehicles or motor vehicle parts. 
(Code 1994, § 38-27; Ord. No. 91-7, § 1, 9-9-1991) 
Sec. 16-21. - Penalty for violation. 
Any person violating this article shall, upon conviction or upon the entering of a plea of guilty or nolo contendere, be punished as provided in section 1-8. Any owner or manager who participates or directs the violation of this article shall likewise be subject to such criminal penalties. 
(Code 1994, § 38-28; Ord. No. 91-7, § 6, 9-9-1991) 
Sec. 16-22. - Suspension or revocation of license for violations. 
In addition to the penalties referred to in section 16-21, the business license of any business under this article shall be subject to suspension or revocation for repeated violations of this article. As used in this section, the term "repeated violations" means three or more prosecutions which result in convictions or pleas of guilty or nolo contendere to violation of this article or any single instance of violation of this article following notice by the city that past violations have been observed and directing that all such violating conditions cease immediately. 
(Code 1994, § 38-29; Ord. No. 91-7, § 7, 9-9-1991) 
Sec. 16-23. - Compliance. 
The owner and manager of a business to which this article applies shall each be responsible for ensuring full compliance with this article. 
(Code 1994, § 38-30; Ord. No. 91-7, § 5, 9-9-1991) 
Sec. 16-24. - Discharge of fluids prohibited. 
(a)  No business to which this article pertains shall permit the discharge, leaking, dumping or spilling of any fluid from a motor vehicle or from a motor vehicle part onto the ground or onto any paved, graveled or cemented surface. 
(b)  No individual, whether acting within the scope of his employment or on his own, shall permit the discharge, leaking, dumping or spilling of any fluid from a motor vehicle or from a motor vehicle part onto the ground or onto any paved, graveled or cemented surface. 
(Code 1994, § 38-31; Ord. No. 91-7, § 3, 9-9-1991) 
Sec. 16-25. - Disposal of fluids. 
All fluids to be drained from motor vehicles or from motor vehicle parts shall be captured, containerized and disposed of by such methods as approved by state and federal environmental rules. 
(Code 1994, § 38-32; Ord. No. 91-7, § 4, 9-9-1991) 
Secs. 16-26—16-53. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NOISE 

Sec. 16-54. - Unlawful noise. 
(a)  Enumeration. It shall be unlawful for any person to make or cause to be made any loud, raucous or unusual noise which interferes with the comfort, repose and peace of reasonable persons on property adjacent to the property from which the noise originates or which endangers the health or safety of others within the corporate limits. Such noises as contemplated by this section shall include but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  The sounding of any horn, whistle, Klaxon, siren, audible signal device, bell or other similar device when such sound is not made in connection with a necessary alert, emergency situation or traffic warning. 
(2)  The discharge into open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, diesel engine, boat motor, motor vehicle, truck, motorcycle, motorbike, motor scooter, go-cart or other vehicle except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud and explosive noises therefrom. 
(3)  The operation of a radio, phonograph or television at a volume which carries the sound beyond the boundaries of the premises on which such is operated. 
(4)  Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling or singing, except in places of worship. 
(5)  The keeping of any animal or fowl that makes a frequent or continuing sound. 
(6)  The use of any musical instrument or drum. 
(7)  The use of or operation of any mechanical device, blower, hydraulic device, machine or equipment. 
(8)  The erection, demolition, alteration or repair of buildings between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(9)  The operation of grading or excavation equipment between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(10)  The shouting, crying, ringing of bells or other sounds made or caused to be made by peddlers, hawkers and vendors. 
(11)  The dragging or hauling of any object which creates noise. 
(b)  Criteria. 
(1)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this subsection (b), shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection (b)(1), except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
"A" band level means the total sound level of all noise as measured with a sound level meter using the "A" weighing network. The unit is the dbA. 
Band pressure level means a specified frequency band; the sound pressure level for the sound contained within the restricted band. The reference pressure shall be specified. 
Cycle means the complete sequence of values of a periodic quantity which occurs during a period. 
Decibel (db) means a unit of level which denotes the ratio between two quantities that are proportional to power; the number of decibels corresponding to the ratio of two amounts of power is ten times the logarithm to the base ten of this ratio. 
Frequency, of a function periodic in time, means the reciprocal of the primitive period. The unit is the cycle per unit time and shall be specified. 
Microbar means a unit of pressure commonly used in acoustics which is equal to one dyne per square centimeter. 
Period, with reference to a periodic quantity, means the smallest increment of time for which the function repeats itself. 
Periodic quantity means an oscillating quantity, the values of which recur for equal increments of time. 
Sound analyzer means a device for measuring the band pressure level or pressure spectrum level of a sound as a function of frequency. 
Sound level meter means an instrument, including a microphone, an amplifier, an output meter, and frequency weighing networks, for the measurement of noise and sound levels in a specified manner. 
Sound pressure level means, in decibels of a sound, 20 times the logarithm to the base ten of the ratio of the pressure of this sound to the reference pressure, which reference pressure shall be explicitly stated. 
Spectrum, of a function of time, means a description of its resolution into components, each of a different frequency. 
(2)  Noise criteria table. 
TABLE 1 
DAYTIME NOISE CRITERION  (7:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m.) 

 
NIGHTTIME NOISE CRITERION  (10:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m.) 

 
(3)  Machinery, fans, air conditioning in residential zones. It shall be unlawful for any person within any residential zone of the city or within a radius of 500 feet therefrom to utilize any fixed and generally operating machinery or equipment, including but not limited to pumps, fans, air conditioning apparatus, and swimming pool equipment, in such a manner as to create in any inhabited area noise levels at the adjoining property line exceeding those shown in Table 1 in subsection (b)(2) of this section. 
(4)  Additional criteria. 
a.  The octave band spectra are the basic criteria. The "A" band level is given for a rapid spot check. 
b.  The sound levels are to be measured at the property line, five feet above ground level. 
c.  In the case of an elevated or directional sound source, compliance with the noise limits is to be maintained at any elevation at the boundary. 
d.  If the noise contains pure tone components (hum, whine, whistle, screech or like sounds), the limits are to be lowered five decibels for any octave band containing such tones. 
e.  If the noise is of an impulsive or transient character (hammering or clanking, or the like), the limit levels are to be lowered by five decibels. 
f.  If the noise is steady in character but of short duration, such as steam or air blasts, the limit levels may be increased only during daytime operation (7:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m.) by amounts depending on duration, as follows: 
1.  One minute per hour ..... 5 db 
2.  Ten seconds per ten minutes ..... 10 db 
3.  Two seconds per ten minutes ..... 15 db 
g.  If the noise is of short duration, there will be no increase above the basic limits during nighttime operations. 
h.  Compliances with the noise criteria shown in Table 1 in subsection (b)(2) of this section shall be determined by utilizing instrumentation which meets the following United States of America Standards Institute publications: 
1.  S1.4-1961, "Specifications for General Purpose Sound Level Meters." 
2.  S1.11-1966, "Specifications for Octave, Half-Octave and Third-Octave Band Filter Sets." 
(5)  Commercial zones. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any generally operating fixed or moveable equipment of a commercial or manufacturing nature in such a manner as to create noise levels exceeding 70 dbA measured at the nearest commercially zoned boundary. 
(Code 1972, § 8-1; Code 1994, § 38-91) 
Sec. 16-55. - Sound amplification devices. 
(a)  Nothing in section 16-54 shall be construed to prohibit the operation of a sound amplification device, whether stationary or attached to a vehicle, provided that the device is operated under the terms and conditions set out in this section. 
(b)  If any person or organization desires permission to operate a sound amplification device for the purpose of advertising, soliciting, attracting attention, announcing a sporting event or exercising the right of free speech as guaranteed by the United States Constitution, he shall be allowed to do so only after he has applied for and received a permit from the mayor and council. Such operation without such permit is declared unlawful. 
(c)  An application for a permit to operate a sound amplification device shall be in writing, filed with the city clerk, and shall set forth the equipment to be used, the place or route to be followed, the intensity of sound level expected, the purpose of such use and the days and hours such use is desired. 
(d)  The mayor and council shall consider such application at its next regular meeting and shall exercise its discretion after considering all pertinent facts. The mayor and council may require the applicant to demonstrate the equipment before issuing the permit. The mayor and council shall not withhold a permit so as to deprive any person of his constitutional rights, but shall have the right to control sound and noise emitted in the city for the general health and welfare of its citizens. Each permit issued shall be issued for a specific term. 
(Code 1972, § 8-2; Code 1994, § 38-92) 
Secs. 16-56—16-83. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SOIL EROSION, SEDIMENTATION AND POLLUTION CONTROL[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2016-8, § 1(exh. A), adopted December 22, 2016, repealed the former article IV, §§ 16-84—16-88, and enacted a new article IV as set out herein. The former article IV pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1994, §§ 38-141—38-145, 38-166, and 38-167; Ord. No. 90-002, §§ 1—5 , adopted May 14, 1990; and Ord. No. 91-4, §§ 1—5, adopted August 12, 1991. 

Sec. 16-84. - Title. 
This article will be known as "The City of Lake City's Soil Erosion, Sedimentation and Pollution Control Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 2016-8, § 1(exh. A), 12-22-2016) 
Sec. 16-85. - Definitions. 
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article, unless otherwise specifically stated. 
Best management practices (BMPs) means sound conservation and engineering practices to prevent and minimize erosion and resultant sedimentation, which are consistent with, and no less stringent than, those practices contained in the Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia published by the commission as of January 1 of the year in which the land-disturbing activity was permitted. 
Board means the board of natural resources. 
Buffer means the area of land immediately adjacent to the banks of state waters in its natural state of vegetation, which facilitates the protection of water quality and aquatic habitat. 
Certified personnel means a person who has successfully completed the appropriate certification course approved by the state soil and water conservation commission. 
Coastal marshlands shall have the same meaning as in O.C.G.A. § 12-5-282. 
Commission means The Georgia Soil and Water Conservation Commission (GSWCC). 
CPESC means certified professional in erosion and sediment control with current certification by EnviroCert, Inc., which is also referred to as CPESC or CPESC, Inc. 
Cut means a portion of land surface or area from which earth has been removed or will be removed by excavation; the depth below original ground surface to the excavated surface. Also known as excavation. 
Department (DNR) means the Georgia Department of Natural Resources. 
Design professional means a professional licensed by the state in the field of: engineering, architecture, landscape architecture, forestry, geology, or land surveying; or a person that is a certified professional in erosion and sediment control (CPESC) with a current certification by EnviroCert, Inc. Design professionals shall practice in a manner that complies with applicable state law governing professional licensure. 
Director means the director of the environmental protection division or an authorized representative. 
District means The Clayton County Soil and Water Conservation District. 
Division means the environmental protection division (EPD) of the department of natural resources.
