(1)  To provide residential subdivision regulations which permit and encourage flexibility of design in order to preserve environmentally sensitive areas and create efficient uses of the land; 
(2)  To preserve open space and unique or sensitive natural resources, such as groundwater, floodplains, wetlands, streams, steep slopes, woodlands, wildlife habitats, historic features and unique topography; 
(3)  To permit clustering of houses and structures on less environmentally sensitive soils which will reduce the amount or infrastructure, including paved surfaces, utilities, earthwork and other land disturbing activities; 
(4)  To reduce erosion and sedimentation by minimizing land disturbance and removal of vegetation in residential developments; 
(5)  To conserve a portion of the otherwise developable property as open space in perpetuity. This option is not necessarily intended to allow an applicant to conserve only the portion of the tract that is already not buildable due to factors such as steep slopes, wetlands, or land adjacent to undesirable areas such as landfills or livestock farming; 
(6)  To promote interconnected greenways and corridors throughout the city; 
(7)  To promote linking of greenways and corridors between the city and neighboring jurisdictions; 
(8)  To encourage interactions of persons living in the resulting residential community by clustering houses and orienting them closer to the street, providing public gathering places and encouraging use of parks and community facilities as focal points in the neighborhood; 
(9)  To encourage street designs that reduce traffic speeds and reliance on main arteries; 
(10)  To incorporate aesthetic design standards that will increase the value of the neighborhood; 
(11)  To conserve scenic views and reduce perceived density by promoting views of open space from arterial and collector roads; and 
(12)  To promote other purposes of the zoning ordinance, subdivision regulations, soil erosion and sediment control ordinance and other ordinances and policies of the city. 
(Ord. No. 07-05, § 1(art. XII(38-570)), 5-14-2007) 
Sec. 16-580. - Permitted locations and districts. 
(a)  Conservation subdivisions, as defined herein, are permitted within the all one-family residential zoning districts. The zoning administrator shall receive all applications for a conservation subdivision on such form as prescribed by the zoning administrator. An application shall include a proposal which will demonstrate compliance with all applicable county regulations regarding the approval of subdivisions as well as the regulations set forth in this article, except as otherwise authorized by this section. The regulations found in this section are optional insofar as it shall be the responsibility of the property owner to determine if conservation development is appropriate for use on a particular piece of property and thereafter apply for approval. 
(b)  An applicant shall tender a conceptual plan to the zoning administrator who shall make a preliminary determination of the general outlines of the subdivision. If the conceptual plan is approved, the applicant will then prepare a preliminary plat, which, if consistent with the conceptual plan, shall serve as the plan for the proposed development. 
(c)  The mayor and council shall have final approval or denial of all applications for conservation subdivisions. Such applications shall be processed in the same manner as other applications for zoning amendments are processed. In making such decisions, the mayor and council shall be guided by the standards set forth in section 16-579. The permitted uses allowed shall be the same as those listed in chapter 42, pertaining to zoning. 
(Ord. No. 07-05, § 1(art. XII(38-571)), 5-14-2007) 
Sec. 16-581. - Dimensional requirements for conservation subdivisions. 
The development standards for conservation subdivisions shall be as follows: 
(1)  The minimum lot size shall be 7,000 square feet. 
(2)  The minimum front setback shall be 20 feet from the property line, unless otherwise approved by mayor and council. 
(3)  The minimum side yard shall be the minimum required by the city fire code. 
(4)  The minimum rear yard setback shall be 25 feet from the rear property line. 
(5)  The minimum lot width shall be 70 feet, unless otherwise approved by mayor and council. 
(6)  The minimum house size shall be the same as required by chapter 42, pertaining to zoning. 
(7)  The minimum access easement width to open space shall be ten feet. 
(Ord. No. 07-05, § 1(art. XII(38-572)), 5-14-2007; Ord. No. 2016-4, § 1, 4-11-2016) 
Sec. 16-582. - Density restrictions. 
The maximum gross density of development in this district shall be based on the zoning district in which the property is located, except as modified elsewhere in this article. Further, the maximum gross density of development shall be based upon the gross acreage before the same is reduced by the 25 percent open space requirement. 
(Ord. No. 07-05, § 1(art. XII(38-573)), 5-14-2007) 
Sec. 16-583. - Subdivision design. 
Proposed conservation subdivisions shall be processed in the same manner as a standard subdivision plat is processed. An approved final plat shall have an additional letter "C," symbolizing the use of conservation design standards, affixed after the original zoning designation listing. Conservation subdivisions to be considered for approval shall meet the following minimum design standards: 
(1)  A minimum of 25 percent of the total land area (open space) shall be permanently protected as described elsewhere in this article. A minimum 20 percent of the total protected land area shall be otherwise suitable for development, be located substantially throughout the subdivision, and adjoin as many lots as is reasonably practical. The land area within any buffer required in subsections (4) and (5) of this section and land in utility and right-of-way easements may be included in calculating the minimum 25 percent open space requirement. 
(2)  All homes must have, at least, all front facades constructed with brick, stone or stucco, or a combination thereof. 
(3)  No vinyl siding, except for eaves and soffits, shall be used. All exterior surface facades, except for eaves and soffits, shall be constructed with a masonry-based material. 
(4)  A 50-foot buffer shall be maintained along all arterial streets and a 25-foot buffer shall be maintained along all collector streets. The buffer shall be natural, planted vegetation, and/or earthen berm, as approved by the zoning administrator; provided, however, that a minimum of a 25-foot vegetated buffer shall be maintained along all external streets. 
(5)  A 75-foot undisturbed buffer shall be maintained on each side of all perennial streams as may otherwise be required by the appropriate state regulatory agency. All buffers should be expanded to include wetlands, steep slopes or the 100-year floodplain. At least part of the buffer must be maintained with native vegetation. 
(6)  All dedications, easements, or other specific measures required to be performed to meet the regulations set forth in this section shall be shown on a final recordable plat prior to the issuance of a building permit on any lot of the subdivision. 
(7)  Front, side and rear yards, where disturbed, shall be sodded. 
(8)  No rear yard fences shall be erected across any drainage or access easements. 
(9)  The minimum pavement width for streets shall be 22 feet. 
(10)  The minimum right-of-way width shall be 43 feet. 
(11)  The minimum width for sidewalks shall be four feet. 
(12)  Sidewalks shall generally slope toward front yards rather than roadways. 
(13)  Unless otherwise approved by mayor and council, sidewalks are required to be constructed on both sides of the street. 
(14)  The maximum driveway widths shall be as follows: nine feet (one lane), 18 feet (two lanes). 
(15)  Shared driveways may be permitted with approval of mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 07-05, § 1(art. XII(38-574)), 5-14-2007; Ord. No. 2016-4, § 2, 4-11-2016) 
Sec. 16-584. - Conservation protection implementation. 
An applicant for a conservation subdivision development shall submit a written management plan for the project and its open space areas prior to the approval of the final plat. The management plan shall include: 
(1)  Provisions for the use, restrictions of use, ownership, maintenance and perpetual preservation of the open space areas; 
(2)  Allocation of responsibility and establishing guidelines for the maintenance and operation of the open space and any facilities located thereon. These guidelines must include provisions for ongoing maintenance and for long-term capital improvements if any; 
(3)  Estimates of the costs and requirements needed for maintenance and operation of, and insurance for, the open space and an outline of the means by which such funding will be obtained or provided; 
(4)  Provisions for the open space required herein to be permanently protected in perpetuity by a conservation easement conveyed to the city prior to the sale of the first lot in such subdivision. The conservation easement shall be created subject to the provisions of article 1 of chapter 10 of title 44 or the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, which is known as the "Georgia Uniform Conservation Easement Act" (O.C.G.A. § 44-10-1 et seq., enacted by Ga. L. 1192, p. 2227, § 1). All such conservation easements shall provide for enforcement rights vested in the city, or in any other party approved by the city manager, and shall provide that the conservation easement may not be terminated or otherwise modified without the consent of all entities having either a property right or enforcement right therein; 
(5)  The open space areas shall be owned and maintained in accordance with the following criteria, provided that the record title to the property and the conservation easement shall be held by different entities: 
a.  Record title may be held by: 
1.  Equal share of undivided interest by each lot owner; 
2.  The homeowners' association; or 
3.  Other entity or arrangement approved by the city manager. 
b.  Conservation easement may be held by: 
1.  The city; or 
2.  Other entity approved by the city manager, qualified to be a holder under the Georgia Uniform 1 Conservation Easement Act. 
c.  Maintenance shall be assumed by: 
1.  Homeowners' association; or 
2.  Other entity approved by the city manager. 
(6)  Homeowners' association. In all cases, a homeowners' association shall be established. Membership shall be mandatory for all lot owners in the development and their successors, and the homeowners' association shall have the power to file liens to collect dues and assessments. The homeowners' association shall be formed under the provisions of article 6 of chapter 3 of title 44 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, which is known as the "Georgia Property Owners' Association Act" (O.C.G.A. § 44-3-220 et seq., enacted by Ga. 1994, p. 1879, § 1), and shall contain provisions for the automatic extension of the initial term, and subsequent terms, as allowed in the Act. 
(Ord. No. 07-05, § 1(art. XII(38-575)), 5-14-2007; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 9, 4-19-2018) 
Sec. 16-585. - Standards for determining open space. 
(a)  The minimum area of open space preserved shall be determined by multiplying the total acreage of all lands included in the development by 0.25. The result shall constitute the minimum amount of area that must be preserved as open space. 
(b)  Physiographic characteristics. The types of land area included in the open space may include the following: 
(1)  Floodprone areas, floodplains, and floodway; 
(2)  Wetlands; 
(3)  Ponds, lakes, stream and river channels, including buffer zones of approximately 100 feet or more (but never less than 25 feet) from the top of the streambanks on both sides; 
(4)  Waters of the state; 
(5)  Wellhead protection zones; 
(6)  Slopes 30 percent and steeper; 
(7)  Areas with shallow bedrock; 
(8)  Areas and soils which, when disturbed, are prone to excessive erosion; 
(9)  Prime views and vistas; 
(10)  Areas of historical or archeological significance; 
(11)  Cemeteries; and 
(12)  Other similar areas which are less suitable for development. 
(c)  The open space should be designed to be, in part, an integrated part of the project rather than an isolated element. The entire project should include elements of design and development that make at least a part of the open space an amenity to the development. 
(d)  The amenity portions of the open space should be designed to be directly or easily accessible to the largest practicable number of lots within the subdivision. Non-adjoining lots shall be provided with safe, convenient access (minimum of ten feet) to the open space. 
(e)  Where practicable open space areas shall also be configured to provide a buffer between adjoining property outside the conservation subdivision and the home sites within the subdivision. Excepting approved fences and signs, a 50-foot setback shall be maintained between structures and the exterior boundaries of the subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 07-05, § 1(art. XII(38-576)), 5-14-2007) 
Sec. 16-586. - Permitted uses of open space. 
(a)  Uses of open space may include the following: 
(1)  Conservation of natural, archeological or historical resources; 
(2)  Meadows, woodlands, wetlands, wildlife corridors, game preserves, or similar conservation-oriented areas; 
(3)  Walking or bicycle trails; 
(4)  Soccer, baseball, football, or track fields, scattered small, landscaped parks, landscaped traffic circles and islands, pools and related structures, clubhouses and related structures, tennis courts or golf courses, or community gardens; 
(5)  Other conservation-oriented uses if approved by the mayor and council. 
(b)  Non-permitted uses of open space include the following: 
(1)  Paved roads and paved parking lots, except as may be approved otherwise by the mayor and council. 
(2)  Other uses inconsistent with the purposes of these regulations and the zoning regulations set forth in chapter 42, and the purposes of this article, as determined by the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 07-05, § 1(art. XII(38-577)), 5-14-2007) 
Sec. 16-587. - Quality construction density bonuses. 
(a)  Prior to the approval of the final plat, the subdivider may choose to implement construction standards cumulatively, as listed in subsection (b) of this section, and receive the appropriate density bonus. The maximum total of all density bonuses used shall not exceed 35 percent. The density bonus percentage shall be applied to the density (units per acre) requirements as set by the mayor and council. Quality construction standards implemented by the subdivider shall be noted as a requirement on the final plat. 
(b)  Allowable density bonuses include the following: 
(1)  Sidewalks installed on both sides of internal streets, and installation of sidewalks along external abutting streets shall merit a six percent density bonus. 
(2)  Full front-side brick, stone, or stucco facade (or a combination thereof) on all homes in the subdivision shall receive a six percent density bonus. 
(3)  Full all-side brick, stone, or stucco facade (or a combination thereof) on all homes in the subdivision shall receive a ten percent density bonus. 
(4)  All homes, in the subdivision, built with front porches (ten feet in length by six feet in width minimum) shall receive a two percent density bonus. 
(5)  Alternate paving design structures for driveways or sidewalks or streets as evaluated and approved by the transportation and development department shall receive a two percent density bonus. 
(6)  Increasing the dwelling size over minimum zoning district requirements shall receive a two percent density bonus per 50 square feet of heated floor area to a maximum of a 14 percent density bonus. 
(Ord. No. 07-05, § 1(art. XII(38-578)), 5-14-2007) 
Sec. 16-588. - Nonconforming uses/structures. 
The conveyance of certain open space or greenspace to the city's Greenspace Land Trust may result in the remaining property being nonconforming or otherwise incompatible with permitted uses within the districts involved. In these instances, the remaining property, structures, or uses of property and structures shall be deemed to be conforming, and the provisions of this article shall not apply as it relates to the size and density of the remaining property and/or structures located thereon. 
(Ord. No. 07-05, § 1(art. XII(38-579)), 5-14-2007) 
Chapter 18 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to provide police and fire protection, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(1); regulation of fire and other hazards to persons and property generally, O.C.G.A. § 25-2-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Contracts for fire protection. 
The mayor and council shall be authorized to enter into contracts on a year-to-year basis with the county or any adjoining municipality which has adequate equipment and personnel to provide the city with fire protection. When such a contract is in existence, the term "chief of the fire department" shall mean the chief of the fire department protecting the city and the term "fire department" shall mean the protecting department. 
(Code 1972, § 11-4; Code 1994, § 42-1; Ord. of 10-14-1991, § 3) 
Sec. 18-2. - Reciprocal agreements for fire protection. 
The mayor and council shall be authorized to enter into reciprocal agreements for fire protection with the United States, the state, the county and municipalities of the state when such agreements are in the best interests of the city and will serve to protect the lives and properties of its citizens. 
(Code 1972, § 11-5; Code 1994, § 42-2) 
Sec. 18-3. - Unlawful acts in connection with fires. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Set fire to any motor vehicle without first obtaining the permission of the chief of the fire department. 
(2)  Set fire to any structure or building without first obtaining the permission of the chief of the fire department. 
(3)  Set any fire on or which spreads to the property of another without the owner's permission. 
(4)  Leave any fire unattended. 
(5)  Set any fire that requires the response of the fire department. 
(6)  Burn any substance or material that emits noxious or poisonous fumes or gases. 
(7)  Set any fire on or which spreads to public property. 
(8)  Obstruct in any manner any fire hydrant in the city. 
(9)  Refuse to obey the orders and directions of fire department personnel in the vicinity of a fire. 
(10)  Obstruct a fire hose or drive a motor vehicle across or over such hose. 
(11)  Obstruct fire department vehicles or apparatus. 
(12)  Interfere with or hinder fire department personnel from performing their duties. 
(13)  Give or turn in a false alarm. 
(14)  Turn on a fire hydrant unless authorized to do so. 
(15)  Damage any fire hydrant, fire alarm box or device or fire extinguisher or equipment designed for use in fighting fires. 
(Code 1972, § 11-8; Code 1994, § 42-3) 
Secs. 18-4—18-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE CODES 

Sec. 18-25. - Adopted. 
(a)  The following codes are adopted by the city for the purpose of regulating conditions that may increase the risk of damage to life and property from fire or explosion: 
(1)  Chapter 42 of the Code of Clayton County, Georgia. 
(b)  The code adopted in subsection (a) of this section is adopted in its entirety and incorporated by reference in this section as fully as though set out at length in this section. In any conflict a provision of the code adopted in subsection (a) and a provision of this Code, that provision which is the most stringent shall prevail and be controlling. 
(c)  Whenever the term "board of commissioners" is used in any provision of the code adopted by this section, it shall mean the mayor and city council. Whenever the term "Clayton County" is used in any provision of the code adopted by this section, it shall mean the City. Whenever the term "County Code of Ordinances" or "County Code" is used in any provision of the code adopted by this section, it shall mean the Code of Ordinances, City of Lake City, Georgia. 
(d)  Current copies of each code adopted by this section shall be maintained on file in the office of the city clerk where they shall be available for public inspection. 
(Code 1972, § 11-1; Code 1994, § 42-26; Ord. of 10-14-1991, § 1; Ord. No. 99-03, § 1(42-26), 12-13-1999; Ord. No. 2016-1, § 1, 2-8-2016) 
Secs. 18-26—18-30. - Reserved. 
Ord. No. 2016-1, §§ 2—6, adopted Feb. 8, 2016, repealed former §§ 18-26—18-30 in their entirety. Subject matter and legislative history of the former sections are listed below. 

 
Chapter 20 - HEALTH AND SANITATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - County nuisance regulations adopted. 
(a)  The city hereby adopts and incorporates by reference as if set out at length herein the latest editions of the nuisance regulation of the Clayton County Board of Health (hereinafter referred to as "the regulations"). 
(b)  All properties and structures in the city shall be maintained, erected, built, repaired, renovated or expanded in accordance with the regulations, and no permit shall be issued for the maintenance, erection, building, repair, renovation or expansion of any structure unless the same is to be maintained, erected, built, repaired, renovated or expanded in the city shall be maintained, erected, built, repaired, renovated or expanded in accordance with the regulations. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with this subsection. 
(c)  At least one copy of the regulations shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(d)  Where reference is made in the regulations to the duties of certain officials named therein, the designated official of the city who has duties corresponding to those of the named official in the regulations shall be deemed to be the responsible official insofar as enforcing the provisions of the regulations is concerned. 
(Ord. No. 04-02, § 1(50-1), 12-13-2004) 
Secs. 20-2—20-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NUISANCES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-1 et seq.; jurisdiction of municipal court or magistrate court to abate nuisance, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5. 

Sec. 20-21. - Acts constituting nuisances designated. 
(a)  A nuisance is anything that works hurt, inconvenience or damage to another, and the fact that the act done may otherwise be lawful shall not keep it from being a nuisance. The inconvenience complained of shall not be fanciful, or such as would affect only one of fastidious taste, but it shall be such as would affect an ordinarily reasonable person. 
(b)  The following conditions, among others, may be declared to be nuisances: 
(1)  Stagnant water on premises; 
(2)  Any dead or decaying matter, weeds, brush, vegetation, or any fruit, vegetable, animal or rodent, or any other objectionable, unsightly, or unsanitary matter upon a premises which is odorous or capable of causing disease to the inhabitants of the city. For the purpose of this article, the term "weeds" means any brush, grass, vegetation, or any plant that is not regularly cultivated, that exceeds a height of ten inches; provided, however, weeds shall not include plants in a maintained wildflower garden. Any plant that is not regularly cultivated exceeding ten inches in height shall be presumed to be a weed. The term "regularly cultivated" means any plant which is routinely cared for by any person to foster its growth, including ornamental grasses, bushes, and trees; 
(3)  The pollution of public water or the injection of matter into the sewage system which would be damaging thereto; 
(4)  Maintaining a dangerous or diseased animal or fowl; 
(5)  Obstruction of a public street, highway or sidewalk without a permit; 
(6)  Unreasonably loud, disturbing and unnecessary noise; 
(7)  All walls, trees and buildings that may endanger persons or property; 
(8)  Uncleanliness; 
(9)  Unused or inoperable appliances of any size or type, including, but not limited to, iceboxes, refrigerators, washers, dryers, water heaters, televisions, stereos, or any parts thereof; 
(10)  Any trees, shrubbery or other plants, or parts thereof, which obstruct clear, safe vision on roadways and intersections of the city; 
(11)  Junked or abandoned motor vehicles; 
(12)  The generation of smoke or fumes in sufficient amount to cause odor or annoyance to the inhabitants of the city; 
(13)  Toilets or sanitary facilities, plumbing, or sewers in bad repair; 
(14)  Defects therein increasing the hazards of fire, accidents, or other calamities; 
(15)  Lack of adequate ventilation, light, or sanitary facilities; 
(16)  Dilapidation; 
(17)  Disrepair; 
(18)  Structural defects; 
(19)  Vacant and dilapidated dwellings, buildings, or structures being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes and/or other illegal activity; and 
(20)  Any other condition constituting a nuisance under state, local or federal law. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § I(art. II, § 50-26), 4-8-2013; Ord. No. 2018-04, § 1, 6-11-2018) 
State Law reference— Power of municipality to define and declare nuisances and to cause their removal or abatement by summary proceedings or otherwise without limitation or impairment by provisions of state law, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9. 
Sec. 20-22. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Applicable codes means: 
(1)  Any optional housing or abatement standard provided in O.C.G.A. tit. 8, ch. 2 as adopted by this Code or operation of law, or other property maintenance standards as adopted by this Code or operation of law, or general nuisance law, relative to the safe use of real property; 
(2)  Any fire or life safety code as provided for in O.C.G.A. tit. 25, ch. 2; and 
Closing means causing a dwelling, building, or structure to be vacated and secured against unauthorized entry. 
Drug crime means an act which is a violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-13-2, known as the Georgia Controlled Substances Act. 
Dwelling, building, or structure means any building or structure or part thereof used and occupied for human habitation or commercial, industrial, or business uses, or intended to be so used, and includes any outhouse, improvement, and appurtenance belonging thereto or usually enjoyed therewith and also includes any building or structure of any design. As used in this section, the term "dwelling, building, or structure" shall not mean or include any farm, any building or structure located on a farm, or any agricultural facility or other building or structure used for the production, growing, raising, harvesting, storage, or processing of crops, livestock, poultry, or other farm products. 
Interested parties means: 
(1)  Owners; 
(2)  Those parties having an interest in the property as revealed by a certification of title to the property conducted in accordance with the title standards of the State Bar of Georgia; 
(3)  Those parties having filed a notice in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-3-9; 
(4)  Any other party having an interest in the property whose identity and address are reasonably ascertainable from the records of the city or records maintained in the county courthouse or by the clerk of the superior court. Interested parties shall not include the holder of the benefit or burden of any easement or right-of-way whose interest is properly recorded which interest shall remain unaffected; and 
(5)  Persons in possession of said property and premises. 
Owner means the holder of the title in fee simple and every mortgagee of record. 
Public authority means the mayor, a member of the city council, city manager, or a head of any department of the city. 
Public officer means the designated building official or code enforcement officer of the city, and/or his designee. 
Repair means altering or improving a dwelling, building, or structure so as to bring the structure into compliance with applicable city codes and the cleaning or removal of debris, trash, and other materials present and accumulated which create a health or safety hazard in or about any dwelling, building, or structure. 
Resident means any person residing at the property on or after the date on which the alleged nuisance arose. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § I(art. II, § 50-27), 4-8-2013; Ord. No. 2018-04, § 1, 6-11-2018) 
Sec. 20-23. - Conviction; penalties. 
(a)  Authority of municipal court. The city municipal court shall have full jurisdiction to try and dispose of all questions of nuisance affecting the public health, safety or welfare. Any person who pleads guilty or nolo contendere, or is convicted of violating the provisions of this article, shall be punished as provided in article IV of the city Charter, this Code or such other general law as may be enacted in the future to provide for punishment and penalties that may be imposed by the municipal courts of the state. 
(b)  Penalties. Each day a nuisance is continued shall constitute a separate offense. Anyone committing a nuisance as defined by this article shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, imprisonment for no more than six months, or a combination thereof. In addition to the fine and/or jail sentence, the judge may impose community service and require that the defendant abate or cure the nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § I(art. II, § 50-28), 4-8-2013; Ord. No. 2018-04, § 1, 6-11-2018) 
Sec. 20-24. - Unfit buildings and structures. 
(a)  Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7, the mayor and council find that there exist within the city dwellings, buildings, or structures which constitute nuisances (i.e., that are unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business uses due to dilapidation and defects increasing the hazards of fire, accidents, or other calamities; lack of adequate ventilation, light, or sanitary facilities; or other conditions rendering such dwellings, buildings, or structures unsafe or unsanitary, or dangerous or detrimental to the health, safety, or welfare, or otherwise inimical to the welfare of the residents of the city, or vacant, dilapidated dwellings, buildings, or structures in which drug crimes may be being committed). 
(b)  Duty to maintain premises. It is the duty of the owner of every dwelling, building, structure, or property within the city to construct and maintain such dwelling, building, structure, or property in conformance with the laws and ordinances of the city, state and United States, which regulate the construction, maintenance, and use of such dwellings, buildings, structures, and/or properties. 
(c)  Powers of public officer. The public officer, as defined herein, is designated to exercise the powers prescribed by this article and state law with respect to nuisances and unfit dwellings, buildings, structures, and property within the city. Among these powers, the public officer is empowered: 
(1)  To investigate the dwelling conditions in city in order to determine which dwellings, buildings, or structures therein are unfit for human habitation or are unfit for current commercial, industrial, or business use or are vacant, dilapidated, and being used in connection with the commission of illegal activity; 
(2)  To administer oaths and affirmations, to examine witnesses, and to receive evidence; 
(3)  To enter upon premises for the purpose of making inspections; provided, however, that such entries shall be made in such manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the persons in possession; 
(4)  To appoint and fix the duties of such officers, agents, and employees as he deems necessary to carry out the purposes of the ordinances; and 
(5)  To delegate any of his functions and powers under the ordinances to such officers and agents as he may designate. 
(d)  Investigation of nuisance. An investigation by the public officer of potentially unfit dwellings, buildings, structures, and/or property within the city may be initiated by: 
(1)  A request filed with the public officer by a public authority; 
(2)  The request of five resident of the city; or 
(3)  A code enforcement officer. 
If the public officer makes a finding that any dwelling, building, structure, or property within the city is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business use, is injurious to the health, safety or welfare of the occupants of such dwelling, building or structure or of the occupants of the neighboring dwelling, building or structure or of other residents of the city, contains defects therein increasing the hazards of fire, accidents or other calamities, lacks adequate ventilation, light or sanitary facilities, is dilapidated or in disrepair, structurally deficient, or unclean, and not in compliance with applicable codes; is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of illegal activity; or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, the public officer may serve the occupant and/or owner of the property with a notice of violation requesting that such nuisance be abated, as set forth within the notice, by a set time. Should the occupant and/or owner fail to abate the nuisance as requested, the public officer may issue a complaint in rem against the lot, tract, or parcel of real property on which such dwelling, building, or structure is situated or where such public health hazard or general nuisance. Nothing in this article shall prevent the public officer from issuing a complaint in lieu of serving the occupant and/or owner with a notice of violation where the severity and/or circumstances surrounding the condition of the nuisance justify such action. 
(e)  Action to abate. Whenever a request is filed with the public officer by at least five residents of the city, a public authority or another code enforcement officer, charging conditions as described in subsection (c) above, the public officer shall, if his preliminary investigation discloses a basis for such charges issue a complaint in rem with the city municipal court which shall: 
(1)  Identify the subject real property by its street address of tax record and official tax map reference; 
(2)  Identify the interested parties; 
(3)  State with particularity the factual basis for the action; and 
(4)  Contain a statement of the action sought by the code enforcement officer to abate the alleged nuisance. 
(f)  Service of complaints. Complaints issued under this section shall be served in the following manner. 
(1)  Mailing or posting of complaint and summons; right to answer. 
a.  At least 14 days prior to the date of the hearing, public officer shall cause for copies of the complaint and summons to be mailed by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery, return receipt requested, to all interested parties whose identities and addresses are reasonably ascertainable. Copies of the summons and complaint shall also be mailed by first-class mail to the property address to the attention of the occupants of the property, if any, and shall be posted on the property and/or hand delivered to an occupant of the property at the location of the property, within three business days of filing the complaint and at least 14 days prior to the date of the hearing. 
b.  The summons shall notify the interested parties that a hearing will be held before the municipal court, at a date and time certain. Such hearing shall be held not less than 15 days nor more than 45 days after the filing of said complaint in the proper court. The interested parties shall have the right to file an answer to the complaint and to appear in person or by attorney and offer testimony at the time and place fixed for hearing. 
(2)  For interested parties whose mailing address is unknown, a notice stating the date, time, and place of the hearing shall be published in the newspaper in which the sheriff's advertisements appear once a week for two consecutive weeks prior to the hearing. 
(3)  A notice of lis pendens shall be filed in the office of the clerk of superior court of the at the time of filing the complaint in the municipal court. 
(4)  Orders and other filings made subsequent to service of the initial complaint shall be served in the manner provided in this section on any interested party who answers the complaint or appears at the hearing. Any interested party who fails to answer or appear at the hearing shall be deemed to have waived all further notice in the proceedings. 
(g)  Findings by the court. If the municipal court determines that the dwelling, building, or structure in question is unfit for human habitation or is unfit for its current commercial, industrial, or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes; is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of illegal activity; or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, or any of the violations stated in subsection (c) above, the court shall state in writing findings of fact in support of such determination and shall issue and cause to be served upon the interested parties that have answered the complaint or appeared at the hearing an order. Among other lawful remedies, the court may: 
(1)  Require the owner, within the time specified in the order, to repair, alter, or improve such dwelling, building, or structure so as to bring it into full compliance with the applicable codes relevant to the cited violation, if the repair, alteration, or improvement of the said dwelling, building, or structure can be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building, or structure; 
(2)  Require the owner to secure the structure so that it cannot be used in connection with the commission of illegal activity; and/or 
(3)  Require the owner, within the time specified in the order, to demolish and remove such dwelling, building, or structure and all debris from the property, if the repair, alteration, or improvement of the said dwelling, building, or structure in order to bring it into full compliance with applicable codes relevant to the cited violations cannot be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building, or structure. 
(h)  Determination of costs. For purposes of this section, the court shall make its determination of "reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building, or structure" without consideration of the value of the land on which the structure is situated; provided, however, that costs of the preparation necessary to repair, alter, or improve a structure may be considered. Income and financial status of the owner shall not be a factor in the court's determination. The present value of the structure and the costs of repair, alteration, or improvement may be established by affidavits of real estate appraisers with a state appraiser classification as provided in O.C.G.A. tit. 43, ch. 39A, qualified building contractors, or qualified building inspectors, without actual testimony presented. Costs of repair, alteration, or improvement of the structure shall be the cost necessary to bring the structure into compliance with the applicable laws and codes relevant to the cited violations. 
(i)  Abatement for failure to comply. If the owner fails to comply with an order to repair or demolish the dwelling, building, or structure, among other available remedies, the city and/or the public officer may cause such dwelling, building, or structure to be repaired, altered, or improved or to be vacated and closed or demolished. Such abatement action shall commence within 270 days after the expiration of time specified in the order for abatement by the owner. Any time during which such action is prohibited by a court order issued pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 41-2-13 or any other equitable relief granted by a court of competent jurisdiction shall not be counted toward the 270 days in which such abatement action must commence. The code enforcement officer shall cause to be posted on the main entrance of the building, dwelling, or structure a placard with the following words: 
"This building is unfit for human habitation or commercial, industrial, or business use and does not comply with the applicable codes or has been ordered secured to prevent its use in connection with illegal activity or constitutes an endangerment to public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions. The use or occupation of this building is prohibited and unlawful." 
(j)  Salvage. If the public officer has the structure demolished, reasonable effort shall be made to salvage reusable materials for credit against the cost of demolition. The proceeds of any moneys received from the sale of salvaged materials shall be used or applied against the cost of the demolition and removal of the structure, and proper records shall be kept showing application of sales proceeds. Any such sale of salvaged materials may be made without the necessity of public advertisement and bid. The code enforcement officer, the city, and the city's employees, agents and officials are relieved of any and all liability resulting from or occasioned by the sale of any such salvaged materials, including, without limitation, defects in such salvaged materials. 
(k)  Lien. The amount of the cost of demolition, including all court costs, appraisal fees, administrative costs incurred by the city, and all other costs necessarily associated with the abatement action, including restoration to grade of the real property after demolition, shall be a lien against the real property upon which such cost was incurred. 
(l)  Non-exclusivity. Nothing in this article shall be interpreted to preclude or prevent the city from instead filing an action for nuisance abatement with a superior court of the state in lieu of the process set forth under this section. Nor shall anything in this section be construed to impair or limit in any way the power of the city to define and declare nuisances and to cause their removal or abatement by summary proceedings or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § I(art. II, § 50-29), 4-8-2013; Ord. No. 2018-04, § 1, 6-11-2018) 
Sec. 20-25. - Liens on property for cost of abating nuisances. 
(a)  Attachment of lien; collection procedure. 
(1)  The lien provided for in this article shall attach to the real property upon the filing of the certified copy of the order requiring repair, closure or demolition in the office of the clerk of the superior court and shall relate back to the date of the filing of the lis pendens notice required under O.C.G.A. § 41-2-12(c). 
(2)  Upon final determination of costs, fees and expenses incurred in accordance with this article, the public officer shall transmit to the city tax collector a statement of the total amount due and secured by said lien, together with copies of all notices provided to the interested parties within 90 days of completion of the repairs, demolition or closure. It shall be the duty of the city tax collector to collect the amount of the lien using all methods for collecting real property ad valorem taxes. 
(3)  Enforcement of liens pursuant to this section may be initiated at any time following receipt by the tax collector of the final determination of costs in accordance with this article. The unpaid lien amount shall bear interest and penalties from and after the date of the final determination of costs in the same amount as applicable to interest and penalties on unpaid real property ad valorem taxes. 
(4)  The redemption amount in any enforcement proceeding pursuant to this section shall be the full amount of the costs as finally determined in accordance with this section together interest, penalties and costs incurred by the city in the enforcement of such lien. Redemption of property from the lien shall be made in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-4-80 and 48-4-81. 
(b)  The city may waive and release any such lien imposed on property upon the owner of such property entering into a contract with the city agreeing to a timetable for rehabilitation of the real property or the dwelling, building or structure on the property and demonstrating the financial means to accomplish such rehabilitation. 
(Ord. No. 2018-04, § 1, 6-11-2018) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2018-04, § 1, adopted June 11, 2018, renumbered the former § 20-25 as 20-26, and added a new § 20-25 as set out herein. The historical notation remains with the renumbered provision. 
Sec. 20-26. - Summary abatement; when authorized. 
Nothing contained in this article shall prevent the mayor and city council from summarily and without notice ordering the abatement of or abating any nuisance that is a nuisance per se in the law or where the case is an urgent one and the health and safety of the public or a portion thereof is in imminent danger. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § I(art. II, § 50-30), 4-8-2013; Ord. No. 2018-04, § 1, 6-11-2018) 
Editor's note— See note to § 20-25. 
Secs. 20-27—20-53. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STORAGE OF PERSONAL PROPERTY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of municipality to provide by ordinance for the removal and disposal of any discarded, dismantled, wrecked, scrapped, ruined, or junked motor vehicles or parts thereof, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-4. 

Sec. 20-54. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to require the maintenance of premises to retain property values and to protect the general environment and appearance of neighborhoods, residential complexes, and commercial industrial areas, and to ensure safe and sanitary conditions in buildings, structures, and premises in the city to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Code 1994, § 50-51; Ord. No. 96-02, § 2(50-51), 6-10-1996) 
Sec. 20-55. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings described to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Derelict automotive vehicle means a vehicle that for a period of at least ten consecutive days, or 15 consecutive days if located on the premises of an automobile service station, automotive facility including repair and servicing, garage, service station, tire recapping and retreading shop, or repair shop or machine shop for automotive vehicles: 
(1)  Is physically incapable of traveling under its own power; 
(2)  Is physically capable of traveling under its own power, but during such traveling on a public road would be in violation of any provision of title 40, chapter 8, article I, parts 1 through 4 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated (not including O.C.G.A. §§ 40-8-76(b)—(d), 40-8-76.1 and 40-8-79); or 
(3)  Possesses at least two of the following characteristics: 
a.  At least one door, the hood, or the trunk cover cannot be closed. 
b.  At least one door, the hood, or the trunk cover is kept in place on the vehicle with tape, rope, or wire. 
c.  Rusting covering at least 50 percent of the body of the vehicle. 
d.  Missing a door, the hood, the trunk cover, or a tire. 
Inoperative means any vehicle or automobile which is rendered unroadworthy according to the standards established by O.C.G.A. § 40-8-1 et seq. Any vehicle which has been left, stored or kept at the same location for 30 or more days shall be presumed to be inoperative for purposes of this article unless the owner or person in possession of such vehicle or automobile proves, by a preponderance of the evidence, to the contrary. 
Junk automobile or junk vehicle means any automobile or vehicle which is inoperative or which does not bear current license plates. 
Same location means on one lot or on a single piece of property within the city. 
(Code 1994, § 50-52; Ord. No. 96-02, § 2(50-52), 6-10-1996; Ord. No. 03-01, § 1(50-52), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 20-56. - Maintenance of property. 
(a)  Except as may otherwise be allowed by this article, it shall be unlawful for any person to own, rent, lease, or be in possession of any property whereon is kept in an area other than a completely enclosed building dilapidated furniture, appliances, machinery, equipment, antiques, lumber, building materials, inventory, cordage, and similar items and materials, including junk automobiles, derelict automotive vehicles, and junk vehicles or automobiles or vehicles which are in a partially wrecked, dismantled or inoperative condition. 
(b)  In the event that any person is in the business of repairing or restoring furniture, appliances, machinery, equipment, antiques, lumber, building materials, inventory, cordage, and similar items and materials, including junk automobiles, derelict automotive vehicles, and junk vehicles or automobiles or vehicles which are in a partially wrecked, dismantled or inoperative condition, all work being performed on such items must be done within a completely enclosed building. 
(c)  All persons that are in the business of repairing or restoring junked automobiles or junked vehicles or automobiles or derelict automotive vehicles or vehicles which are in a partially wrecked, dismantled or inoperative condition shall have no more than one automobile or vehicle on the property per 200 square feet of indoor repair facility. The mayor and council, upon receipt and review of a written application, shall increase the number of automobiles or vehicles allowed contingent upon the completion of proposed additional parking, after review of a detailed site plan showing such proposed parking including striping of parking spaces, upon making the following findings: 
(1)  The proposed parking complies with all parking and other requirements contained in the city Code as well as state and federal law. 
(2)  The proposed parking would have no adverse effect on any residential area. Such increase shall be limited so as to ensure that no adverse effects on any residential area occur. 
(Code 1994, § 50-53; Ord. No. 96-02, § 2(50-53), 6-10-1996; Ord. No. 03-01, § 2(50-53), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 20-57. - Exclusion from section 50-56. 
Section 50-56 shall not apply to: 
(1)  Any person who is operating a junkyard, provided that said junkyard obtains an occupation tax certificate for the current year and that said junkyard is in compliance with the zoning regulations in chapter 42; and 
(2)  All persons that are in the business of selling or repairing heavy equipment. For purposes of this section, heavy equipment shall include bulldozers, front-end loaders, backhoes, dump trucks, and any truck or machinery for which a commercial driver's license would be required for its operation. 
(Code 1994, § 50-54; Ord. No. 96-02, § 2(50-54), 6-10-1996) 
Sec. 20-58. - Screening and fencing. 
(a)  No person exempted by section 50-57 shall store, keep, maintain or allow to be kept on property within the city limits any furniture, appliances, machinery, equipment, antiques, lumber, building materials, inventory, cordage, and similar items and materials, including junk automobiles, derelict automotive vehicles, and junk vehicles or automobiles or vehicles which are in a partially wrecked, dismantled or inoperative condition unless such items are housed in a completely enclosed building or screened by opaque fencing which is a minimum of eight feet in height. 
(b)  All persons that are in the business of repairing or restoring junked automobiles or junked vehicles or automobiles or derelict automotive vehicles or vehicles which are in a partially wrecked, dismantled or inoperative condition shall keep all such vehicles either housed in a completely enclosed building or screened by opaque fencing which is a minimum of eight feet in height. 
(Code 1994, § 50-55; Ord. No. 96-02, § 2(50-55), 6-10-1996; Ord. No. 03-01, § 3(50-55), 4-14-2003) 
Sec. 20-59. - Inspection; notice; hearing. 
(a)  Should the code enforcement officer or chief of police determine that any person is violating the terms of this article, he shall issue a written notice of code violation to such person and give five days in which to correct the violation. The notice of code violation shall be a prerequisite to the bringing of charges against an offender. 
(b)  Should the person to whom the notice of code violation is directed fail to comply with the corrective action set forth therein within the five-day period, the law enforcement officers of the city shall be authorized to proceed with the bringing of charges as for the violation of any city ordinance. Each day the violation exists shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(c)  Any violation which remains on the same property for a period of 30 days after either a plea of finding of guilty shall be presumed to be abandoned and subject to being removed from the property by the chief of police or his duly authorized agent or employee. For purposes of this section, a plea of nolo contendere shall constitute a finding of guilty. After removal, the chief of police shall determine whether or not the property has any value. If he finds it to have value, it shall be disposed of by sale as for other abandoned or other unclaimed property. If the chief of police finds the property to have no value, he shall immediately and personally see to its destruction. The chief of police shall also have the authority to charge the cost of removing said violations to the owner of any such property. The city clerk shall have full, ample and complete authority to issue execution in the name of the city, which shall issue and be levied as executions for taxes in the city are issued and levied. Such execution shall issue and constitute a lien upon the property so cleaned and against the owner thereof, provided a detailed, itemized statement of the cost of such work shall be attached to and form a part of the execution, and provided further that no execution shall issue against any landowner unless he shall have been served in person with written notice, as hereinabove provided, at least five days before such work is commenced by the city, and provided further that in the event that such a landowner is a nonresident, such written notice must be have been mailed to him, or to his last known address, at least ten days prior to beginning the work of the city. 
(d)  Violations of this article shall be punishable pursuant to section 1-8. 
(Code 1994, § 50-56; Ord. No. 96-02, § 2(50-56), 6-10-1996; Ord. No. 03-01, § 4(50-56), 4-14-2003; Ord. No. 03-08, § 1(50-56), 6-9-2003) 
Secs. 20-60—20-76. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - COMMUNITY REDEVELOPMENT TAX INCENTIVE PROGRAM[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2018-04, § 2, adopted June 11, 2018, repealed the former article IV, §§ 20-77—20-83, and enacted a new article IV as set out herein. The former article IV pertained to unfit structures and derived from Ord. No. 00-03, adopted February 14, 2000. 

Sec. 20-77. - Purpose. 
The existence of real property that is maintained in a blighted condition increases the costs to city budgets by increasing the need for government services, including but not limited to social services, public safety services and code enforcement services. Rehabilitation of blighted property decreases this need for such government services. 
In recognition of the need for enhanced governmental services and in order to encourage private property owners to maintain their real property and the buildings, structures and improvements thereon in good condition and repair, and as an incentive to encourage community redevelopment, a community redevelopment tax incentive program is hereby established as authorized by article IX, section II, paragraph VII(d) of the 1983 Constitution of the State of Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 2018-04, § 2, 6-11-2018) 
Sec. 20-78. - Definitions. 
(a)  Blighted property, blighted, or blight means any urbanized or developed property that: 
(1)  Presents two or more of the following conditions: 
a.  Uninhabitable, unsafe, or abandoned structures; or 
b.  Inadequate provisions for ventilation, light, air, or sanitation; or 
c.  An imminent harm to life or other property caused by fire, flood, hurricane, tornado, earthquake, storm, or other natural catastrophe that the governor has declared a state of emergency under the state law or has certified the need for disaster assistance under federal law; provided, however, this subsection shall not apply to property unless the relevant public agency has given notice in writing to the property owner regarding specific harm caused by the property and the owner has failed to take reasonable measures to remedy the harm; or 
d.  A site identified by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency as a superfund site pursuant to 42 U.S.C. Section 9601, et. seq., or environmental contamination to the extent that requires remedial investigation or a feasibility study; or 
e.  Repeated illegal activity on the individual property of which the property owner knew or should have known; or 
f.  The maintenance of the property is below state, county, or municipal codes for at least one year after written notice of the code violation to its owner; and 
g.  Is conducive to ill health, transmission of disease, infant mortality or crime in the immediate proximity of the property. 
(2)  Property shall not be deemed blighted solely because of aesthetic conditions. 
(3)  Property shall not be deemed blighted for the purpose of this section's increase of ad valorem taxation if the property is a dwelling house which is being used as a primary residence of one or more persons. 
(b)  Building official. Person authorized to enforce provisions of the technical construction codes. 
(c)  Community redevelopment means any activity, project, or service necessary or incidental to achieving the redevelopment or revitalization of a redevelopment area or portion thereof designated for redevelopment through an urban redevelopment plan or through local ordinances relating to the repair, closing, and demolition of buildings and structures unfit for human habitation. 
(d)  Millage or millage rate means the levy, in mills, that is established by the mayor and city council for purposes of financing, in whole or in part, the city's general fund expenses for the fiscal year. 
(e)  Person. Any natural person, corporation, or unincorporated association. 
(f)  Public officer means the city manager or such other officer or employee of the city as designated by the city manager to perform duties and responsibilities hereafter set for the in this article. 
(g)  Structure. Anything constructed or erected which has, or the use of which requires, permanent or temporary location on or in the ground, or which is attached to something having a permanent location on the ground, including, but not limited to, the following: buildings, gazebos, signs, billboards, tennis courts, radio and television antennae and satellite dishes (including supporting towers), swimming pools, light fixtures, walls, fences and steps. 
(Ord. No. 2018-04, § 2, 6-11-2018) 
Sec. 20-79. - Levy on increased ad valorem tax on blighted real property. 
(a)  There is hereby levied on all real property within the city that has been officially identified as maintained in a blighted condition an increased ad valorem tax by applying a factor of seven times millage rate applied to the property, so that such property shall be taxed at a higher millage rate generally applied in the city, or other provided by general law (all properties that meet this definition will be subject to this article). 
(b)  Such increased ad valorem tax shall be applied and reflected in the next tax bill cycle which begins July 1 of every year following official designation of a real property as blighted. 
(c)  Revenues arising from the increased rate of ad valorem taxation shall, upon receipt, be segregated by the city manager and the finance director and used only for community redevelopment purposes, including defraying the cost of the city's program to close, repair or demolish unfit buildings and structures. 
(Ord. No. 2018-04, § 2, 6-11-2018) 
Sec. 20-80. - Official identification of property maintained in blighted condition. 
(a)  In order for a parcel of real property to be officially designated as maintained in a blighted condition and subject to increased taxation, the following steps must be completed: 
(1)  An inspection must be performed on the parcel of property. In order for inspection to be performed: 
a.  A request may be made by the public officer or by at least five residents of the city for inspection of a parcel of property, said inspection to be based on the criteria as delineated by ordinance; or 
b.  The public officer may cause a survey of existing housing conditions to be performed, or may defer to any such survey conducted or finalized within the previous five years, to locate or identify any parcels that may be in a blighted condition and for which a full inspection should be conducted to determine if that parcel of property meets the criteria set out in this article for designation as being maintained in a blighted condition. 
(2)  A written inspection report of the findings for any parcel of property inspected pursuant to subsection (1) above shall be prepared and submitted to the public officer. Where feasible, photographs of the conditions found to exist on the property on the date of inspections shall be made and will supplement the inspection report. Where compliance with minimum construction, housing, occupancy, fire and life safety codes in effect within the city are in question, the inspection shall be conducted by a certified inspector possessing the requisite qualifications to determine minimal code compliance. 
(3)  Following completion of the inspection report, the building official shall make a determination, in writing, that a property is maintained in a blighted condition, as defined in this article, and is subject to increased taxation. 
(4)  Said inspection report and supporting documents will be reviewed by the city manager for confirmation and approval of all findings and recommendations by the building official and concurrence that the property identified meets the definition of blighted area as defined under this article. At that point, the mayor and city council shall be notified in writing of the determination of blighted condition. 
(5)  The building official shall cause a written notice of this determination that the real property at issue is being maintained in a blighted condition to be served upon the person(s) shown on the most recent tax digest of the county as responsible for payment of ad valorem taxes assessed thereon and parties in interest; provided, however, where through the existence of reasonable diligence it becomes known to the public officer that real property has been sold or conveyed since publication of the most recent tax digest, written notice shall be given to the person(s) known or reasonably believed to then own the property or be chargeable with the payment of ad valorem taxes thereon, at the best address available. Service in the manner set forth at O.C.G.A. § 41-2-12 shall constitute sufficient notice to the property's owner or persons chargeable with the payment of ad valorem taxes for purpose of this section, except that posting of the notice on the property will not be required. 
(b)  The written notice given to the person(s) chargeable with the payment of ad valorem taxes and parties in interest shall notify such person and parties in interest of the building official's determination that the real property is being maintained in a blighted condition and shall advise such person and parties in interest of the hours and location at which the person may inspect and copy the building official's determination and any supporting documentation. Persons and parties in interest notified that the real property of which the person(s) is chargeable with the payment of ad valorem taxes shall have 30 days from the receipt of notice in which to request an appeal hearing before the mayor and city council. Written request for hearing shall be filed with the building official and shall be date stamped upon receipt. Upon receipt of a request for appeal hearing, the building official shall notify the city manager. 
(c)  Within 30 days of the receipt of a request for an appeal hearing, the building official shall set a date, time and location for the hearing and shall give at least ten business days' notice to the person(s) and/or parties in interest requesting the hearing and the city manager. A notice stating the date, time, and place of the hearing shall be published in the newspaper in which the sheriff's advertisement appears in the county once a week for two consecutive weeks prior to the hearing. Hearings may be continued upon request of any party, for good cause. 
(d)  At the hearing, the public officer shall have the burden of demonstrating by a preponderance of the evidence that the subject property is maintained in a blighted condition, as defined in this article. Upon hearing from the public officer and/or their witnesses and the person(s) or parties in interest requesting the hearing and/or their witnesses, the mayor and city council shall make a determination either affirming or reversing the determination of the public officer. The determination shall be in writing and copies thereof shall be served on the parties by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery. The determination by the mayor and council shall be deemed final. A copy of such determination shall be served upon the city tax collector and the county tax commissioner, who shall include the increased tax on the next regular tax bill rendered on behalf of the city. 
(e)  Persons aggrieved by the determination of the mayor and city council affirming the determination of the public officer may petition the county superior court for a writ of certiorari, within 30 days of issuance of the city council's written determination. 
(Ord. No. 2018-04, § 2, 6-11-2018) 
Sec. 20-81. - Remediation or redevelopment to remove designation of blighted condition. 
(a)  A property owner or person(s) who is chargeable with the payment of ad valorem taxes on real property that has been officially designated pursuant to this article as property maintained in a blighted condition may petition the public officer to lift the designation, upon proof of compliance with the following: 
(1)  Completion of work required under a plan of remedial action or redevelopment approved by the city's building official that addresses the conditions of blight found to exist on or within the property, including compliance with all applicable minimum codes; and 
(2)  Completion of work required under a court order entered in a proceeding brought pursuant to article II of this chapter; and 
(3)  Any outstanding ad valorem taxes (state, school, county and city, including the increased tax pursuant to this section) and governmental liens due and payable on the property must be satisfied in full. 
(b)  Before action on a petition to lift the designation, the public officer shall case the property to be thoroughly inspected by a building inspector, who by written inspection report, shall certify that all requisite work has been performed to applicable code in a workmanlike manner, in accordance with the specifications of the plan of remedial action or redevelopment, or applicable court order. Upon finding required work to be satisfactorily performed, the public officer shall issue a written determination that the real property is no longer maintained in a blighted condition. Copies of this determination shall be served upon the person(s) chargeable with the payment of ad valorem taxes, and upon the county tax commissioner. 
(c)  All corrective action plans shall be in writing, signed by the person(s) chargeable with the payment of ad valorem taxes on the real property and the building official and city manager, and contain the following: 
(1)  The corrective action plan shall be consistent with the city's comprehensive plan and all laws and ordinances governing the subject property, and shall conform to any urban redevelopment plan adopted for that area; 
(2)  The corrective action plan shall set forth in a reasonable detail the requirements for repair, closure, demolition, or restoration of existing structures, in accordance with minimal statewide codes. Where structures are demolished, the plan shall include provisions for debris removal, stabilization and landscaping of the property; 
(3)  On parcels of five acres or greater, the plan shall address the relationship to local objectives respecting land uses, improved traffic, public transportation, public utilities, recreational and community facilities, and other public improvements; 
(4)  The plan shall contain verifiable funding sources that will be used to complete its requirements and show the feasibility thereof; and 
(5)  The plan shall contain a timetable for completion of required work. 
(Ord. No. 2018-04, § 2, 6-11-2018) 
Sec. 20-82. - Decreased rate of taxation to be applied after successful remedial action or redevelopment of blighted property. 
Real property that has had its designation as maintained in a blighted condition removed by the public officer shall be eligible for a decrease in the rate of city ad valorem taxation by applying a factor of 0.25 to the city millage rate applied to the property, so that such property shall be taxed at a lower millage rate than the millage rate generally applied in the city or otherwise provided by general law; such decreased rate of taxation shall be applied beginning with the next tax bill rendered following removal of official designation of a real property as blighted. The decreased rate of taxation may be given in successive years, depending in the amount of cost expended by the person(s) chargeable with payment of ad valorem taxes on the property to satisfy its remediation or redevelopment, with every $40,000.00 or portion thereof equaling one year of tax reduction; provided, however, that no property shall be entitled to reduction in the city ad valorem tax rate for more than two successive years. In order to claim entitlement for a decreased rate of taxation, the person(s) chargeable with payment of ad valorem taxes on the property shall submit a notarized affidavit to the public officer, supported by receipts or other evidence of payment, of the amount expended. 
(Ord. No. 2018-04, § 2, 6-11-2018) 
Sec. 20-83. - Duty of public officer to provide notice to county tax commissioner. 
It shall be the duty of the public officer to notify the city tax collector and the county tax commissioner in writing as to designation or removal of designation of a specific property as maintained in a blighted condition. Such notice shall identify the specific property by street address and tax map land lot and parcel number, as assigned by the county tax assessor's office. The public officer shall cooperate with the tax commissioner to assure accurate tax billing of those properties subject to increase or reduced ad valorem taxation under this article. 
(Ord. No. 2018-04, § 2, 6-11-2018) 
Secs. 20-84—20-109. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - HOSPITALITY ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 20-110. - Food service regulations adopted. 
(a)  The city hereby adopts and incorporates by reference as if set out at length herein the latest editions of the county health department food service rules and regulations, as adopted and amended by the county environmental health department (hereinafter referred to as the "regulations"). 
(b)  All food service establishments of every kind or character maintained, erected, built, repaired, renovated or expanded in the city shall be maintained, erected, built, repaired, renovated or expanded in accordance with the regulations, and no permit shall be issued for the maintenance, erection, building, repair, renovation or expansion of any food service establishments unless the same is to be maintained, erected, built, repaired, renovated or expanded in the city shall be maintained, erected, built, repaired, renovated or expanded in accordance with the regulations. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with this subsection. 
(c)  At least one copy of the regulations shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(d)  Where reference is made in the regulations to the duties of certain officials named therein, the designated official of the city who has duties corresponding to those of the named official in the regulations shall be deemed to be the responsible official insofar as enforcing the provisions of the regulations is concerned. 
(Ord. No. 04-02, § 2(art. V, § 18-200), 12-13-2004) 
Sec. 20-111. - Tourist court rules and regulations adopted. 
(a)  The city hereby adopts and incorporates by reference as if set out at length herein the latest editions of the county health department tourist court rules and regulations, as adopted and amended by the county environmental health department (hereinafter referred to as the "regulations"). 
(b)  All establishments described by the regulations of every kind or character maintained, erected, built, repaired, renovated or expanded in the city shall be maintained, erected, built, repaired, renovated or expanded in accordance with the regulations, and no permit shall be issued for the maintenance, erection, building, repair, renovation or expansion of any such establishment unless the same is to be maintained, erected, built, repaired, renovated or expanded in the city shall be maintained, erected, built, repaired, renovated or expanded in accordance with the regulations. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with this subsection. 
(c)  At least one copy of the regulations shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(d)  Where reference is made in the regulations to the duties of certain officials named therein, the designated official of the city who has duties corresponding to those of the named official in the regulations shall be deemed to be the responsible official insofar as enforcing the provisions of the regulations is concerned. 
(Ord. No. 04-02, § 2(art. V, § 18-201), 12-13-2004) 
Secs. 20-112—20-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - VACANT BUILDING REGISTRY 

Sec. 20-136. - Registration of vacant buildings. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, whenever any building, dwelling or structure is vacant for more than 60 days and is in violation of this article, the owner, shall within ten days of written notice from the city of the existence of a vacant building, dwelling or structure, register, or caused to be registered, such building, dwelling or structure as a vacant building, dwelling or structure and submit a vacant building plan. 
(b)  Any building, dwelling or structure designed as a home dwelling that is vacant for a period less than 12 months shall be exempt from registration under this section, provided that the building, dwelling or structure is currently and continuously being marketed for sale and is not otherwise in violation of this article. At any time such building, dwelling or structure ceases to be marketed for sale or at such time as the building, dwelling or structure becomes vacant for a period greater than 12 months, then the owner of such building, dwelling or structure, shall within ten days of such event, register, or caused to be registered such building, dwelling or structure as a vacant building, dwelling or structure and submit a vacant building plan. 
(c)  The vacant building registration shall be completed through and approved by the code enforcement officer accompanied with a filing fee. Registration of a vacant building shall be valid for a period of six months. The filing fee shall be in an amount as established by the mayor and council from time to time. 
(d)  If the building is vacant at the expiration of any registration period and the requirements of the vacant building plan have not been completed, the owner shall re-register such building and pay another filing fee. If the building is vacant at the expiration of any registration period and the requirements of the vacant building have been completed, the owner shall re-register such building, but shall not file a vacant building plan and shall not pay the filing fee. 
(e)  The owner registering a vacant building shall supply the following information on an authorized from provided by the city: 
(1)  Name, address, and telephone number of the owner; 
(2)  Name, address and telephone number of any responsible party, if applicable; 
(3)  Name, address, and telephone number of any local agent or representative of the owner; 
(4)  Name, address, and telephone number of all persons with any legal interest in the property, building or premises, including mortgagees and successors in interest; 
(5)  Legal description and tax parcel identification number of the premises on which the building is situated; 
(6)  The common address of the building; 
(7)  Date on which the building became vacant; and 
(8)  Vacant building plan. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 1(19-1), 3-12-2012) 
Sec. 20-137. - Establishment of vacant building plan. 
(a)  When a building is registered as required by this article, the owner shall submit, or caused to be submitted, for approval a vacant building plan. The plan shall contain the following: 
(1)  The reasonably expected period of vacancy; 
(2)  A plan to make the building ready for occupancy with sufficient detail regarding the proposed repair and/or rehabilitation of the building to enable the code enforcement officer to determine the adequacy of such plan; 
(3)  A letter of written consent by the owner allowing city officials to enter and inspect the property for the period in which the vacant building plan is in effect; 
(4)  For buildings, dwellings or structures which are identified as being or containing public nuisances, then the vacant building plan shall contain a plan of action to remedy such public nuisances; 
(5)  For each required plan, a time schedule shall be submitted identifying a date of commencement of repair and/or rehabilitation and schedule for completion of repair and/or rehabilitation for each building, dwelling or structure and identified nuisance; 
(6)  When the owner proposes to occupy, sell, lease or demolish the vacant building, then the owner shall submit a plan and time schedule for such action; and 
(7)  A plan of action to secure, monitor and maintain the building and premises thereof in conformance with this article. 
(b)  The code enforcement officer is hereby authorized to collect a fee to the enable city to monitor or inspect the building and to review and approve the vacant building plan. The code enforcement officer shall have discretion to determine the number of inspections required to monitor the subject building upon submission of the plan based upon the type and condition of the property and the history of violations at the subject property. A standard schedule of fees shall be published by the code enforcement officer. 
(c)  The vacant building plan shall be recorded and indexed in the property records of the county and shall be released by the city when it has been determined that the property is no longer vacant. 
(d)  Failure by the owner to submit a vacant building plan or comply with a vacant building plan that has been approved by the city under this section or pay a fee as required under this section is a violation of this article and may be remedied by any of the following:
