(1)  An administrative penalty of up to $500.00 for the first citation; up to $750.00 for the second citation; and up to $1,000.00 for the third citation and any others after that; or 
(2)  Acquisition of the property by eminent domain in a manner consistent with section 20-138. 
(e)  If the property is subject to a vacant building plan and the plan has been properly recorded in the property records of the county, the transferee is subject to the terms of the vacant building plan. The transferee may apply to the city to be released from the requirements of the vacant building plan. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 1(19-2), 3-12-2012) 
Sec. 20-138. - Acquisition of vacant buildings by eminent domain. 
(a)  The city may acquire by eminent domain, pursuant to applicable state law, any property determined to be vacant and a persistent nuisance, and shall have the power to hold, clear, manage or dispose of property so acquired for residential, commercial, industrial and related use. 
(b)  The mayor and council shall not institute eminent domain proceedings pursuant to this section unless the code enforcement officer has certified that the property is vacant and a persistent nuisance. A property may only be certified to the mayor and council as vacant and a persistent nuisance after the code enforcement officer has determined that: 
(1)  The owner of the property or designated agent has been sent a notice or order by the appropriate agency of the municipality to eliminate the conditions which are in violation of local codes or law; 
(2)  The property is vacant; 
(3)  The property is a nuisance under the terms of article IV of this chapter; and 
(4)  The city has notified the property owner or designated agent that the property has been determined to be blighted or deteriorated and the time period for correction of such condition has expired and the property owner or agent has failed to comply with this notice. 
(c)  The findings required by subsection (b) of this section shall be in writing and included in the report prepared by the code enforcement officer to the mayor and council. 
(d)  The code enforcement officer shall notify the owner of the property or a designated agent that a determination that the property is vacant and a persistent nuisance has been made and that failure to eliminate the conditions causing such condition shall render the property subject to condemnation by the city under this article. Notice shall be mailed to the owner or designated agent by certified mail, return receipt requested. However, if the address of the owner or designated agent is unknown and cannot be ascertained by the commission in the exercise of reasonable diligence, copies of the notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the property affected and notice shall be published the newspaper which is the official organ of the county in which the sheriff's advertisements appear. The written notice sent to the owner or the owner's agent shall describe the conditions that render the property blighted and deteriorated, and shall demand abatement of the conditions within 90 days of the receipt of such notice. 
(e)  An extension of the 90-day time period may be granted by the city if the owner or designated agent demonstrates that such period is insufficient to correct the conditions cited in the notice. 
(f)  No elected official, officer or employee of the city shall acquire any interest in any property declared to be vacant or a persistent nuisance. 
(g)  If any elected official, officer or employee owns or has a financial interest, direct or indirect, in any property certified to be vacant and a persistent nuisance, the officer or employee shall immediately disclose, in writing, such interest to the mayor and council, and such disclosure shall be entered in the minutes of the mayor and council. 
(h)  Failure to so disclose such interest shall constitute misconduct in office. 
(i)  No payment shall be made to any elected official, officer or employee for any property or interest therein acquired by the city from such elected official, officer or employee unless the amount of such payment is fixed by court order in eminent domain proceedings, or unless payment is unanimously approved by the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 1(19-3), 3-12-2012) 
Sec. 20-139. - Enclosure of vacant lots. 
(a)  The code enforcement officer, at his discretion and based upon substantial evidence of the occurrence of criminal activities or offenses affecting the public health, safety and welfare in or on any vacant lot in the city, may order the owner or agent for the owner of such vacant lot to erect or cause to be erected a fence of a height and type permitted by the zoning code along all or any part of the perimeter of such vacant lot. 
(b)  A conviction of any person of failure or refusal to comply with an order of the code enforcement officer issued pursuant to this section shall be punishable by a fine of not less than $50.00. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 1(19-4), 3-12-2012) 
Chapter 22 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to provide for police protection, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(1); Georgia Peace Officer Standards and Training Act, O.C.G.A. § 35-8-1 et seq.; compensation of municipal law enforcement officers to be by fixed salary only, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-9; municipality's liability for torts of police or other officers, O.C.G.A. § 36-33-3. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Chief of police. 
There shall be a person experienced and trained in law enforcement as the chief of the police department. The chief of police shall see that all penal sections of this Code are enforced; shall attend, in person or by duly authorized representative, all meetings of the mayor and council; and shall perform all other duties that may be required by the Charter, state law, this Code or otherwise as directed by the city manager. 
(Code 1972, § 11-12; Code 1994, § 54-1; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 7, 4-9-2018) 
Sec. 22-2. - Law enforcement officers and personnel. 
The chief of police, with approval and consent of the city manager, shall appoint police officers, marshals or other law enforcement officers as is deemed desirable and necessary, and budgeted. Such officers shall be responsible for the enforcement of this Code and shall perform such duties and acts as directed by the chief of police or as prescribed by this Code. 
(Code 1972, § 2-8; Code 1994, § 54-2; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 7, 4-9-2018) 
Sec. 22-3. - Duties of officers; policy. 
The primary responsibility of the police department shall be to ensure the safety and security of the person and property of each of its citizens. Therefore, it shall be the duty of law enforcement officers while on duty to maintain a vigilant patrol of all areas of the city. While free, orderly and lawful traffic flow on principal thoroughfares is most desirable, law enforcement officers are specifically directed not to neglect to give residential areas periodic and unscheduled patrol. 
(Code 1972, § 11-11; Code 1994, § 54-3) 
Sec. 22-4. - Agreement for prisoner incarceration. 
The mayor and council shall be authorized to enter into agreements with the county or other municipalities for the incarceration of persons arrested by law enforcement officers of the city. When such contracts are made, the mayor and council is authorized to pay a reasonable sum to the other contracting party for the maintenance of facilities and caring of the prisoners. 
(Code 1972, § 11-17; Code 1994, § 54-4) 
Secs. 22-5—22-26. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ALARM SYSTEMS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 22-27—22-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FALSE ALARMS 

Sec. 22-56. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
False alarm means any accident or occurrence wherein a private alarm system of any type is activated by any cause and which summons any public officer to the location of the alarm or which causes any public officer to begin traveling en route to the location of the alarm, when there in fact exists no emergency or other condition requiring the presence of such officer. 
(Code 1994, § 34-26; Ord. No. 93-1, § 1(a), 4-12-1993) 
Sec. 22-57. - Excessive number. 
It is declared by the mayor and council that more than two false alarms in any one month or more than six false alarms in any one year is excessive and constitutes a danger to the public safety by hindering public safety officials from performing their necessary and proper functions. 
(Code 1994, § 34-27; Ord. No. 93-1, § 1(b), 4-12-1993) 
Sec. 22-58. - Fees for excessive alarms. 
(a)  Any person who owns or occupies a building or lot upon which is located a private alarm system that experiences excessive false alarms shall be assessed a fee for each false alarm over and above those defined as excessive in amounts as established by the mayor and council from time to time. 
(b)  This fee is imposed whether the police department received the alarm by direct connection or any other source, such as an answering service or modified central station. No fee is imposed by this section when the choice is made to notify the police department directly by any person or in any situation. In determining whether an alarm is a false alarm, all circumstances shall be considered. 
(Code 1994, § 34-28; Ord. No. 93-1, § 1(c), (d), 4-12-1993) 
Chapter 24 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to establish, maintain and operate a municipal court, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1 et seq.; city courts generally, O.C.G.A. § 15-8-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - Established. 
There is established, pursuant to 1968 Ga. Laws (Act No. 1247), page 3712 et seq., a municipal court which shall have jurisdiction over violations of such act and this Code and other ordinances of the city. The court shall be presided over by a judge. 
(Code 1972, § 13-1; Code 1994, § 62-1) 
Sec. 24-2. - Summons, accusation, affidavit and warrant. 
Forms for municipal court summons, accusation, affidavit and warrant shall be as directed and prescribed by the judge. 
(Code 1972, § 13-6; Code 1994, § 62-2) 
Sec. 24-3. - Copies of charges. 
All copies of charges requiring persons to appear in the municipal court shall be dated the day of issuance, shall specify the charge being made, shall notify the person summoned of the date and hour for his appearance and shall be signed by the officer making the case. 
(Code 1972, § 13-7; Code 1994, § 62-3) 
Sec. 24-4. - Docket. 
A municipal court docket shall be kept in the office of the city clerk on which shall appear the name of every defendant charged and the charges made. The judge or alternate judge shall make an entry on the docket of the punishment inflicted and the date of such. If a fine is imposed, the clerk shall make entries showing the date of collection and the disposition of the funds collected. 
(Code 1972, § 13-8; Code 1994, § 62-4) 
Sec. 24-5. - Bond schedule. 
The municipal judge shall establish a schedule of bonds to be posted by persons accused of offenses against this Code or other city ordinances to guarantee the appearance of the offender in the municipal court. Property bonds or cash bonds shall be accepted. The judge is authorized to forfeit a bond when the accused does not appear in court in accordance with the summons or copy of charges given him. The clerk of court or his designee shall be responsible for approving property bonds and accepting cash bonds. He shall be personally accountable for all funds received by him as cash bonds. It is the intent of the mayor and council that cash bonds shall be administered by the city as set forth in this section and in accordance with O.C.G.A. §§ 9-10-10, 17-6-4 and 17-6-10. 
(Code 1972, § 13-10; Code 1994, § 62-5) 
Sec. 24-6. - Technology surcharge. 
There shall be imposed by the municipal court a technology surcharge in the amount of $10.00 per offense for all offenses except those set forth in O.C.G.A. §§ 40-8-76 and 40-8-76.1. Said technology surcharge shall be in addition to all other fines and fees imposed by the municipal court. All revenue derived from the technology surcharge shall be utilized by the city to provide technology support for the police department and related court technology. 
(Ord. No. 12-02, § 1(62-6), 2-13-2012) 
Secs. 24-7—24-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - JUDGE 

Sec. 24-31. - Qualifications. 
To be eligible to serve as judge, one must be at least 21 years of age, a citizen of the state and the United States and must have had at least one year of legal practice in the state or three years' service as a judge, magistrate or any other higher judicial position, and an active member in good standing of the State Bar of Georgia. 
(Code 1972, §§ 2-9, 13-2; Code 1994, § 62-26; Ord. of 2-25-1980) 
Sec. 24-32. - Oath. 
Before entering upon the discharge of any duties, the municipal judge shall take an oath administered by the mayor. The form of the oath shall be as follows: 
"I do solemnly swear that I will faithfully discharge the duties imposed upon me as judge of the City of Lake City for as long as I serve in such capacity and that I will administer justice to the best of my skill and ability without favor or affection for any person, so help me God." 
(Code 1972, § 13-3; Code 1994, § 62-27) 
Sec. 24-33. - Authority; holding court. 
(a)  The judge shall have full authority as judge of the municipal court for the administration of its affairs. He shall prescribe the dates and times for holding court; provided, however, that court shall always be held in the same place where council meetings are held and court shall be held as often as necessary to dispose of the business pending before the court. 
(b)  The judge shall have all of the powers conferred upon municipal courts by the laws of the state, including committals, binding over, forfeiture of bonds and the power of an ex officio magistrate in criminal cases. 
(Code 1972, §§ 13-4, 13-9; Code 1994, § 62-28) 
Sec. 24-34. - Alternate judge. 
In the absence or disqualification of the judge, municipal court may be held by an alternate designated by the mayor and council. The alternate judge, when presiding, shall have all the duties, powers and authority of the judge. The mayor or mayor pro tem may be the alternate so designated. 
(Code 1972, § 13-5; Code 1994, § 62-29) 
Secs. 24-35—24-56. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - INDIGENT DEFENSE ADMINISTRATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Peace Officer, Prosecutor, and Indigent Defense Funding Act, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-70 et seq. 

Sec. 24-57. - Rules and procedures adopted. 
The mayor and council adopts the rules and procedures set forth in this article for the defense of indigent criminal defendants. This article is a recompilation of rules in effect as of the time of its promulgation. No rule or procedure prescribed herein will be construed to supersede nor limit the power of the municipal court to appoint counsel and to order compensation and reimbursement from public funds, as the proper administration of justice may require. 
(Res. No. 03-02, 2-10-2003) 
Sec. 24-58. - Program compliance; designation of administrator. 
(a)  The mayor and council elects to utilize the panel attorney system to provide indigent defense services. 
(b)  The program established by this article shall be designed and administered to ensure compliance with all applicable laws, rules of court, and with the program guidelines promulgated from time to time by the state supreme court upon recommendation of the state indigent defense council. 
(c)  The city manager is designated to serve as the indigent defense administrator (IDA) to be responsible to the mayor and council for the day-to-day operation of the program. 
(Res. No. 03-02, § I, 2-10-2003; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 9, 4-9-2018) 
Sec. 24-59. - Panel attorneys. 
(a)  List. The IDA will maintain a list of attorneys designated by the mayor and council as eligible and willing to accept assignment of indigent cases. Application for inclusion of the panel shall be made on a form prescribed by the mayor and council and submitted through the IDA. 
(b)  General eligibility requirements. Attorneys wishing to be on the list for assignment of indigent cases must: 
(1)  Maintain membership in good standing with the State Bar of Georgia and with the Clayton County Bar Association; 
(2)  Comply with these rules and procedures, and in all ways conduct their practice in accordance with the requirements of law and in conformance with the highest ethical standards; 
(3)  Comply with the business licensing requirements applicable to the situs of their county office; and 
(4)  Be actively engaged in the practice of law in the county. For the purpose of this requirement, the term "practice of law in the county" is defined to include the following: 
a.  Maintenance of a private office for the attorney's exclusive, full-time use within the county. 
b.  Said office must be suitable for, and regularly used to meet with clients, witnesses, and other business visitors, and attorneys must regularly receive mail and telephone calls at said office. 
c.  Said office must contain, as a minimum, a desk and chair for the attorney's use on a full-time basis and is not to be shared with any other person. 
(c)  Applications and general administration. 
(1)  Application for inclusion on the panel for assignment of indigent cases shall include an affidavit of compliance with the general eligibility requirements as well as such specific indicia of compliance as the mayor and council may from time to time prescribe. The application will also include an agreement by the attorney to notify the mayor and council, through the IDA, of any change in information provided in the application. 
(2)  The IDA shall periodically require all panel attorneys to re-certify their eligibility by means of the application process. The IDA or any mayor and council member may require a panel attorney to re-certify eligibility at any time. 
(3)  Panel attorneys who wish to discontinue their service, either temporarily or permanently, must notify the IDA in writing giving the effective date. Attorneys will be required to complete all of their open cases unless relieved of this responsibility by the court before which a case is pending. In all such cases, panel attorneys must comply with all requirements set by statute or court rules pertaining to withdrawal as counsel of record. 
(4)  Panel attorneys taking temporary leaves of absence will notify the IDA in writing of the dates they will be unavailable to attend court events. 
(Res. No. 03-02, § II, 2-10-2003) 
Sec. 24-60. - Determination of indigency and entitlement to counsel at public expense. 
(a)  Financial eligibility shall be determined in accordance with paragraph 1.5 of the Guidelines of the Georgia Indigent Defense Council for the Operation of Local Indigent Defense Programs (hereinafter "guidelines"). 
(b)  The following persons are authorized to make eligibility determinations: 
(1)  The IDA, or a principal assistant when designated by the IDA to act in that capacity on a temporary basis; or 
(2)  Any judge or judicial officer of the municipal court. 
(c)  The IDA will establish procedures to ensure compliance with section 24-59 pertaining to availability of counsel. 
(Res. No. 03-02, § III, 2-10-2003) 
Sec. 24-61. - Assignment of cases to panel attorneys. 
(a)  Qualified cases will be assigned to panel attorneys on a rotational system. The IDA may make exceptions to this method of assignment in order to: 
(1)  Ensure balanced workload among panel attorneys; 
(2)  Assign complex cases to more experienced attorneys; and 
(3)  Serve the interests of justice. 
(b)  Panel attorneys are required to accept all cases as they are assigned unless prohibited from doing so by reason of conflict of interest or for other good cause. New charges against an indigent defendant upon whom a panel attorney has an open case will be assigned to that attorney, and attorneys who have open cases on an indigent defendant should respond to notices to appear on other charges concerning that same defendant. 
(c)  Panel attorneys are required to visit incarcerated defendants within 48 hours of assignment (weekends and county holidays excluded). 
(d)  Panel attorneys may, by prior agreement with the IDA, limit their practices to appeals only. No other limitations on practice are authorized. 
(e)  The mayor and council will normally require that newly admitted attorneys and those attorneys of limited experience in the practice of criminal law be assigned cases from a restricted category of offenses for the first year of their service on the panel. 
(Res. No. 03-02, § IV, 2-10-2003) 
Sec. 24-62. - Fee schedule and administration. 
(a)  Hourly rates: 
(1)  Out-of-court time spent in investigation and preparation, per hour: ..... $ 35.00 
(2)  Time spent in court, per hour: ..... 50.00 
(b)  Per diem rates (requires that attorney attend and actively represent a defendant in a hearing or other proceeding before a judicial officer): 
(1)  Municipal court: 
a.  Cases disposed by acquittal, nolo or guilty plea and sentence, and findings of guilty and sentence only: ..... 200.00 
b.  All other cases: ..... 100.00 
(c)  Dismissal, bench warrant, nolle pros, dead docket, or replacement by retained counsel subsequent to appointment, but prior to actual representation of defendant in court: ..... 100.00 
(d)  Maximum limitations of fees for misdemeanors: ..... 750.00 
(e)  Miscellaneous rules pertaining to fees: 
(1)  Panel attorneys are presumed to be knowledgeable of criminal law and procedure and will not normally be compensated for time spent researching or consulting on the law. Exception may be made for appeals and unusual circumstances fully documented and justified in the claim for compensation, or if approved and ordered by the judge hearing the case. 
(2)  All claims for compensation at the hourly rate will include a time sheet detailing the nature, dates, and time in hours allocated to services rendered. 
(3)  Time claimed at the hourly rate may not include travel time or in-court waiting time. 
(4)  Compensation at the hourly rate for attendance at calendar calls and status conferences will be limited to the lesser of one hour or time actually spent in court. 
(5)  Normally, a panel attorney will be expected to represent a defendant from the time the case is assigned through completion of direct appeal. Exceptions must be authorized by the assigned trial judge. A single claim for compensation will be submitted after final disposition of the case unless an exception is ordered by the judge hearing the case. 
(6)  All claims for fees and expenses will be presented to the IDA who shall forthwith adjudicate and pay the allowable amounts of such claims. If a claim exceeds the maximum limitation on fees allowable for the class of offense, it will be referred to the mayor and council for consideration of waiver and adjudication. 
(7)  A panel attorney dissatisfied with a determination of allowable fees and expenses made by the IDA may submit, to the IDA or to any mayor and council member, a written request for review by the mayor and council of the action taken by the IDA. The request for review must be received within 30 days of the date of the check issued in settlement of the claim, and it may contain any additional matter the attorney cares to present. It will indicate whether the attorney desires to attend the mayor and council's meeting in person. 
(8)  A panel attorney dissatisfied with the mayor and council's determination of allowable fees and expenses may request relief by petition to the court which heard the case. The court's determination will be final. 
(Res. No. 03-02, § V, 2-10-2003) 
Sec. 24-63. - Expenses. 
Panel attorneys will be entitled to recover items of unreimbursed expense necessarily incurred in the defense of the indigent, subject to the following: 
(1)  To recover expenses, panel attorneys must claim fees by hourly rate. Expenses will not be allowed in claims for compensation at the per diem rate. As an exception, and in order to encourage attorneys to accept a reasonable number of collect phone calls from incarcerated defendants only, actual costs up to a maximum amount of $25.00 per claim for such collect calls will be allowed on per diem claims. 
(2)  Incidental out-of-pocket expenses for such items as toll telephone calls and copying must be accompanied by a receipt or cash register tape if they exceed a unit cost of $10.00. 
(3)  Panel attorneys must obtain approval in advance, from the judge of the court before which a case is pending for the following types of expenses. The court order allowing the item of expense must accompany the claim for reimbursement. Failure to obtain prior judicial approval will result in the disallowance of the claimed expense and the attorney's personal liability to the service provider: 
a.  Employment of experts; 
b.  Stenographic or court reporting and transcribing services for proceedings not required by general law to be recorded, reported, or transcribed. 
(4)  Items of allowable expense may be advanced to the attorney or to the service provider only when specifically authorized by order of the court. Accounting for advances must accompany the attorney's final claim for reimbursement. 
(Res. No. 03-02, § VI, 2-10-2003) 
Secs. 24-64—24-84. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PROSECUTING ATTORNEY 

Sec. 24-85. - Short title. 
This article shall be known as the "Lake City Office of the Prosecuting Attorney of the Municipal Court Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 12-05, § 1(art. III, § 62-30), 7-9-2012) 
Sec. 24-86. - Findings and intent. 
The ordinance from which this article is derived is adopted to address requirements made under state law for the city to pass an ordinance or resolution creating the office of the prosecuting attorney of the municipal court should the city choose to hire or have a prosecuting attorney of the municipal court. Under state law, in order to have a municipal court prosecutor, the city must pass this ordinance or resolution and provide to the state prosecuting attorneys' council a copy of the same. The city is also required to submit the name of the person appointed to be the prosecuting attorney of the municipal court within 30 days of such appointment in order to maintain the office of the prosecuting attorney of the municipal court. It is therefore the intent of the city to comply with state law, particularly article 5 of chapter 18 of title 15 of the Official Code of Georgia, Annotated, and to enact the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(Ord. No. 12-05, § 1(art. III, § 62-31), 7-9-2012) 
Sec. 24-87. - Establishment of office. 
The office of the prosecuting attorney of the municipal court is hereby established for the purpose of providing representation of the city in matters pertaining to ordinance violations of the city and state offenses enforceable in the municipal court as allowed by state law. The prosecuting attorney for the municipal court shall be a part-time position. 
(Ord. No. 12-05, § 1(art. III, § 62-32), 7-9-2012) 
Sec. 24-88. - Qualifications. 
Any person appointed as the prosecuting attorney for the municipal court shall be a member in good standing of the State Bar of Georgia and admitted to practice before the trial and appellate courts of the state. Nothing in this article shall prevent the city from appointing the city attorney to be the prosecuting attorney for the municipal court, so long as all other requirements under the law are met. 
(Ord. No. 12-05, § 1(art. III, § 62-33), 7-9-2012) 
Sec. 24-89. - Oath. 
The prosecuting attorney of the municipal court shall take and subscribe to the following oath: 
"I swear (or affirm) that I will well, faithfully, and impartially and without fear, favor, or affection discharge my duties as Prosecuting Attorney of the Municipal Court for the City of Lake City." 
(Ord. No. 12-05, § 1(art. III, § 62-34), 7-9-2012) 
Sec. 24-90. - Term of office. 
Unless otherwise provided by the city Charter, the prosecuting attorney for the municipal court shall serve a term as shall be prescribed by the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 12-05, § 1(art. III, § 62-35), 7-9-2012) 
Sec. 24-91. - Jurisdiction, duties, and authority. 
The office of the prosecuting attorney of the municipal court shall have the duty and authority to represent the city as defined by the city Charter and by state law, particularly as described in O.C.G.A. § 15-18-96. 
(Ord. No. 12-05, § 1(art. III, § 62-36), 7-9-2012) 
Sec. 24-92. - Assistant prosecuting attorney. 
The prosecuting attorney of the municipal court may appoint one or more assistant prosecuting attorneys whose appointment shall be ratified by the mayor and council before becoming an assistant prosecuting attorney for the municipal court. Such assistant prosecuting attorney shall be a member in good standing of the State Bar of Georgia or satisfy the provisions of the Third Year Practice Act, found in the O.C.G.A. § 15-18-22. 
(Ord. No. 12-05, § 1(art. III, § 62-37), 7-9-2012) 
Sec. 24-93. - Ratification. 
This article shall ratify all actions that have been taken by the persons acting in the positions of the office of the prosecuting attorney for the municipal court to date as authorized by the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 12-05, § 1(art. III, § 62-38), 7-9-2012) 
Chapter 26 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Limitation on home rule powers of municipal corporations with respect to duplication of state criminal offenses, Ga. Const. art. III, § VI, ¶ IV; O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2); Criminal Code of Georgia, O.C.G.A. § 16-1-1 et seq.; nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-1 et seq.; jurisdiction of municipal court or magistrate court to abate nuisance, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5; abandoned motor vehicles generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Disorderly conduct. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in disorderly conduct within the corporate limits of the city. A person commits the offense of disorderly conduct when such person does any of the following: 
(1)  Acts in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another person whereby such person is placed in reasonable fear of the safety of such person's life, limb, or health; 
(2)  Acts in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another person whereby the property of such person is placed in danger of being damaged or destroyed; 
(3)  Without provocation, uses to or of another person in such other person's presence, opprobrious or abusive words which by their very utterance tend to incite to an immediate breach of the peace (that is to say, words which as a matter of common knowledge and under ordinary circumstances will, when used to or of another person in such other person's presence, naturally tend to provoke violent resentment, that is, words commonly called "fighting words"); 
(4)  Without provocation, uses obscene and vulgar or profane language in the presence of or by telephone to a person under the age of 14 years which threatens an immediate breach of the peace; or 
(5)  Recklessly or knowingly commits any act which may reasonably be expected to prevent or disrupt a lawful meeting, gathering or procession. 
(Code 1994, § 66-1; Ord. No. 91-02, §§ 1, 2, 6-10-1990; Ord. No. 98-04, 10-12-1998) 
Sec. 26-2. - Obscene, vulgar and profane language. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use any obscene, vulgar or profane language in the hearing of others or commit any act of public indecency or quarrel in a manner calculated to disturb the public peace. 
(Code 1994, § 66-2; Ord. of 5-21-1970, § 11) 
Sec. 26-3. - Injuring, defacing public property. 
It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to willfully, maliciously, wantonly, negligently or otherwise injure, deface, destroy, tamper or interfere with or remove real property or improvements thereto or moveable or personal property belonging to or under supervision or control of the city. 
(Code 1994, § 66-3; Ord. of 5-21-1970, § 12) 
Sec. 26-4. - Firearms discharge. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any firearm in the corporate limits of the city except in defense of person or property. This section shall not apply to authorized officers of the law. 
(Code 1994, § 66-4; Ord. of 5-21-1970, § 13) 
Sec. 26-5. - Slingshots; bows and arrows; air rifles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use, discharge or shoot any slingshot, air rifle or gun discharged by the forcing of air, gas, pressure or any other manner or any bow and arrow in the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1994, § 66-5; Ord. of 5-21-1970, § 14) 
Sec. 26-6. - Dangerous knives and implements. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to have, possess or carry upon the streets, alleys, sidewalks or in any public place any of the following implements, unless such are securely wrapped so as not to be readily available for harmful use: 
(1)  A knife that has a blade which opens automatically by hand pressure applied to a button, spring or other device in the handle, the blade of which when open projects from the handle more than two inches. 
(2)  A knife that has any obstruction or other device of any kind which holds the blade partly open, the blade of which when open projects from the handle more than two inches. 
(3)  A knife of any kind, the blade of which when open projects from the handle more than three inches. This is intended to include all knives such as butcher knives and knives that do not close and any type knife with the blade open. 
(4)  A razor or razor blade. 
(5)  An ice pick or similar device having a sharp point; except that this subsection shall not apply to any person delivering ice. 
(Code 1994, § 66-6; Ord. of 5-21-1970, § 15) 
Sec. 26-7. - Abandonment of iceboxes, refrigerators and airtight containers. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to leave outside of any building or dwelling in a place accessible to children any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator or any container of any kind that has an airtight door or lock that may not be released for opening from the inside of the icebox, refrigerator or container. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to leave outside of any building or dwelling in a place accessible to children any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator or any other container of any kind that has an airtight door with snap lock or other similar device on the door of the icebox, refrigerator or container. 
(Code 1994, § 66-7; Ord. of 5-21-1970, § 20) 
Sec. 26-8. - Open wells and excavations. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner, occupant or person to permit any open well or hazardous excavation to remain or exist on the property under the control of such owner, occupant or person. 
(Code 1994, § 66-8; Ord. of 5-21-1970, § 21) 
Sec. 26-9. - Preventing of disrupting lawful meetings, gatherings, or processions. 
A person who intends to disrupt, by actions which substantially impair the ordinary conduct of activities or a meeting occurring at any house of worship, home for the elderly or property which is federally funded, state subsidized or owned by private nonprofit or private citizen, or any lawful meeting, gathering, or procession of others both inside/outside and/or surrounding properties around those previously described, is guilty of preventing or disrupting lawful meetings, gatherings, or processions. 
(Ord. No. 98-02, 10-12-1998) 
Sec. 26-10. - Graffiti. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Graffiti means any text, picture, drawing or other visual depiction placed upon any property without the written permission, either express or implied, of the property owner when such text, picture, drawing or other visual depiction is visible from any public right-of-way or any adjacent property. 
Graffiti implement or paraphernalia means any substance or material such as, but not limited to, aerosol paint containers, permanent ink markers, paint sticks, and etchers; also including, but not limited to, tips or nozzles which can be applied to aerosol paint containers. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place graffiti upon the property of another. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of property upon which graffiti is placed to allow the graffiti to remain on the property more than seven days after receipt of written notice from the city of the placement of the graffiti on the property. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess any graffiti implement or paraphernalia while in, on, at or about any public property, including, but not limited to, public parks, playgrounds, swimming pools, recreation facilities, schools, school district facilities, libraries, court houses, utility stations, storm drains or any other publicly owned, operated and/or maintained facility. This subsection shall not apply to any officer, employee or agent of the public entity that owns the property. 
(e)  Violations of this section shall be punishable pursuant to section 1-8. 
(Ord. No. 03-07, § 1(66.9), 6-14-2003) 
Sec. 26-11. - Public drunkenness. 
A person who shall be and appear in an intoxicated condition in any public place or within the curtilage of any private residence not his own other than by invitation of the owner or lawful occupant, which condition is made manifest by boisterousness, by indecent condition or act, or by vulgar, profane, loud, or unbecoming language, is guilty of the offense of public drunkenness. 
(Ord. No. 98-03, 10-12-1998) 
Sec. 26-12. - Loitering or prowling. 
(a)  A person commits the offense of loitering or prowling when he is in a place at a time or in a manner not usual for law-abiding individuals under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity. 
(b)  Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether alarm is warranted is the fact that the person takes flight upon the appearance of a law enforcement officer, refuses to identify himself, or manifestly endeavors to conceal himself or any object. Unless flight by the person or other circumstances make it impracticable, a law enforcement officer shall, prior to any arrest for an offense under this section, afford the person an opportunity to dispel any alarm or immediate concern which would otherwise be warranted by requesting the person to identify himself and explain his presence and conduct. No person shall be convicted of an offense under this section if the law enforcement officer failed to comply with the foregoing procedure or if it appears at trial that the explanation given by the person was true and would have dispelled the alarm or immediate concern. 
(Ord. No. 98-01, 10-12-1998) 
Secs. 26-13—26-42. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MINORS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 26-43—26-72. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CURFEW 

Sec. 26-73. - Hours when effective. 
No minor under the age of 17 years shall be or remain in or upon the public streets, alleys, parks, playgrounds, public grounds, public places, public buildings, public places of amusement and entertainment, vacant lots or other unsupervised public places within the city between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 5:00 a.m. 
(Code 1994, § 66-41; Ord. No. 07-01, § 1(66-41), 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 26-74. - Exceptions. 
This division shall not apply to a minor accompanied by the minor's parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of the minor or when the minor is upon an emergency errand or legitimate business directed or authorized by the minor's parent, guardian or such other adult person having the care and custody of the minor. 
(Code 1994, § 66-42; Ord. No. 07-01, § 1(66-42), 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 26-75. - Responsibility of parents. 
It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of a minor under the age of 17 years to knowingly permit such minor to be or remain in or upon the public streets, alleys, parks, playgrounds, public grounds, public places, public buildings, public places of amusement and entertainment, vacant lots or other unsupervised public places within the city between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 5:00 a.m. except when the minor is accompanied by the minor's parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of the minor or when the minor is upon an emergency errand or legitimate business directed or authorized by the minor's parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of the minor. 
(Code 1994, § 66-43; Ord. No. 07-01, § 1(66-43), 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 26-76. - Responsibility of officers. 
It shall be the right of any authorized officer or person to arrest and detain any minor violating the curfew established in this division and to keep the minor detained until the parent, guardian or custodian is notified. The minor may be released upon the receipt and execution by the minor and the minor's parent or guardian or custodian of a citation stating that such minor, together with the minor's parent, guardian or custodian will appear at a stated time before the proper authority to answer to the charges. 
(Code 1994, § 66-44; Ord. No. 07-01, § 1(66-44), 3-12-2007) 
Chapter 28 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Power to provide parks, recreation areas, programs and facilities, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(5); authority of municipality to construct and operate parks, swimming pools, golf courses, recreation grounds and buildings used for sports, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3; establishment of recreation systems authorized, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-1 et seq. 

Sec. 28-1. - Establishment and maintenance of parks and recreational facilities. 
The mayor and council is authorized to establish and maintain parks and recreational facilities in the corporate limits. The mayor and council may contract with persons, firms or other political subdivisions for the furnishing of such facilities and services to the citizens of the city. The mayor and council shall have all of the powers in this regard as are granted to municipalities in the state, including but not limited to those powers granted by O.C.G.A. § 36-64-1 et seq. 
(Code 1972, § 9-1; Code 1994, § 70-1) 
Sec. 28-2. - Use of grounds, etc. 
(a)  Use of grounds and facilities in general. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, association, or corporation using the city parks, ball fields, facilities and grounds to fail to clean up debris, extinguish all fires when fires are permitted and leave the premises in as good an order and the facilities in as neat and sanitary condition as when they began use of facilities. 
(b)  Prohibited acts. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, association, or corporation using the city parks, ball fields, facilities or grounds to either perform or permit to be performed any of the following acts: 
(1)  Willfully mar, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with, displace or remove any buildings, tables, benches, signs, notices, placards, permanent monuments, statues, boundary markers, structures, fixtures, equipment, facilities, park property or appurtenances thereof whatsoever, either real or personal; 
(2)  Damage, cut, carve, transplant, or remove any tree or plant or any part thereof; 
(3)  Bring in, dump, deposit or leave any bottles, broken glass, ashes, paper boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish, waste, garbage, refuse, or other trash. No such refuse or trash shall be placed in storm sewers, drains, waters or contiguous to any park, or left anywhere on the grounds thereof, but shall be placed in the proper receptacles where these are provided, and where not provided all rubbish or waste shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for the presence of such rubbish or waste, and properly disposed of elsewhere; 
(4)  Disturb the peace, or use any profane or obscene language; 
(5)  Endanger the safety of any person by any conduct or act; 
(6)  Take part in or abet the playing of any game involving thrown or otherwise propelled objects, such as balls, stones, arrows, javelins, or model airplanes, except in areas set apart for such forms of recreation. The playing of rough or potentially dangerous games such as football, basketball, handball, and soccer is prohibited, except on fields, courts, or areas provided therefor; 
(7)  Vend, sell, peddle, or offer for sale any commodity or article within any park area or facility, unless authorized in writing by the city; 
(8)  Bring any dangerous animal or any dog into any park area except as provided by special permit when such activity is part of an approved special event; 
(9)  Ride or cause to be ridden any horse, mule, or pony on any property in the park areas except as provided by special permit when such activity is part of an approved special event; 
(10)  Drive or park any automobile or off-road vehicle, except on a street, driveway, or parking lot in any park; or to park or leave any such vehicle on any place other than one established for public parking; 
(11)  Set up tents, shacks, or other temporary shelter for the purpose of overnight camping, nor shall any person leave any movable structure or special vehicle to be used, or that could be used for such purposes, such as a house trailer, camp trailer, wagon, or the like in the park area after closing hours, unless authorized by the city; 
(12)  To tamper with, break into or enter any facility or park area that is secured by locks or padlocks; 
(13)  To have any motorized vehicle or bicycle on any jogging track or ball field; 
(14)  To carry or use firearms in any park; 
(15)  Throw, discharge or otherwise place or caused to be placed in the waters of any fountain, pond, lake, stream, or other body of water in or adjacent to any park or any tributary, stream, storm sewer or drain flowing into such waters, any substance, matter, or thing, liquid or solid, which will or may result in the pollution of such waters; 
(16)  Build or attempt to build a fire, except in such areas and under such regulations as may be designated by the city. No person shall drop, throw, or otherwise scatter lighted matches, burning cigarettes or cigars, tobacco paper or other inflammable material within any park area or on any highway, road, or street abutting or contiguous thereto; 
(17)  Have in his possession, custody or control, or consume any alcoholic beverage, drug or any illegal substance, unless as otherwise allowed by resolution of the mayor and council; 
(18)  Barbecue anywhere other than in barbecue pits provided by the city or in areas designated for the use of portable above-ground grills; 
(19)  Paste, glue, tack or otherwise post any sign, placard, advertisement or inscription whatsoever, erect or cause to be erected any sign whatsoever on any public lands, highways, or roads adjacent to a park; and 
(20)  Perform any act which is prohibited by this Code. 
(Code 1994, § 70-2; Ord. No. 96-4, § 1, 8-22-1996; Ord. No. 96-05, § 1, 8-22-1996) 
Chapter 30 - SOLID WASTE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to provide for garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. 1983, art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(2); Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; Litter Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-40 et seq.; transporting garbage or waste across state or county boundaries without permission, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-16; littering highways, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-249. 

Sec. 30-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Approved container means a receptacle or roll-top garbage or recycling container approved by the city or provided by the city's contractor. 
Bags means plastic or paper sacks designed to store and enclose yard trimmings, with sufficient wall strength to maintain physical integrity when lifted by the top. The total weight of a bag with contents shall not exceed 40 pounds. 
Bulky waste means stoves, refrigerators, water heaters, automobile parts, washing machines, furniture and other waste materials other than construction debris, dead animals or hazardous waste, with the weights or volumes greater than those allowed for approved containers. 
Construction debris means waste building materials resulting from construction, remodeling, repair or demolition operations. 
Dead animals means animals or portions thereof equal to or greater than ten pounds in weight that have died from any cause, except those slaughtered or killed for human consumption. 
Garbage means waste paper and plastics, normal household disposable items, any or all dead animals of less than ten pounds in weight except for those slaughtered for human consumption; every accumulation of waste (animal, vegetable and/or other matter) that results from the preparation, processing, consumption, dealing in, handling, packing, canning, storage, transportation, decay or decomposition of meats, fish, fowl, birds, fruits, grains or other animal or vegetable matter, including, but by no way limited to, used tin cans and other food containers, and all putrescible or easily decomposable waste animal or vegetable matter. 
Hazardous waste means any chemical, compound, mixture, substance or article which is designated by the United States Environmental Protection Agency or an appropriate agency of the state to be hazardous, as that term is defined by federal or state law or regulations. 
Producer means an occupant of a residential unit who generates waste. 
Recycling materials means materials which would otherwise become solid waste which, if collected, separated, or processed are capable of being reused or returned to use in the form of raw materials or products. Recycling materials shall include, but are not limited to, HDPE and PET plastics; clear, green and brown glass; old newsprint; and aluminum and bi-metal cans. 
Refuse means all ashes, bulky waste, construction debris, dead animals, garbage, recycling materials, trash, and yard trimmings. 
Residential unit means a single-family or two-family dwelling within the city occupied by a person or group of persons. A residential unit shall be deemed occupied when water services, either public or private, are being supplied thereto. Each unit of an apartment or condominium dwelling, whether a single-level or multilevel construction, shall be treated as a residential unit; provided that any multifamily complex provided with dumpster service in lieu of approved containers for each housing unit shall be excluded from this definition. 
Trash means all waste wood, wood products, combustible waste pulp and other products such as are used for packaging or wrapping crockery and glass, ashes, cinders, and any or all other waste materials not included in the definitions of "bulky waste," "construction debris," "dead animals," "garbage," or "hazardous waste." 
Yard trimmings means leaves, brush, grass clippings, shrub and tree limbs and prunings, discarded Christmas trees, nursery and greenhouse vegetative residuals, and vegetative matter resulting from landscape development and maintenance other than mining, agricultural, and silvicultural operations; provided, however, that the term "yard trimmings" shall not include limbs or other materials generated by commercial gardeners, tree services, and the like. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1(86-1), 2-12-1996) 
Sec. 30-2. - Collection by city required; exceptions. 
(a)  All garbage, recycling materials, and yard trimmings accumulated in the city shall be collected, conveyed and disposed of by the city or by the city's contractor except as otherwise expressly authorized in this chapter. Use of the city collection and disposal system shall be required of all residential units in the city. 
(b)  No person shall collect, convey over any of the streets or alleys of the city or dispose of any refuse accumulated in the city, except as expressly authorized in this chapter or as allowed by pertinent and appropriate actions of the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1(86-2), 2-12-1996) 
Sec. 30-3. - City garbage collection; container requirements. 
(a)  All garbage shall be deposited in approved containers. 
(b)  The owner or occupant of the premises where garbage is located shall utilize the receptacle or roll-top garbage container provided by the city's contractor or shall be responsible for providing approved containers as set forth in this chapter and a refusal to do so shall constitute a violation of this chapter. 
(c)  Where more than one residential unit is located in a building, the container shall be marked so as to indicate the dwelling unit using the particular container. The container may be identified by placing the apartment number thereon or the name of the person having control of the disposal of the garbage in the unit. When containers are so identified, such containers may only be used by the person whose name or other identification is shown thereon. 
(d)  When, in the opinion of the city clerk or his designee, the amount of garbage generated by a multifamily building makes individual garbage collection impractical, the city clerk or his designee may require the owner of the building to install one or more dumpsters of such capacity as to be determined to be necessary to adequately containerize waste generated in the building and may discontinue individual collection services. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1(86-3), 2-12-1996) 
Sec. 30-4. - Accessibility of containers. 
(a)  Producers having authority to control the disposal of garbage, recycling material, or yard trimmings in any residential unit shall cause all such materials collected therein to be placed in an approved container and placed at the curb on scheduled collection days. Unless an exemption is granted from this requirement, approved containers shall be moved by producers to curbside no earlier than 4:00 p.m. on the day preceding collection and shall be returned to their storage location on the side or rear yard of the property no later than 9:00 a.m. on the day following collection. 
(b)  Exemptions from the requirement for placement of approved containers at curbside may be granted by the city clerk for a producer with physical limitations which prevent placement of the approved container at the curb, provided that such person submits a written request for an exemption and the exemption is approved in writing by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1(86-4), 2-12-1996) 
Sec. 30-5. - Deposit in containers. 
All garbage shall be daily deposited in the approved containers. Approved containers shall be kept tightly covered at all times except when it is necessary to lift the cover in order to deposit garbage in the approved container. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1(86-5), 2-12-1996) 
Sec. 30-6. - Maintenance of containers. 
It shall be the responsibility of the occupant of each residential unit to maintain the approved container serving his unit in a clean and sanitary manner, free of obnoxious odors, maggots, insects and rodents, or any other condition which may render the container unhealthy to the occupants of the premises or the neighborhood. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1(86-6), 2-12-1996) 
Sec. 30-7. - Disposal. 
All approved containers shall be emptied and disposition made of the contents thereof according to the city's collection schedule, but in no event less than one time per week. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1(86-7), 2-12-1996) 
Sec. 30-8. - Collection of bulky waste, construction debris, and other materials. 
(a)  Construction debris and similar materials resulting from the construction, alteration, repair or demolition of buildings or structures must be removed by the owner of the property or the person performing such work. 
(b)  Bulky waste must be removed by the owner or occupant of the property or shall be subject to special collections at terms and conditions specified by the city or the city's contractor. 
(c)  Waste products of industrial plants and spent oils or greases accumulated at garages, filling stations, or similar establishments must be removed by the owner of the property or occupant of the premises. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1(86-8), 2-12-1996) 
Sec. 30-9. - Recycling materials and yard trimmings. 
(a)  All recycling materials shall be placed in approved recycling containers and shall be emptied and disposition made of the contents thereof according to the city's collection schedule, but in no event less than one time per week. 
(b)  All yard trimmings shall be placed in bags and disposition made of the contents thereof according to the city's collection schedule, but in no event less than one time per week; provided, however, that limbs shall not be in excess of four feet in length and three inches in diameter, and that all limbs shall be secured in bundles and shall not exceed 40 pounds in total weight per collection day. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1(86-9), 2-12-1996) 
Sec. 30-10. - Items not collectible. 
The following items are not collectible by the city: 
(1)  Construction debris; 
(2)  Dirt or rocks; 
(3)  Heavy car parts; 
(4)  Tires; 
(5)  Hazardous waste, including, but not limited to, HTH, paint, oil, car batteries; 
(6)  Metal drums, 35-gallon size or larger; 
(7)  Dead animals; 
(8)  Items weighing in excess of 75 pounds; and 
(9)  Bulky waste. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1(86-10), 2-12-1996) 
Sec. 30-11. - Unlawful disposal. 
No person shall place any refuse in any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place, or upon any private property, whether owned by such person or not, within the city, unless it is placed in approved containers for collection as authorized in this chapter or under express written approval by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1(86-11), 2-12-1996) 
Sec. 30-12. - Unauthorized accumulations. 
Any unauthorized accumulation of refuse on any premises is hereby declared to be a violation of this chapter. Failure to remove any existing accumulation of refuse within 48 hours after being directed to do so by the city clerk shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1(86-12), 2-12-1996) 
Sec. 30-13. - Scavenging. 
No person, other than the owner thereof, or an agent of the city clerk, or any employee of an entity which has a franchise from the city for the collection of refuse, shall interfere with any container placed for the purpose of storing refuse pending collection, or remove or take any of the contents thereof, or remove any such container from the location where the container has been placed by the owner thereof. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1(86-13), 2-12-1996) 
Sec. 30-14. - Commercial collection. 
(a)  All owners and occupants of commercial and industrial property, as well as owners of multifamily property not served by city collection crews, shall contract with a private refuse collector which has obtained a franchise from the city for the regular collection and disposal of refuse generated at their facility. 
(b)  All persons who collect, transport or dispose of refuse from commercial, industrial or multifamily property in the city shall obtain a franchise from the city to provide such service and shall conduct their activities in full compliance with state laws and regulations and city ordinances regulating the collection, transportation or disposal of such waste, and, upon failure to do so, shall be subject to prosecution for such violations. 
(c)  The city shall determine the size, capacity and location of both containers or dumpsters used for the storage of refuse on commercial, industrial or multifamily property pending collection. Where the volume of refuse generated on the premises exceeds the capacity of the bulk container or dumpster provided, the city may require a larger container to be installed. 
(d)  Owners and occupants of commercial, industrial and multifamily property serviced by bulk containers or dumpsters shall maintain the area immediately surrounding the container free of unsightly refuse at all times. Such owner or manager shall be responsible for instructing all employees in the proper method for the use of the container and shall ensure that all refuse is placed completely within the container, with all doors and lids to be closed at all times the container is not being loaded or emptied. 
(e)  All commercial, industrial and multifamily property utilizing bulk containers or dumpsters shall provide upon the premises an accessible hard-surfaced space of sufficient size to accommodate the container. The hard-surfaced area shall have sufficient driving area to permit reasonable ingress and egress by collection vehicles. No building permit shall be issued by the building inspector for new construction unless appropriate plans and specifications are submitted setting forth and meeting the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1(86-14), 2-12-1996) 
Sec. 30-15. - Penalties. 
Failure to perform any act required by this chapter, or the performing of any act prohibited by this chapter, shall constitute an offense and shall subject the offender to prosecution in the municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1(86-16), 2-12-1996) 
Sec. 30-16. - Debris carried or dropped onto public streets by vehicles. 
(a)  No person shall operate or cause to be operated upon any public street in the city any truck, wagon, or other vehicle, in and upon which sand, dirt, rocks, cement, garbage, trash, waste materials, or other debris or materials, is transported unless such vehicle shall be equipped with a cover or other device that will prevent such sand, dirt, rocks, cement, garbage, trash, waste materials, or other debris or materials, from falling from the vehicle onto the streets of the city. 
(b)  Any person performing work on private property which requires movement of vehicles from the public streets onto such private property shall be responsible for the cleanup of all dirt, mud, gravel or other debris tracked from the private property onto the public street by such vehicles. Cleanup of streets shall be completed no later than 5:00 p.m. of each day. 
(c)  No person conducting a business adjacent to a public street shall maintain a yard or lot, pavement or covering of gravel, or other substances in such a manner that the gravel or other substances are movable upon being walked upon or driven over by vehicles going to and from the place of business unless such materials are so placed and maintained that the gravel or other substances will not get into or upon the adjacent public street. 
(Ord. No. 90-54, § 1, 8-12-1991) 
Sec. 30-17. - Regulations adopted. 
(a)  The city hereby adopts and incorporates by reference as if set out at length herein the model litter control ordinance (hereinafter referred to as the "regulations"). 
(b)  At least one copy of the regulations shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(c)  Where reference is made in the regulations to the duties of certain officials named therein, the designated official of the city who has duties corresponding to those of the named official in the regulations shall be deemed to be the responsible official insofar as enforcing the provisions of the regulations is concerned, and the term "jurisdiction" shall mean the city. 
(d)  Incorporation by reference. A copy of the regulations described in subsection (a) of this section is attached to the ordinance from which this section is derived as Exhibit A and incorporated herein by reference. 
(Ord. No. 05-03, §§ 1(86-10), 2, 6-13-2005) 
Sec. 30-18. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Section 86-10 pertaining to the sanitation tax as enacted by § 2 of Ord. No. 11-01, adopted Oct. 10, 2011, has been moved to appear under chapter 36, Taxation, as per the instructions of the city during the 2014 recodification of the city Code. Section 1 of Ord. No. 11-01, adopted Oct. 10, 2011, amended the entirety of section 8 of chapter 86 of the Code of Ordinances by removing all substantive text under the section and reserving the section. 
Chapter 32 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— City has power to construct and maintain roads, including curbs, sidewalks, street lights and devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4); municipal street systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-90 et seq.; powers with respect to municipal street system, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-92; regulation of maintenance and use of public roads generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1 et seq.; municipal authority to regulate alleys, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 32-1. - House numbering. 
The mayor and council shall provide a uniform numbering system for all property in the city. It shall be the duty of each property owner to secure the correct number for his property from the code enforcement officer and thereafter to display the assigned number in a conspicuous place on the property so that the number is clearly discernible from the street. 
(Code 1972, § 15-3; Code 1994, § 90-1) 
Sec. 32-2. - Display of merchandise. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to display any merchandise, product or equipment for sale, trade or barter on any public street, street right-of-way, sidewalk or park of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 15-5; Code 1994, § 90-2) 
Sec. 32-3. - Excavations in streets or sidewalks. 
(a)  No excavation shall be made in the right-of-way of any public street or sidewalk located within the city limits except by the city or, for utility installation or repair, a public utility company, a cable company, the Clayton County Water Authority (CCWA), or a franchisee of any of these entities. 
(b)  Any entity other than the city desiring to conduct an excavation (hereinafter referred to as "the entity") in the right-of-way of any public street or sidewalk located within the city limits shall obtain from the city a permit for excavation at least 48 hours before beginning excavation, except in the case of an emergency threatening life or property, in which case the entity shall contact the police department as soon as reasonably practicable and fulfill the requirements of a permit application as set out in this section within 24 hours of beginning excavation. 
(c)  In order to obtain a permit, the entity shall submit a written application to the city clerk, which application shall show the location where the excavation will occur, its purpose, the approximate number of square yards of surface to be cut, an address at which the entity consents that the city may properly serve on the entity notice of any matter concerning the excavation, and the name of a representative (hereinafter referred to as "the representative") of the entity. The entity shall also comply with any conditions, including posting of a bond, required by the city clerk in writing. 
(d)  For the protection of the public health, safety, and welfare, the entity shall take such precautionary actions, including but not limited to the provision of markers, warning lights or barricades, as the circumstances dictate. 
(e)  All costs of excavation and compliance with this section shall be assumed by the entity, and the entity agrees, as a condition of the issuance of a permit, to indemnify and hold harmless the city against any claims or expenses, including but not limited to attorney fees, for bodily injury or property damage arising out of the entity's excavation operations. 
(f)  Upon completion of the excavation, the entity shall restore the area excavated to essentially the same condition that existed prior to the excavation. Additionally, all excess debris and refuse, including but not limited to excess pavement, concrete, bricks and lumber, shall be removed from the site by the entity. 
(g)  In the event the entity conducts an excavation pursuant to the emergency repair provision contained in subsection (b) of this section and the city determines that no emergency in fact existed, the entity responsible for such excavation shall be deemed to have failed to comply with this section. Additionally, any entity conducting an emergency repair designates as its representative any person performing such work. 
(h)  In the event the entity fails to comply with the requirements of this section, the representative of the entity, any person (whether an employee of the entity, a subcontractor of the entity, or an employee of a subcontractor of the entity) at the excavation site on behalf of the entity, and the entity itself shall be jointly and severally subject to a penalty as provided under section 1-8. 
(Code 1972, § 15-6; Code 1994, § 90-3; Ord. No. 99-02, § 1(90-3), 11-8-1999) 
State Law reference— Georgia Utility Facility Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 25-9-1 et seq. 
Sec. 32-4. - Damaging streets and sidewalks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle or equipment on, over or upon any street, sidewalk or other public property when the vehicle or equipment causes damage to the street, sidewalk or other public property. 
(Code 1972, § 15-9; Code 1994, § 90-4) 
Sec. 32-5. - Public nudity prohibited. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Nudity means showing of the human male or female genitals, pubic area or buttocks with less than a fully opaque covering; or the showing of the female breast with less than a fully opaque covering of any part of the nipple. 
Public place means all outdoor places owned by or open to the general public, all locations, whether indoor or outdoor, that are visible from any public right-of-way or any adjacent property, and all buildings and enclosed places owned by or open to the general public, including such places of entertainment, taverns, restaurants, clubs, theaters, dance halls, banquet halls, party rooms or halls limited to specific members, restricted to adults or to patrons invited to attend, whether or not an admission charge is levied. 
(b)  The mayor and council find that public nudity creates a threat to the public health, safety, welfare and morals. Among the potential harmful effects of public nudity are: accidents in various situations, including traffic accidents, caused by the inherently distractive nature of public nudity; decrease in property values near places where public nudity occurs regularly; decrease in business at commercial establishments located near places where public nudity occurs regularly; risk of unsanitary deposit of human excrement. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly or intentionally, in a public place, to appear in a state of nudity. 
(d)  The prohibition set forth in this section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Any child under ten years of age; or 
(2)  Any female exposing a breast in the process of nursing a child. 
(Ord. No. 03-03, § 1(90-5), 4-14-2003) 
Secs. 32-6—32-28. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 32-29. - Water drainage on sidewalks. 
No person shall erect or maintain any drain, gutter, downspout, valley or roof in such a manner as to allow such to drain or shed water on any sidewalk in the city. 
(Code 1972, § 15-7; Code 1994, § 90-26) 
Sec. 32-30. - Maintenance. 
It shall be unlawful for the occupant of any improved property which abuts a paved sidewalk to fail to keep the sidewalk clean and free from dirt, trash, grass, ice and snow or to place or cause to be placed thereon any object which interferes with the free and unfettered use of the sidewalk by the public or which interferes with surface water drainage. 
(Code 1972, § 15-8; Code 1994, § 90-27) 
Secs. 32-31—32-48. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STREETS 

Sec. 32-49. - Dedication. 
No dedication to the city of property to be used as a street, alley or other public use shall be valid until such has been accepted in writing by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1972, § 15-1; Code 1994, § 90-51) 
Sec. 32-50. - Naming. 
The mayor and council shall have the power to name public streets, erect street signs and change the names of streets. 
(Code 1972, § 15-2; Code 1994, § 90-52) 
Sec. 32-51. - Obstructions. 
The city shall not and does not grant to any person the right to erect or maintain a structure or obstruction in a public street. It shall be unlawful for any person to place or cause to be placed in any street or alley any dirt, lumber, building material, trash or other material or object so that such interferes with the free and unfettered use of the street or alley by the public or which interferes with surface water drainage. 
(Code 1972, § 15-4; Code 1994, § 90-53) 
State Law reference— Grant of right to obstruct public street prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-10. 
Sec. 32-52. - Debris carried or dropped by vehicles. 
(a)  No person shall operate or cause to be operated upon any public street any truck, wagon or other vehicle in and upon which sand, dirt, rocks, cement, garbage, trash, waste materials or other debris or materials are transported unless such vehicle shall be equipped with a cover or other device that will prevent such sand, dirt, rocks, cement, garbage, trash, waste materials or other debris or materials from falling from the vehicle onto the streets. 
(b)  Any person performing work on private property which requires movement of vehicles from the public streets onto such private property shall be responsible for the cleanup of all dirt, mud, gravel or other debris tracked from the private property onto the public street by such vehicles. Cleanup of streets shall be completed no later than 5:00 p.m. of each day. 
(c)  No person conducting a business adjacent to a public street shall maintain a yard or lot, pavement or covering of gravel or other substance in such a manner that the gravel or other substance is movable upon being walked upon or driven over by vehicles going to and from the place of business unless such material is so placed and maintained that the gravel or other substance will not get into or upon the adjacent public street. 
(Code 1994, § 90-54; Ord. No. 91-3, § 1, 8-12-1991) 
Chapter 34 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Recording of maps and plats, O.C.G.A. § 15-6-67 et seq.; subdivisions abutting state highways, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-150 et seq.; the Zoning Procedures Laws, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq.; Georgia Land Sales Act, O.C.G.A. § 44-3-1 et seq. 

Sec. 34-1. - Regulations adopted by reference. 
(a)  Except where such regulations may otherwise conflict with specific provisions contained within chapter 42, pertaining to zoning, the county subdivision regulations, as adopted and amended through May 22, 2008, are hereby adopted as the subdivision regulations of the city and are incorporated by reference into this chapter as fully as though set out at length herein. A current copy of the subdivision regulations shall be maintained on file in the office of the city clerk where it shall be available for public inspection. 
(b)  Where reference is made in the county subdivision regulations to the duties of certain officials named therein, the city manager or his designee shall be deemed to be the responsible official for the city insofar as administrating and enforcing the provisions of the regulations is concerned. 
(c)  Where reference is made in the county subdivision regulations to the duties of certain county departments, boards, committees, or advisory groups named therein, shall be deemed to be the mayor and city council or their designee insofar as administrating and enforcing the provisions of the regulations is concerned. 
(d)  Where reference is made in the county subdivision regulations to a specific article or section of the county zoning ordinance, it shall be deemed to be a reference to similar subject matter as it appears in the corresponding article or section of the city's zoning regulations contained in chapter 42. 
(e)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in the county subdivision regulations, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Board of county commissioners means the mayor and council of the City of Lake City, Georgia. 
County means the City of Lake City, Georgia. 
County zoning ordinance means chapter 42 of the Lake City Code, pertaining to zoning. 
Jurisdiction means the City of Lake City, Georgia. 
Local enforcement authority means the City of Lake City, Georgia. 
Local government means the City of Lake City, Georgia. 
Local permitting authority means the City of Lake City, Georgia. 
(Code 1994, § 92-1) 
Sec. 34-2. - Conflicts. 
(a)  In the event that the county subdivision regulations in any way conflict with the provisions of chapter 42, pertaining to zoning, said chapter 42 shall prevail. 
(b)  Where general subdivision and construction requirements of the county subdivision regulations conflict with specific subdivision and construction requirements in the city Code, including but not limited to floodplain management, soil erosion and sedimentation control, grading, stormwater management, driveways, outdoor parking and display areas of businesses, stream buffer protection regulations, conservation subdivision development, house numbering, landscaping of commercial and professional building lots, and road construction for commercial and residential construction projects, then the provisions concerning the specific subdivision and construction requirements in the city Code shall prevail. 
Chapter 36 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Taxation power of municipal and county governments, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV, ¶ I(a) and (b)(2); ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 36-1—36-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AD VALOREM TAX 

Sec. 36-19. - Levy; sanitation tax. 
(a)  Levied. For the purposes of raising revenues and funds for the general administration of city government, there shall be levied and collected an annual ad valorem tax of five mills applied to a 40 percent valuation of fair market value upon all real and personal property, including money, notes, bonds and other evidences of indebtedness, money used in banking and every other species of property in the city owned or held therein subject to taxation. 
(b)  Sanitation tax. 
(1)  An annual sanitation tax for the collection and disposal of waste from improved single-family residential properties within the city is hereby levied and assessed against all improved single-family residential properties which are to be served or benefited by the city's removal of garbage therefrom and against the owners thereof within the city. Such sanitation tax shall be due in one annual payment and shall be assessed and collected by the city in the same manner, subject to the same penalties for late payment, and at the same time as other ad valorem taxes otherwise collected. 
(2)  The sanitation tax rate for each year until changed by ordinance shall be assessed against the real property and to the real property owner and shall be as follows: 
a.  Residential. Per single-family residential structure ..... $204.00
