(3)  For such sanitation tax, the city shall have a lien against such building lot and the improvements thereon and the owner thereof, which lien shall be prior and superior to any and all other liens except state and county tax liens, and except that it shall be equal to any liens the city may have against such property for city taxes. 
(4)  In lieu of payment of this sanitation tax, all properties which are exempt from ad valorem taxes under state law shall be billed for all sanitation service received from the city via a monthly bill to the registered address of the owner of such property. 
(Code 1972, § 16-1; Code 1994, § 94-26; Ord. No. 92-2, § 1, 4-13-1992; Ord. No. 11-01, § 2(86-10), 10-10-2011) 
Sec. 36-20. - Duties of chief of police. 
Under this article, it shall be the duty of the chief of police to: 
(1)  Keep a file of all newspapers in which his official advertisements appear. 
(2)  Keep an execution docket in which he shall enter a full description of all executions levied by him on any kind of property, showing the property levied on, the date of levy and the service of levy notice, together with all his acts and doings thereon. 
(3)  Keep a book in which shall be entered a record of all sales made by him, describing the property and the process under which sold, the date of the levy and sale and the name of the purchaser and the price. 
(4)  Keep the book required by subsection (3) of this section indexed for each entry therein. 
(Code 1972, § 16-16; Code 1994, § 94-27) 
Sec. 36-21. - Payment. 
All ad valorem taxes due the city on all property in the city subject to taxation shall be due and payable annually on or before November 20 in each year. All unpaid taxes shall bear interest at 12 percent per annum from the date when due. 
(Code 1972, § 16-2; Code 1994, § 94-28; Ord. of 8-8-1974) 
Sec. 36-22. - Execution for failure to pay. 
When any person shall fail to pay the ad valorem tax imposed by the city according to law, the city clerk shall issue execution for the tax. The execution shall be signed by the city treasurer, attested by the city clerk and directed to the chief of police to levy such on the goods, chattels, lands and tenements of the defendant or so much thereof as shall be sufficient to satisfy the taxes and costs. This execution shall bind all the property, real and personal, of the defendant and the costs thereof shall be the same as on tax collector's executions under the laws of the state. Upon receipt of the execution or fieri facias, it shall be the duty of the chief of police, forthwith, to levy such upon the defendant's property. 
(Code 1972, § 16-10; Code 1994, § 94-29; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 8, 4-9-2018) 
Sec. 36-23. - Notice and sale of real property. 
When the chief of police levies on real property under this article, notice of the levy in form substantially similar to O.C.G.A. § 48-3-10, shall be given to the property owner and record owner of each security deed and mortgage affecting such property. If the real estate is vacant property, such notice shall be served upon the owner of the property, if a resident of the city, personally, or by leaving the notice at his most notorious place of abode. If such property is vacant and the owner is not a resident of the city, notice of the levy shall be given to him at his last known address, by certified mail, return receipt requested. All notice required in this section shall be given at least 20 days before the property is sold. Real property levied upon shall be advertised for sale once a week for four weeks next preceding the date of sale in the official organ of the county and notice shall be provided to the property owner as required by O.C.G.A. § 48-4-1. Sales shall be held on the first Tuesday in each month between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. at the place where the last city election was held. Sales shall be conducted by the chief of police at public outcry to the highest bidder for cash. 
(Code 1972, § 16-11; Code 1994, § 94-30; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 8, 4-9-2018) 
Sec. 36-24. - Notice and sale of personal property. 
When the chief of police levies on personal property under this article, he shall give notice of the levy to the owner if known. If the owner is a resident of the city, such notice shall be personally given or by leaving a copy of the notice at his most notorious place of abode. If the owner is a nonresident, notice of the levy shall be given him at his last known address by certified mail, return receipt requested. The requirements as to term of notice, advertisement and sale as set forth in section 36-23 and applying to real property shall apply to personal property under this section. 
(Code 1972, § 16-12; Code 1994, § 94-31) 
Sec. 36-25. - Making title after sale. 
The chief of police is authorized to make proper bills of sale and deeds of title to real and personal property purchased at public sales pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1972, § 16-13; Code 1994, § 94-32) 
Sec. 36-26. - Purchase by the city. 
The city treasurer may, on behalf of the city, bid the amount of ad valorem tax and costs on property sold for tax by the chief of police, where no one else bids that amount. The city clerk shall keep a record of all such purchases made by the city and file deeds and bills of sale executed by the chief of police to the city. The chief of police shall put the city clerk in possession of the property purchased by the city, and the city clerk shall be authorized to rent out the property and deposit rentals collected in the city treasury. The clerk shall keep a record of all amounts thus received for rent. 
(Code 1972, § 16-14; Code 1994, § 94-33; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 8, 4-9-2018) 
Sec. 36-27. - Redemption of property. 
(a)  An owner desiring to redeem real or personal property purchased by the city at tax sale may do so within one year from the date of sale by satisfying his debt to the city. 
(b)  Whenever any real property is sold under and by virtue of any tax execution issued in pursuance of the Charter and this Code, the owner thereof, his agent or attorney or the vendor of the land when the purchase money has not been paid shall have the right and privilege of redeeming the land thus sold within one year from the time of sale, by paying the purchaser thereof the amount paid by such purchaser for the land, with legal interest thereon, and a ten percent premium. 
(Code 1972, § 16-15; Code 1994, § 94-34) 
Sec. 36-28. - Sale of property purchased by the city. 
Property purchased by the city at the tax sales for city taxes and which has been held by the city under deed made in pursuance of the sale for one year shall be sold and disposed of by the city as follows: 
(1)  The city clerk shall present to the mayor and council at any regular or called meeting thereof a full description list of all property so purchased by the city and which has been so held by the city for one year. 
(2)  The mayor and council may then, by resolution, direct a sale of all or such portion of the property as in the judgment of the mayor and council should be sold. Such direction being given, it shall be the duty of the chief of police to advertise such property for sale once a week for four weeks before a regular sheriff's sale day, and to have notice of such sale served on the owner by certified mail, return receipt requested, at their last known address. A return of the service of whatever notice is given shall be made by the chief of police or party giving the notice as in cases of regular tax sales, before the city hall door. The chief of police shall sell or have sold the property to the highest bidder for cash, and each piece of the property shall be sold separately. 
(Code 1972, § 16-17; Code 1994, § 94-35; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 8, 4-9-2018) 
Sec. 36-29. - Title of property sold given by city. 
Purchasers at such sale as provided in section 36-28 shall receive from the city a quitclaim deed, to be executed by the mayor upon the payment of the purchase money to the city clerk or the chief of police. For failure to comply with the bids, the city shall have the same alternatives and remedies as prescribed by state law for sheriff's sales. 
(Code 1972, § 16-18; Code 1994, § 94-36) 
Sec. 36-30. - Reclaiming property sold. 
Whenever any personal property has been levied upon by the chief of police by virtue of any execution in favor of the city, the chief of police may, in his discretion, allow the defendant in fi. fa. to replevy the property under the same rules and conditions as prescribed for sheriffs and constables in the state, and the bonds thus taken shall be collectible in the same manner prescribed for the collection of forthcoming bonds taken by sheriffs and constables of the state or the chief of police may receive money in pledge instead of bond. 
(Code 1972, § 16-19; Code 1994, § 94-37) 
Chapter 38 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Cities are authorized to exercise power over parking facilities and traffic control devices, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4) and (11); power of local authorities with respect to uniform rules of the road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-370 et seq.; jurisdiction of municipal courts over misdemeanor traffic offenses, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-21(a). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 38-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Commercial vehicle means every vehicle designed, maintained or used primarily for the transportation of property. 
Curb loading zone means a space adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or materials. 
Established place of business means the place actually occupied either continuously or at regular periods by a dealer or manufacturer where his books and records are kept and a large share of his business is transacted. 
Farm tractor means every motor vehicle designed and used primarily as a farm implement, for drawing plows, mowing machines and other implements of husbandry. 
Freight curb loading zone means a space adjacent to a curb for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of freight or passengers. 
Official time standard, whenever certain hours are named in this chapter, means standard time or daylight saving time, as may be in current use in the city. 
Passenger curb loading zone means a place adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading and unloading of passengers. 
Registration means the registration certificate and registration plates issued under the laws of the state pertaining to the registration of vehicles. 
Road tractor means every motor vehicle designed and used for drawing other vehicles and not so constructed as to carry any load thereon independently or any part of the weight of a vehicle or load so drawn. 
Traffic control device means any device, whether manually, electrically or mechanically operated, by which traffic is alternately directed to stop and permitted to proceed. 
Traffic division means the traffic division of the police department or, if a traffic division is not established, the police department. 
(Code 1972, § 17-1(6), (8), (11), (13), (15), (25), (30), (40), (43), (56), (57); Code 1994, § 98-1) 
Sec. 38-2. - Adoption of state law; penalty for violation. 
(a)  O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-1—40-6-395, known as the Uniform Rules of the Road, and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 are adopted as and for the traffic rules of the city with like effect as if recited in this chapter. 
(b)  Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any section of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00 or by imprisonment of not more than 60 days, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Code 1994, § 98-2; Ord. of 9-13-1983(1)) 
Sec. 38-3. - Police administration. 
Traffic control in the city shall be the direct responsibility of the chief of police and those officers employed in the police department assigned to duty in traffic control. In addition to any other duty imposed upon the police department in this Code, the department and the officers therein shall have the duty to: 
(1)  Enforce the street traffic rules of the city and of the state; 
(2)  Make arrests for traffic violations; 
(3)  Investigate accidents; 
(4)  Issue summons when justified; 
(5)  Cooperate with other officers and officials of the city and the mayor and council in the administration of traffic laws and in developing ways and means to improve traffic conditions; and 
(6)  Carry out those duties imposed upon the department and the officers therein by this chapter. 
(Code 1972, § 17-2; Code 1994, § 98-3) 
Sec. 38-4. - Traffic engineering. 
The city may, from time to time, require traffic engineering assistance in planning and studying traffic problems. The mayor and council may, when the need arises, contract for such services with a person offering such or may enter into a contract with the county or another municipality to provide such services. 
(Code 1972, § 17-3; Code 1994, § 98-4) 
Sec. 38-5. - Records of traffic violations. 
The police department shall keep a record of all violations of this chapter and of the state vehicle laws of which any person has been charged, together with a record of the final disposition of all such alleged offenses. These records shall be filed alphabetically under the name of the person charged and shall be permanent records and public records. 
(Code 1972, § 17-4; Code 1994, § 98-5) 
Sec. 38-6. - Investigation of accidents. 
It shall be the duty of the police department to investigate traffic accidents, to arrest and to assist in the prosecution of those persons charged with violations of law causing or contributing to such accidents. 
(Code 1972, § 17-5; Code 1994, § 98-6) 
Sec. 38-7. - Records of traffic accidents. 
The police department shall maintain a suitable system of filing traffic accident reports. These records shall be permanent and public records. 
(Code 1972, § 17-6; Code 1994, § 98-7) 
Sec. 38-8. - Traffic accident studies. 
Whenever the traffic accidents at any particular location become numerous, the chief of police shall make a study of such location and such accidents and make a recommendation to the mayor and council for remedial measures. 
(Code 1972, § 17-7; Code 1994, § 98-8) 
Sec. 38-9. - Annual traffic safety report. 
Between January 15 and January 30 of each year, the chief of police shall prepare a traffic report which shall be filed with the mayor. Such report shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The number of charges made for each category of traffic offense. 
(2)  The number of traffic accidents investigated, the number of persons killed and the number of persons injured. 
(3)  The recommendations of the police department to improve traffic safety. 
(Code 1972, § 17-8; Code 1994, § 98-9) 
Sec. 38-10. - Authority of police and fire personnel. 
Officers of the police department are authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand or signal in conformance with traffic laws, provided that, during a fire, an accident or other emergency or to expedite traffic or to safeguard pedestrians, such officers may direct traffic as conditions may require. Personnel of the fire department, when at the scene of a fire, may direct or assist the police in directing traffic thereat or in the immediate vicinity. 
(Code 1972, § 17-9; Code 1994, § 98-10) 
Sec. 38-11. - Reports to state department of public safety and other state agencies. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police to see that timely reports are filed with the state department of public safety and other agencies of the state when required by law. 
(Code 1972, § 17-10; Code 1994, § 98-11) 
Sec. 38-12. - Coasters, roller skates and similar devices. 
No person upon roller skates or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device shall go upon any roadway, except while crossing a street on a crosswalk. When so crossing such person shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians. 
(Code 1972, § 17-13; Code 1994, § 98-12) 
Sec. 38-13. - Crosswalks and safety zones. 
The chief of police, with the approval of the mayor and council, is authorized to: 
(1)  Designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections and elsewhere where in his opinion there is a danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway. 
(2)  Establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as he may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians. 
(Code 1972, § 17-15; Code 1994, § 98-13) 
Sec. 38-14. - Traffic lanes. 
The chief of police, with approval of the mayor and council, is authorized to mark traffic lanes upon the roadway of any street or highway where a regular alignment of traffic is necessary. 
(Code 1972, § 17-16; Code 1994, § 98-14) 
Sec. 38-15. - Traffic control devices. 
(a)  Authority to install. The chief of police, with the approval of the mayor and council, shall place and maintain official traffic control devices when and as required under this chapter to make this chapter effective and may place and maintain such additional official traffic control devices as he may deem necessary to regulate, warn or guide traffic under this chapter or state law. 
(b)  Specifications. All traffic control signs, signals and devices shall conform to the specifications contained in the Georgia Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways, as revised. All signs and signals required for a particular purpose shall so far as practicable be uniform as to type and location throughout the city. All traffic control devices so erected and not inconsistent with state law or this Code shall be official traffic control devices. 
(Code 1972, § 17-17(A), (B); Code 1994, § 98-15) 
Sec. 38-16. - Stopping, standing or parking. 
(a)  The mayor and council may from time to time prohibit the parking, stopping and standing of vehicles in certain areas and along certain roadways where it is deemed such prohibition to be desirable to protect life, limb and property and to facilitate the orderly flow of traffic. When such limitations are established, the mayor and council shall adopt a resolution to that effect and cause signs to be erected warning the public of the prohibition. 
(b)  In addition to those areas where the parking, standing and stopping of vehicles are prohibited as provided in subsection (a) of this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to stop, stand or park a vehicle: 
(1)  On a crosswalk or within ten feet thereof. 
(2)  Within any area marked as a coach or bus stop. 
(3)  On the roadway side of any other vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street. 
(4)  In any area along a street where the curb has been painted yellow, provided that such painting is authorized by the mayor and council. 
(5)  Along any street whereby the nature of the street as to width, grade or curvature would impede traffic and create conditions dangerous to life, limb and property. 
(6)  For the purpose of washing, greasing or repairing a vehicle except for the purpose of making emergency repairs. In such an emergency, such vehicle shall be moved or towed away with dispatch unless the vehicle has been involved in an accident in which event the vehicle shall not be moved except at the direction of an officer. 
(c)  When any police officer finds a vehicle standing, stopped or parked in violation of this section, such officer is authorized to move such vehicle or require the owner, driver or person in charge of the vehicle to move the vehicle to a safe and lawful point. 
(d)  When any police officer finds a vehicle unattended and standing, stopped or parked in violation of this section, such officer is authorized to see to the removal of such vehicle to a lawful and safe place. 
(e)  The removal or moving of a vehicle under subsections (c) and (d) of this section shall not prevent or preclude prosecution for violating this section. 
(f)  Whenever any motor vehicle without a driver is found standing, stopped or parked in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by the city or by state law, the officer finding such vehicle shall take its registration number and may take any other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user and shall conspicuously affix to such vehicle a traffic citation on a form provided by the city for the driver to answer to the charge against him at a specified time and a specified place. In any prosecution charging a violation of any law or restriction governing the standing or parking of a vehicle, proof that the vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of any such law or restriction, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time of such parking the registered owner of the vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of the vehicle was the person who parked or placed the vehicle at the point where and for the time during which the violation occurred. 
(g)  The mayor and council may by resolution provide for the establishment, installation and maintenance of parking meters in the city. 
(h)  Specific parking restrictions. 
(1)  Except as otherwise provided in this section and in section 38-18, it shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle on any street; only off-street parking shall be permitted. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person, including but not limited to the owner or user of any vehicle described herein or anyone owning, renting, leasing, or in possession of property described herein, to allow any vehicle on any property having frontage along a residential street to be parked on any surface other than an impervious surface under the entire base of the vehicle. 
(3)  Temporary parking. 
a.  Notwithstanding subsection (h)(1) and (2) of this section, this section shall not hinder any nonresident from temporarily parking his vehicle on a residential street during temporary visits to a residence which has all available impervious surface (e.g., concrete or asphalt) or gravel surface parking spaces utilized by other vehicles. 
b.  Notwithstanding subsection (h)(3)a of this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to temporarily park any vehicle on a residential street for more than six hours at any time during the day or night. 
c.  Notwithstanding subsection (h)(3)a of this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle on any street in such a manner as to reduce the width of the navigable portion of the street to less than 14 feet. 
(4)  For the purposes of this section, the term "residential street" shall include the following areas: Forest Hill Court, Laurel Circle, High Point Court, Laurel Street School Lane, Woodland Way, Ahyoka Drive, Wahsega Way, Trahlyta Terr., Tsali Trail, Sanders Drive, Ellington Street, Sanders Way, Helen Street, Eubanks Drive, Jones Court, Grove Court, Orchard Place, Lakeland Circle, Dellwood Circle, Huron Drive, Erie Place, Ontario Avenue. 
(i)  Violations of this section shall be punishable pursuant to section 1-8. 
(Code 1972, § 17-19(A), (B)5, 6, 13, 15—18, (C)—(G); Code 1994, § 98-16; Ord. No. 01-01, § 1(98-16), 3-12-2001; Ord. No. 03-09, § 1(98-16), 6-9-2003) 
Sec. 38-17. - Stop signs and yield right-of-way signs. 
(a)  The mayor and council may by resolution specifically designate certain streets or parts of streets as through streets. When such is done it shall be the duty of the chief of police to see to the placement and maintenance of a stop sign or a yield right-of-way sign at appropriate places at each intersection of such through street or part thereof. 
(b)  The mayor and council may by resolution direct the chief of police to see to the placement and maintenance of a stop sign or a yield right-of-way sign at any intersection in the city where it is determined that a hazardous condition exists and such sign is necessary to prevent loss of life, limb or property. 
(Code 1972, § 17-20(A), (B); Code 1994, § 98-17) 
Sec. 38-18. - Large vehicles. 
(a)  Parking in residential areas. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or store on property having a residential zoning classification, any large vehicle, in excess of 10,000 pounds, gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR), provided that a person may temporarily park such a vehicle in a residential area while actually engaged in delivery of products or services, including loading and unloading operations, while the driver is on duty and remains with the vehicle. For the purposes of this section, the term "large vehicle" means tractors, trailers, cabs, trucks, busses, vehicle carriers, tow trucks, towing vehicles, and truck cabs, but shall not include pickup trucks with no special equipment and which are used for personal transportation only. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to store in a residential area any parts of the vehicles described in subsection (a)(1) of this section or their accessories, including materials hauled by the vehicles, unless such storage has been approved by the mayor and council. 
(3)  Recreational vehicles, when parked in the rear yard on an impervious surface (e.g., concrete, asphalt) or a gravel surface permitted under section 38-16(h), are specifically excluded from the prohibition contained in this subsection. 
(4)  For the purposes of this subsection, the term "recreational vehicles" means vehicles that are used primarily for recreational purposes, are not used primarily for transportation, and are not used for commercial purposes. 
(b)  Moving across curb. No large vehicle, cab, trailer, truck or tractor trailer, as designated in subsection (a) of this section, shall be pulled, pushed or in any way moved across any curb in the city without prior permission from the police department. 
(c)  Servicing. It shall be unlawful to service a vehicle, as designated in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, except for emergency service as may be rendered upon permission of the police department. 
(Code 1994, § 98-18; Ord. of 8-12-1980(1), § 17-26; Ord. No. 01-01, § 2(98-18), 3-12-2001) 
Sec. 38-19. - Off-road vehicles. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-7-5, the following shall apply within the city: 
(1)  No off-road vehicle shall be operated in an area zoned for residential use. 
(2)  Any area used for off-road vehicles must first be established for this use and approved by the mayor and council. 
(3)  No off-road vehicle shall be operated in an area adjacent to a zoned residential area, if the area of operation is within 1,000 feet of the zoned residential area. 
(4)  In areas where off-road vehicles are allowed to operate, the hours of operation shall be restricted to the hours between 10:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. 
(Code 1994, § 98-19; Ord. of 5-22-1979) 
State Law reference— Off-Road Vehicle Act of 1975, O.C.G.A. § 40-7-1 et seq.; enforcement and penalties, O.C.G.A. § 40-7-6. 
Sec. 38-20. - Use of traffic control signal monitoring devices; penalty. 
(a)  The city elects to use traffic control signal monitoring devices within the jurisdictional limits of the city as provided by O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20(f). 
(b)  The driver of a motor vehicle shall be liable for a civil monetary penalty of not more than $70.00 per violation if such motor vehicle is found, as evidenced by recorded images produced by a traffic control signal monitoring device, to have been operated within the city limits in disregard or disobedience of a circular red or red arrow signal in violation of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20(f). 
(c)  The police department shall send by first-class mail addressed to the owner of the motor vehicle postmarked not later than ten days after the date of the alleged violation: 
(1)  A citation for the violation, which shall include the date and time of the violation, the location of the intersection, the amount of the civil monetary penalty imposed, and the date by which the civil monetary penalty shall be paid; 
(2)  A copy of the recorded image; 
(3)  A copy of a certificate sworn to or affirmed by a trained law enforcement officer or a technician employed by a law enforcement agency for which such device is authorized and stating that, based upon inspection of recorded images, the owner's motor vehicle was operated in disregard or disobedience of a circular red or red arrow signal in violation of subsection (a) of this section and that such disregard or disobedience was not otherwise authorized by law; 
(4)  A statement of the inference provided by O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20(d) which is herewith incorporated by reference and of the means specified therein by which such inference may be rebutted; 
(5)  Information advising the owner of the motor vehicle of the manner and time in which liability as alleged in the citation may be contested in court; and 
(6)  Warning that failure to pay the civil monetary penalty or to contest liability in a timely manner shall waive any right to contest liability and result in a civil monetary penalty; 
however, only warning notices and not citations for violations shall be sent during the 30-day period commencing with the installation of a traffic control signal monitoring device at such location. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, § (a)(98-20), 5-8-2006) 
Sec. 38-21. - Signage required for use of traffic control signal monitoring devices. 
(a)  Prior to placing any traffic control signal monitoring devices in use, the public works department shall erect a sign on every highway that comprises a part of the state highway system at that point on the highway which intersects the jurisdictional limits of the city. 
(b)  The department of public works shall also erect a sign on each public road on the approach to the next traffic control signal for such road when a traffic control device is monitoring such next signal for such road, subject to inspection. 
(c)  Such signs shall be at least 30 inches by 30 inches in measurement and shall warn motorists that traffic control signal monitoring devices are being employed. 
(d)  The city project manager shall inspect and certify the placement of all required signage before placing any traffic control signal monitoring devices in use and shall periodically inspect to ensure that the required signage has not been removed, modified or otherwise rendered ineffective. It shall be the duty of the city project manager to replace and re-erect such signage as required by law or this chapter during all times the traffic control signal monitoring device program is in effect within the city. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, § (a)(98-21), 5-8-2006) 
Sec. 38-22. - Traffic control signal monitoring program. 
(a)  The city project manager shall operate a traffic control signal monitoring program using approved traffic control signal monitoring devices in strict accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-20(f) and 40-6-20 through 40-14-24. All definitions of terms used therein are expressly incorporated by reference for the purposes of this chapter. 
(b)  The timing of any traffic control signal which is being monitored by a traffic control signal monitoring device shall conform to regulations promulgated by the state department of transportation pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 32-6-50. The city project manager shall cause each traffic control signal monitoring device placed in operation within the city to be independently tested for accuracy by a qualified technician, other than its manufacturer, at regular intervals and record and maintain the results of each test. The test results log shall be a public record subject to inspection. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, § (a)(98-22), 5-8-2006) 
Sec. 38-23. - Reporting of traffic control signal monitoring device use. 
The city project manager or his designee shall submit not later than February 1 of each year a report on traffic control signal monitoring device use during the preceding calendar year to the governor, the lieutenant governor, the speaker of the house of representatives, the board of commissioners, the city manager, and the judge of the municipal court. Such report shall include: 
(1)  A description of the locations where the traffic control signal monitoring devices were used; 
(2)  The number of violations recorded at each location and in the aggregate on a monthly basis; 
(3)  The total number of citations issued; 
(4)  The number of civil monetary penalties and total amount of such penalties paid after citation without contest; 
(5)  The number of violations adjudicated and results of such adjudications, including a breakdown of dispositions made; 
(6)  The total amount of civil monetary penalties paid; and 
(7)  The quality of the civil adjudication process and its results. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, § (a)(98-23), 5-8-2006) 
Sec. 38-24. - Designation of city project manager. 
For purposes of administering this chapter and any traffic control signal monitoring program operated in accordance herewith, the chief of police is hereby designated as the city project manager. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, § (a)(98-24), 5-8-2006) 
Secs. 38-25—38-51. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DISPLAYING MOTOR VEHICLES FOR SALE 

Sec. 38-52. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Display for sale means to display or affix any sign, marking or other device on or to a motor vehicle in such manner as to be visible to passing motorists or pedestrians and which indicates the vehicle is available for alienation. 
Motor vehicle means every vehicle which is self-propelled. Boats and trailers will be included in this category. 
Vehicle sales lot means an area maintained by a business, licensed for the sale of new or used motor vehicles, and upon which such vehicles are parked for display in conjunction with such business. 
(Code 1994, § 98-41; Ord. of 11-8-1988, § 1(A)) 
Sec. 38-53. - Exemptions. 
This article shall not apply to the parking of motor vehicles on vehicle sales lots. 
(Code 1994, § 98-42; Ord. of 11-8-1988, § 1(E)) 
Sec. 38-54. - Parking on private property. 
No person shall park any motor vehicle on private property in such a manner as to display it for sale, except in accordance with the following: 
(1)  The vehicle owner or his agent shall obtain a permit from the city clerk for display of each vehicle. The clerk shall charge such fee as fixed from time to time by the mayor and council for issuance of a permit. 
(2)  No person may display for sale more than one motor vehicle owned by him at one time. 
(3)  No person may display for sale more than three motor vehicles owned by him within any period of 12 consecutive months. 
(4)  No vehicle owner may display a motor vehicle for sale on property owned by another without the written consent of the property owner, and no property shall be used to display more than three motor vehicles for sale in any period of 12 consecutive months. 
(Code 1994, § 98-43; Ord. of 11-8-1988, § 1(B)) 
Sec. 38-55. - Parking on public property. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, no person shall park any motor vehicle on public property in such a manner as to display it for sale. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit the use or parking of a vehicle in conjunction with legitimate entertainment or shopping so long as the vehicle is lawfully parked in a parking space or lot available for such use and the duration of such parking does not exceed the time devoted to such entertainment or shopping. 
(Code 1994, § 98-44; Ord. of 11-8-1988, § 1(C), (D)) 
Secs. 38-56—38-83. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SPEED LIMITS 

Sec. 38-84. - Maximum speed. 
Unless otherwise posted, the maximum speed that an automobile, truck, tractor, motorcycle or other motor-driven vehicle may be driven or operated on any street, highway or thoroughfare in the corporate limits shall be 30 miles per hour. However, the mayor and council may from time to time establish greater or lesser limits in school zones, in areas of congestion and in areas where the mayor and council deem the operation at 30 miles per hour to be dangerous to life, limb and property or in areas where a greater speed is authorized as a result of traffic and road conditions. When such greater or lesser limits are established, the mayor and council shall adopt a resolution to that effect and shall cause signs to be erected warning the public of the differing speed restriction. 
(Code 1972, § 17-18; Code 1994, § 98-66) 
Sec. 38-85. - Speed zones. 
(a)  The following speed zones are established: 
(1)  For on-system zones, with signs to be erected by the state department of transportation, see the latest state speed zone order for the county as effected and issued by the state departments of transportation and public safety. The state speed zone order is adopted in this subsection by reference thereto for those sections of state routes located within the city limits. 
(2)  Off-system zones, with signs to be erected by the city, shall consist of the following segments and the maximum speed for each segment: 

 
Ratteree Drive, from Forest Parkway to Burks Drive, a distance of 0.30 mile\35 
Forest Parkway, from a point 300 feet west of Victory Boulevard to North Parkway, a distance of 0.40 mile\50 
Forest Parkway, from North Parkway to State Road 54, a distance of 1.10 miles\45 
Harper Drive, from Rex Road to Northlake Drive, a distance of 0.50 mile\40 
Harper Drive, from Northlake Drive to State Road 54, a distance of 0.40 mile\35 
Huie Road, from State Road 54 to Reynolds Road, a distance of 0.30 mile\35 
Kenyon Road, from White Drive to State Road 54, a distance of 0.50 mile\35 
Laurel Street, from Phillips Drive to Forest Hills Court, a distance of 0.30 mile\25 
North Parkway, from Forest Parkway to Harper Drive, a distance of 0.80 mile\40 
Northlake Drive, from Forest Parkway to Harper Drive, a distance of 0.70 mile\35 
Phillips Drive, from a point 300 feet north of Warner Street to Kenyon Road, a distance of 0.35 mile\30 
Phillips Drive, school zone, from Woodland Drive to Kenyon Road, a distance of 0.25 mile, from 7:30 a.m. to 8:30 a.m. and 2:30 p.m. to 3:45 p.m., school days only, for Lake City Elementary School\25 
Rex Road from Trammell Road to North Parkway, a distance of 0.80 mile\40 
Rex Road, from Northlake Drive to State Road 54, a distance of 0.40 mile\35 
Reynolds Road, from a point 0.10 mile south of Huie Road to White Drive, a distance of 0.60 mile\35 
Trahlyta Terrace, from White Drive to dead end, a distance of 0.25 mile\25 
Tsali Trail, from White Drive to dead end, a distance of 0.30 mile\25 
White Drive, from Reynolds Road to Kenyon Road, a distance of 0.25 mile\35 
Woodland Drive, from Phillips Drive to Helen Street, a distance of 0.30 mile\25 
(b)  Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished as provided by law. 
(Code 1994, § 98-67; Ord. No. 93-2, 4-12-1993) 
Chapter 42 - ZONING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to adopt plans and exercise the power of zoning, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ IV; the Zoning Procedures Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq.; local government zoning powers, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-2; conflicts of interest in zoning actions, O.C.G.A. § 36-67A-1 et seq.; effect of zoning laws on covenants running with the land, O.C.G.A. § 44-5-60. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 42-1. - Preamble. 
For the several purposes of promoting the health, safety, morals, convenience, order, prosperity or the general welfare of the present and future inhabitants of the city; of improving the city's appearance; lessening congestion in the streets; furthering traffic safety; securing safety from fire, panic and other dangers; providing adequate light and air; preventing the overcrowding of land, avoiding both undue concentration of population and urban sprawl; facilitating the adequate provision of transportation, water, sewerage, schools, parks and other public requirements; protecting property against blight and depreciation; encouraging the most appropriate use of land, buildings, and other structures throughout the city; securing economy in government expenditures; and for other purposes, all in accordance with a land use plan for the development of the city, the mayor and council do hereby ordain and enact into law the following articles and sections of this chapter. 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Res. of 3-12-1985, art. I; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Sec. 42-2. - Short title. 
This chapter shall be known as the "Lake City Zoning Regulations." 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Res. of 3-12-1985, art. II; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Secs. 42-3—42-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PROVISION OF OFFICIAL ZONING MAP; ESTABLISHMENT OF DISTRICTS 

Sec. 42-23. - Official zoning map. 
(a)  The city is hereby divided into zoning districts, as shown on the official zoning map, which, together with all explanatory matter thereon, is hereby adopted by reference and declared to be a part of this chapter. 
(b)  The official zoning map shall be identified by the signature of the mayor and attested by the city clerk, and bearing the seal of the city under the following words: "This is to certify that this is the official zoning map referred to in the Lake City Zoning Regulations," together with the date of adoption of the resolution from which this chapter is derived. 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Res. of 3-12-1985, art. III, § 3.1; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Sec. 42-24. - Amendments to maps. 
(a)  If, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, changes are made in district boundaries or other matter portrayed on the official zoning map, such changes shall be entered on the official zoning map periodically after the amendment has been approved by the mayor and council, with an entry in the minutes of such council meeting as follows: "On ____________ , 20 ____________ , by official action of the mayor and council, the following (change) changes (was) were made to the official zoning map: (brief description of nature of changes or changes)," which entry shall be signed by the mayor and attested by the city clerk. No amendment to this chapter is official until such change and entry is made on said map. 
(b)  No changes of any nature shall be made in the official zoning map or matter shown thereon except in conformity with the procedures set forth in this chapter. 
(c)  Regardless of the existence of purported copies of the official zoning map which may from time to time be made or published, the official zoning map which shall be located in the office of the city clerk shall be the final authority as to the current zoning status of the city. 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Res. of 3-12-1985, art. III, § 3.2; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Sec. 42-25. - Replacement of official zoning map. 
(a)  In the event that the official zoning map becomes damaged, destroyed, lost or difficult to interpret because of the nature or number of changes and additions, the mayor and council may, by resolution, adopt a new official zoning map which shall supersede the prior official zoning map. The new official zoning map may correct drafting or other errors or omissions in the prior official zoning map, but no such correction shall have the effect of amending the original official zoning map, and shall be identified by the signature of the mayor attested by the city clerk, and bearing the seal of the city under the following words: 
"This is to certify that this official zoning map supersedes and replaces the official zoning map adopted the date of ____________ , 20 ____________ , as part of the Lake City Zoning Regulations." 
(b)  Unless the previous official zoning map has been lost, or has been totally destroyed, the prior map or any significant remaining parts thereof, shall be preserved, together with all available records pertaining to its adoption or amendment. 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Res. of 3-12-1985, art. III, § 3.3; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Sec. 42-26. - Rules for interpretation of district boundaries. 
Where uncertainty exists with respect to the location of the boundaries of any zoning district in the city, the following rules shall apply: 
(1)  Where a zoning district boundary line is shown as approximately following a corporate limits line, a militia district line, a land lot line, a lot line or the centerline of a street, a county road, a state highway, an interstate highway, or a railroad right-of-way or such lines extended, then such lines shall be construed to be the zoning district boundary lines. 
(2)  Where a zoning district boundary line is shown as being set back from a street, a county road, a state highway, an interstate highway or a railroad right-of-way, and approximately parallel thereto, then such zoning district boundary line shall be construed as being at the scaled distance from the centerline of the street, county road, state highway, interstate highway or railroad right-of-way and as being parallel thereto. 
(3)  Where a zoning district boundary line divides a lot, the location of the line shall be the scaled distance from the lot lines. In this situation, the requirements of the zoning district in which the greater portion of the lot lies shall apply to the balance of the lot except that such extension shall not include any part of a lot that lies more than 50 feet beyond the zoning district boundary line. 
(4)  Where zoning district boundaries are in doubt, the mayor and council shall determine such boundaries using the appropriate scale from the official zoning map. 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Res. of 3-12-1985, art. III, § 3.4; Ord. No. 01-02, § 1(3.4), 7-9-2001; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Sec. 42-27. - Districts listed. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the incorporated land area of the city is divided into zoning districts designated as follows: 
(1)  RS-200 Single-Family Residence: 20,000 square foot lot district; provides for low density single-family residential uses. 
(2)  RS-150 Single-Family Residence: provides for the development of single-family residences on individual lots. 
(3)  RM Multiple-Family Residence: provides for moderate-high residential densities not to exceed ten dwelling units per acre. 
(4)  RMH Mobile Home or Manufactured Home Park Residence: provides for mobile home or manufactured home parks. 
(5)  OI Office/Institutional: provides a location for offices, institutions and limited, related retail businesses and services. 
(6)  BN Neighborhood Business: provides a location for convenience and service establishments or individual lots or within planned shopping centers when serving the day-to-day need of residents of adjacent residential neighborhoods. 
(7)  BG General Business: provides for a wide range of retail, service and related commercial establishments. 
(8)  M Manufacturing: provides for heavy commercial and light industrial uses which are compatible with land use plan objectives. 
(9)  SCR Shopping Center Reuse: allows the repurposing of an existing development of land to provide for a wide range of retail, service and wholesale establishments. 
(10)  G-1 Gateway Village Development: established as part of a collaborative partnership between the City of Lake City, Georgia, City of Morrow, Georgia, and Clayton College and State University (CCSU) for the purpose of establishing architectural and site design standards for the regulation of new development and construction as well as the creation of a Gateway Village Master Plan. 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Sec. 42-28. - Annexation. 
Any land annexed into the city shall, upon such annexation and unless otherwise zoned upon such annexation, automatically be classified in the RS-200 Single-Family Residence District and remain so zoned until an amendment to this chapter shall place such annexed land into a different district. 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Res. of 3-12-1985, art. III, § 3.6; Ord. No. 01-02, § 2(3.6), 7-9-2001; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Secs. 42-29—42-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - APPLICATION OF DISTRICT REGULATIONS 

Sec. 42-60. - Uniformity. 
The regulations set by this chapter within each district shall be minimum regulations and shall apply uniformly to each class or kind of structure or land, and particularly, except as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Sec. 42-61. - Applicability to land, buildings and open space. 
No building, structure, land or open space shall hereafter be used or occupied and no building or structure or part thereof shall hereafter be erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved, or structurally altered unless in conformity with all of the regulations herein specified for the district in which it is located. 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Sec. 42-62. - Height and density. 
No building or other structure shall hereafter be erected or altered: 
(1)  To exceed the height or bulk limits of this chapter; 
(2)  To accommodate or house a greater number of families; 
(3)  To occupy a greater percentage of lot area; 
(4)  To have narrower or smaller rear yards, front yards, side yards, or other open spaces than herein required; 
or in any other manner be contrary to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Sec. 42-63. - Lot size and occupancy. 
No lot, even though it may consist of one or more adjacent lots in the same ownership at the time of passage of the resolution from which this chapter is derived, shall be reduced in size so that lot width or size of yards of lot area per family or any other requirements of this chapter are not maintained. This section shall not apply when a portion of a lot is acquired for public use. 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Sec. 42-64. - Yard and other spaces. 
No part of a yard or other open space or off-street parking or loading spaces required about any one building shall be included as a part of the yard or off-street parking or loading spaces required for another building, except as specifically provided for herein. 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Sec. 42-65. - One principal building on a lot. 
For residential development, only one principal building and its accessory buildings may hereafter be erected on any one lot, except as otherwise provided for in this chapter. 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Sec. 42-66. - Minimum lot sizes for residences using septic tank systems. 
No single-family residence shall be permitted on a lot of less than 25,000 square feet in a new subdivision which is to be served by septic tanks, regardless of the zoning district classification. With respect to existing platted lots, the county board of health will evaluate each individual request for a permit on a case-by-case basis. This restriction on lot size does not apply to residential development served by community sewer systems. 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Editor's note— As of the publication date of the 2015 Code of Ordinances, the square footage requirement for the above section from 20,000 to 25,000 square feet, pursuant to City Code 1994 § 92-1 (Regulations adopted by reference) which adopted by reference the entirety of the Clayton County Subdivision Regulations (§ 86-161(b), Sanitary Sewer Standards, adopted May 22, 2008). 
Sec. 42-67. - Street frontage requirement. 
No building or structure shall hereafter be erected on a lot that does not abut for at least a distance of 25 feet upon a public street, a publicly approved street or a publicly maintained street. 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Secs. 42-68—42-92. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - NONCONFORMING USES 

Sec. 42-93. - Continued. 
(a)  Within the zoning districts established by this chapter or amendments that may later be adopted there exists: lots, structures, uses of land and structures; which were lawful before the resolution from which this chapter is derived was passed or amended, but which would be prohibited, regulated, or restricted under the terms of this chapter or future amendment. It is the intent of this chapter to permit these nonconformities to continue until they are removed, but not to encourage their survival. It is further the intent of this chapter that nonconformities shall not be enlarged upon, expanded or extended, nor be used as grounds for adding other structures or uses prohibited elsewhere in the same district. 
(b)  Nonconforming uses are declared by this chapter to be incompatible with permitted uses in the districts involved. A nonconforming use of a structure, a nonconforming use of land, or a nonconforming use of structure and land in combination shall not be extended or enlarged after passage of the resolution from which this chapter is derived. 
(c)  To avoid undue hardship, nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to require a change in the plans, construction, or designated use of any building on which actual construction was lawfully begun prior to the effective date of adoption of the resolution from which this chapter is derived. Actual construction is hereby defined to include the placing of construction materials in permanent position and fastened in a permanent manner. Where excavation or demolition or removal of an existing building has been substantially begun preparatory to rebuilding, such excavation or demolition or removal shall be deemed to be actual construction. 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Sec. 42-94. - Nonconforming lots of record. 
(a)  In any district in which single-family dwellings are permitted, a single-family dwelling and customary accessory building may be erected on any single lot of record at the effective date of adoption or amendment of the resolution from which this chapter is derived, notwithstanding limitations imposed by other provisions of this chapter. Such lot must be in separate ownership and not of continuous frontage with other lots in the same ownership. This provision shall apply even though such lot fails to meet the requirements for area or width, or both, that are generally applicable in the district, provided that yard dimensions and requirements other than these applying to area or width, or both, of the lots shall conform to the regulations for the district in which such lot is located. 
(b)  If two or more lots or combinations of lots and portions of lots with continuous frontage in single ownership are of record at the time of passage or amendment of the resolution from which this chapter is derived, and if all or part of the lots do not meet the requirements established for lot width and area, the lands involved shall be considered to be undivided parcel for the purposes of this chapter, and no portion of said parcel shall be used or sold in a manner which diminishes compliance with lot width and area requirements established by this chapter, nor shall any division of any parcel be made which creates a lot with width or area below the requirements stated in this chapter. 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Sec. 42-95. - Nonconforming structures. 
Where a lawful structure exists at the effective date of adoption or amendment of the resolution from which this chapter is derived that could not be built under the terms of this chapter due to restrictions on area, lot coverage, height, yards, its location on the lot, or other requirements concerning the structure, such structure may be continued so long as it remains otherwise lawful, subject to the following provisions: 
(1)  No such nonconforming structure may be enlarged or altered in a way which increases its nonconformity, but any structure or portion thereof may be altered to decrease its nonconformity. 
(2)  Should such nonconforming structure or nonconforming portion of a structure be destroyed by any means to an extent of more than 50 percent of its replacement cost at time of destruction, it shall not be reconstructed except in conformity with the provisions of this chapter. 
(3)  Should such structure be moved for any reason for any distance whatever, it shall thereafter conform to the regulations for the district in which it is located after it is moved. 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Sec. 42-96. - Nonconforming uses of structures or of structures and premises in combination. 
If lawful use involving individual structures with a replacement cost of $1,000.00 or more, or of structure and premises in combination, exists at the effective date of adoption or amendment of the resolution from which this chapter is derived, the lawful use may be continued so long as it remains otherwise lawful, subject to the following provisions: 
(1)  No existing structure devoted to a use not permitted by this chapter in the district in which it is located shall be enlarged, extended, constructed, reconstructed, moved, or structurally altered except in changing the use of the structure to a use permitted in the district in which it is located. 
(2)  If no structural alterations are made, any nonconforming use of a structure, or structure and premises, may be changed to another nonconforming use, provided that the mayor and council either by general rule or by making findings in the specific case, shall find that the proposed use is equally appropriate or more appropriate to the district than the existing nonconforming use. In permitting such change, the mayor and council may require appropriate conditions and safeguards in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(3)  Any structure, or structure and land in combination, in or on which a nonconforming use is superseded by a permitted use, shall thereafter conform to the regulations for the district, and the nonconforming use may not thereafter be resumed. 
(4)  When a nonconforming use of a structure, or structure and premises in combination, is discontinued or abandoned for six consecutive months (except when government action impedes access to the premises), the structure, or structure and premises in combination, shall not thereafter be used except in conformity with the regulations of the district in which it is located. The intent, and any evidence thereof, of any owner and/or user of a structure, or structure and premises in combination, to discontinue or abandon the use shall be irrelevant in determining whether discontinuance or abandonment shall be based upon such objective evidence as would lead a reasonable observer of actual use of the structure, or structure and premises in combination, to believe that discontinuance or abandonment of the use has in fact occurred. 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Sec. 42-97. - Repairs and maintenance. 
(a)  On any nonconforming structure or portion of a structure containing a nonconforming use, work may be done in any period of 12 consecutive months on ordinary repairs, or on repair or replacement of non-bearing walls, fixtures, wiring, or plumbing, to an extent not exceeding ten percent of the current replacement cost of the nonconforming portion of the structure, as the case may be, provided that the cubic content existing when it became nonconforming shall not be increased. 
(b)  If a nonconforming structure or portion of a structure containing a nonconforming use becomes physically unsafe or unlawful due to lack of repairs and maintenance, and is declared by any duly authorized official to be unlawful by reason of physical condition, it shall not thereafter be restored, repaired, or rebuilt except in conformity with the regulations of the district in which it is located. 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Secs. 42-98—42-122. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - INTERPRETATION AND DEFINITIONS 

Sec. 42-123. - Interpretation. 
For the purpose of this chapter, the following interpretations shall apply: 
(1)  All words used in the present tense include the future tense. 
(2)  All words in the plural number include the singular number, and all words in the singular number include the plural number, unless the natural construction of the wording indicates otherwise. 
(3)  The word "shall" is mandatory and not directory. 
(4)  The word "used" shall be deemed also to include "designed, intended or arranged to be used." 
(Code 1994, § 110-1; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 5-13-2002) 
Sec. 42-124. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Accessory apartment means a dwelling unit created within an existing single-family home or on the same lot. An accessory apartment is an independent unit, but it may share an entrance, yard and parking with the principal unit. 
Accessory use means a use or structure on the same lot, and of a nature customarily and subordinate to, the principal use or structure. Examples of accessory uses include free standing garages, tennis courts, swimming pools and satellite dish antennas. 
Automobile means any motor vehicle including, but not limited to, cars, trucks, vans, and motorcycles. 
Automobile broker means a business or person who, for a commission or with the intent to make a profit or gain of money or other thing of value, negotiates or attempts to negotiate the sale of a new or used automobile on behalf of another without taking possession of the vehicle. Such term shall not mean any person engaged in the solicitation, negotiation, or advertising of the sale of used automobiles or any owner of real property who allows the display of a used automobile on such property if the sale of such vehicles is made by a used car dealer or a financial institution. 
Automobile dealer means a person or business who brokers, deals, or engages in the purchase, sale, lease, or exchange of five or more used automobiles within a twelve-month period or two or more used automobiles at any one point in time. 
Automobile repair means major or minor repair of automobiles as follows: 
(1)  Minor automobile repair service means replacement of parts, tires, tubes, or batteries; diagnostic services; minor maintenance services such as grease, oil, spark plug, or filter changing; wheel alignment or tire balancing; engine tune-ups; emergency road services; replacement of starters, alternators, hoses and brake parts; automobile washing or polishing; performing emission testing or other required inspections and making any minor repairs necessary to pass said inspections; maintenance servicing of air-conditioning or exhaust systems; or similar servicing or repairs that do not normally require any significant disassembly or storing of automobiles on the premises overnight. This definition does not include any major repair service. 
(2)  Major automobile repair service means general repair, rebuilding or reconditioning of an automobile's engine or transmission system; collision service such as body, frame, or fender straightening or repair; automobile painting services; steam cleaning, undercoating or rust proofing; customizing; or any similar servicing, rebuilding, or repair that normally requires significant disassembly or storing of automobiles on the premises overnight. This definition includes any minor repair service which is offered addition to, or in conjunction with, any major repair service. 
Automobile repair garage means any building or land area, or any portion thereof, used for the provision of any major automobile repair service. 
Automotive retail establishment means any building or land area, or any portion thereof, used for the direct retail sale to the public on the premises of products necessary for automobile service or maintenance, provided that all such products are new and not previously used. Products necessary of automobile service or maintenance include, but are not limited to, engine fuels, motor oil and lubricants, grease for the purpose of operating an automobile, tires, batteries, brakes, and shock absorbers. The phrase "automotive retail establishment" does not include any building or land area, or any portion thereof, used for the storage of automobiles or for the provision of any major automobile repair service or any minor automobile repair service. 
Automobile sales establishment means a place of business where a manufacturer, authorized business or dealer engages in the sale, lease, or exchange of new and used automobiles where a majority of the sales inventory is new. 
Automobile salvage shop means any building or land area, or portion thereof, where a person, a business, or other entity destroys, dismantles, disassembles, recycles, or stores for later dismantling, destruction, disassembling, or recycling any automobile or part thereof and may engage in the sale of used automobile parts or scrap in connection with the provision of major repair services or minor repair Services. An automobile salvage shop is not a junk or salvage yard. 
Automobile service station means any building or land area, or any portion thereof, used for the provision of any minor automobile repair service. 
Boardinghouse or roominghouse means a dwelling in which meals or lodging or both are furnished for compensation to more than two but not more than ten non-transient persons. 
Buffer means a planted area of width to be determined by the mayor and council, the purpose of which is to insulate existing uses from new or expanding incompatible or marginally compatible land uses. 
Buildable area means the portion of a lot remaining after required yards have been provided. 
Building means any structure attached to the ground which has a roof and which is designed for the shelter, housing or enclosure of persons, animals or property of any kind. 
Building inspector means the official appointed by the city and charged with the responsibility of issuing permits and certificates of zoning compliance. 
Building, height of, means the vertical distance measured from the average elevation of the proposed finished grade to the highest point of the coping of a flat roof or to the deck line of a mansard roof, or to the average height of the highest gable of a pitch or hip roof. 
Building, principal, means a building or structure in which is conducted the principal use of the lot on which said building is situated. 
Certificate of zoning compliance means a permit issued by the zoning administrator indicating that the use of the building or land in question is in conformity with this chapter or that there has been a legal variance therefrom as provided by this chapter. 
Clinic means an establishment where patients, who are not lodged overnight, are admitted for examination and treatment by one physician or dentist or a group of physicians or dentists practicing medicine. 
Club means a building or facilities owned or operated by and for special educational or recreational purposes, but not primarily for profit, or to render a service that is customarily carried on for gain. 
Conditional uses means a use which may be permitted within a zoning district subject to meeting specific conditions contained in this chapter or required by the mayor and council. 
Condominium means the ownership in fee simple title of a single unit in a multi-unit structure and undivided ownership, in common with other purchases, of the common elements of the structure and including the land and its appurtenances. 
Convenience store means any building or land area, or any portion thereof, used primarily for the retail sale or offering of sale to the public of a range of everyday items such as groceries, snack food, candy, toiletries, soft drinks, tobacco products and newspapers and includes any incidental retail dispensing, sale or offering of sale of motor fuels to uses or motor vehicles. The phrase "convenience store" does not include any building or land area, or any portion thereof, used for the storage of automobiles or for the provision of any major automobile repair service or any minor automobile repair service. 
County street means a street which is owned and/or maintained by Clayton County. 
Drive-in restaurant means any place or premises used for sale, dispensing or service of food, refreshment, or beverages in automobiles, including those establishments where customers may eat or drink the food, or beverage on the premises. 
Dwelling means a building or portion thereof which is designed or used exclusively for residential purposes, including single-family, two-family, multiple-family dwellings, roominghouses and boardinghouses, fraternities, sororities, and modular dwellings, but not including hotels or motels. 
Dwelling, mobile home or manufactured home, means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length or, when erected on site, is 320 or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and electrical systems contained therein and manufactured prior to June 15, 1976. 
Dwelling, multiple-family, means a building or portion thereof designed for three or more dwelling units, with the number of families in residence not exceeding the number of dwelling units provided. 
Dwelling, single-family, means a detached residential unit other than a mobile home or manufactured home, hotel or motel, designed for and occupied by one family only. 
Dwelling, single-family attached, means a structure subdivided by a coincidental property line and wall which separates the structure into a maximum of two dwelling units, each occupying its own lot. The two lots created by the coincidental property line and wall shall each contain at least 50 percent of the minimum lot area in the zoning district in which they are located, 50 percent of the minimum lot width in the zoning district in which they are located, and 50 percent of the minimum gross floor area in the zoning district in which they are located. An attached single-family structure must meet all front, rear and side yard setback requirements in the zoning district in which it is located, except for the coincidental property line and wall. Each unit must be separately metered for all utilities, and the coincidental property wall must be fire-rated and extend from the foundation to the roof decking of the structure. Otherwise, an attached single-family structure must meet all standards that would be required for two family dwellings in the zoning districts in which they are located. 
Dwelling, two-family, means a detached residential building containing two dwelling units, designed for occupancy by not more than two families living independent of each other. 
Dwelling unit means one room, or rooms connected together, constituting a separate, independent housekeeping establishment of owner occupancy, for rental or lease on a weekly, monthly, or longer basis, and physically separated from any other rooms or dwelling units which may be in the same structure, and containing independent cooking, sleeping and toilet facilities. 
Family means one or more persons occupying a single dwelling unit, provided that, unless all members are related by blood or marriage, no such family shall contain over five persons, but further provided that domestic servants employed on the premises may be housed on the premises without being counted as a separate family or families. The term "family" does not include any organization or institutional group. 
Flea market means any event or area at which two or more persons or entities offer merchandise for sale or exchange, and either a fee is charged by the owner or operator of the event or area to such persons or entities for the privilege of offering such merchandise for sale or exchange, or a fee is charged to prospective buyers from for admission to the area or event at which merchandise is offered or displayed for sale or exchange. The term "fee" refers to any compensatory arrangement between the owner/operator of a flea market and the owner/operator's vendor. 
Floor area means the floor area is the gross horizontal area of the several floors of a structure, exclusive of carport, basement, attic and open porches. 
Gasoline service station means any building or land area, or any portion thereof, used primarily for the retail dispensing, sale or offering of sale of motor fuels to users of motor vehicles and includes any incidental retail sale of a range of everyday items such as groceries, snack food, candy toiletries, soft drinks, tobacco products and newspapers or of minor accessories necessary for the operation of a motor vehicle such as oil, antifreeze or windshield wipers. The phrase "gasoline service station" does not include any building or land area, or any portion thereof, used for the provision of any major automobile repair service or any minor automobile repair service. 
Ground coverage means the area of a lot occupied by all buildings expressed as a percentage of the gross area of the lot. 
Home occupation means a business, occupation or profession carried on within a single-family residential dwelling by the resident thereof, as regulated in section 42-152. 
Inoperable vehicle means any motorized vehicle incapable of immediately being driven. 
Junk or salvage yard means a place where waste, discarded or salvaged metals, building materials, paper, textiles, used plumbing fixtures, used cars or trucks in inoperable condition are bought, sold, exchanged, stored, baled or cleaned. 
Loading space, off-street, means space logically and conveniently located for bulk pickups and deliveries, scaled to the size of delivery vehicles expected to be used. 
Lot means a parcel of land occupied or intended for occupancy by a building or use, and any accessory building and use incidental to it, and including open space not less in extent than that required by this chapter, and having its principal frontage upon a public street. 
Lot, corner, means a lot situated at the intersection of two streets, or bounded on two or more adjacent sides by street right-of-way lines. 
Lot, double frontage, means a lot having frontage on two non-intersecting streets, as distinguished from a corner lot. 
Lot frontage means that portion of a lot adjacent to a street. 
Lot, interior, means a lot other than a corner lot or a through lot. 
Lot line means a boundary of a lot. The term "lot line" is synonymous with property line. 
Lot of record means an individual lot or a lot which is a part of a subdivision, the map of which has been recorded in the office of the clerk of superior court of the county; or a parcel of land, the deed of which has been recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of the county. 
Lot width means the distance between side lot lines measured at the minimum front yard setback line. 
Manufactured home means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length or, when erected on site, is 320 or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air-conditioning, and electrical systems contained therein; except that the term "manufactured home" includes any structure which meets all the requirements of this definition except the size requirements and with respect to which the manufacturer voluntarily files a certification required by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and complies with the standards established under the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974, 42 USC 5401 et seq. 
Mini-warehouse means a building or portion thereof used for dead storage, mainly of the excess personal property of an individual or family, but also of small amounts of goods or merchandise for businesses or individuals. The term "mini-warehouse" shall not include retail sale on the premises, commercial repair or other services, manufacturing or any other commercial use. 
Mobile home or manufactured home park means a tract of land that is used, designated, maintained, or held out for rent to accommodate three or more mobile homes or manufactured homes. Mobile homes or manufactured home located in a mobile home or manufactured home park are used only to provide living and sleeping accommodations. A mobile home or manufactured home park does not include an automobile or mobile home or manufactured home sales lot on which unoccupied mobile homes or manufactured homes are parked for inspection or sale. 
Modular home means a factory-fabricated transportable building consisting of units designed to be incorporated at a building site on a permanent foundation into a structure to be used for residential purposes. 
Nonconforming use means any building, structure, or use of land lawful at the time of passage of amendment of the resolution from which this chapter is derived which does not conform, after the passage or amendment of the resolution from which this chapter is derived, with the regulations of the district in which it is located. 
Nursing home means a home for the aged, chronically ill, or incurable persons in which three or more persons not of the immediate family are kept or provided with food and shelter or care for compensation; The term "nursing home" does not include hospitals, clinics, or other similar institutions devoted primarily to the diagnosis and treatment of the sick or injured. 
Parking space, off-street, means an off-street parking space consisting of a space adequate for parking an automobile with room for opening doors on both sides, together with properly related access to a public street or alley and maneuvering room, design standards for which are contained in this chapter. 
Pawn shop means any establishment engaged in whole or in part in the business of lending money on the security of pledged goods (as that term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 44-12-130(5)), or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property on a condition that it may be redeemed or repurchased by the seller for a fixed price within a fixed period of time, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property from persons or sources other than manufacturers or licensed dealers as part of or in conjunction with the business activities described in this paragraph. 
Principal permitted use means that use of a lot which is among the uses allowed as a matter of right under the zoning classifications. 
Private deed restrictions or covenants means private deed restrictions or covenants imposed on land by private landowners. Private deed restrictions bind and restrict the land in the hands of present owners and subsequent purchasers and are enforced only by the landowners involved and not by the city or other public agency. 
Right-of-way means access over or across a particularly described property for a specific purpose.
